human_text: This paper describes the Wide Field Spectrograph (WiFeS) under construction at the Research School of Astronomy and Astrophysics (RSAA) of the Australian National University (ANU) for the ANU 2.3m telescope at the Siding Spring Observatory. WiFeS is a powerful integral field, double-beam, concentric, image-slicing spectrograph designed to deliver excellent thoughput, wavelength stability, spectrophotometric performance and superb image quality along with wide spectral coverage throughout the 320-950 nm wavelength region. It provides a 25x38 arcsec. field with 0.5 arcsec. sampling along each of twenty five 38X1 arcsec slitlets. The output format is optimized to match the 4096x4096 pixel CCD detectors in each of two cameras individually optimized for the blue and the red ends of the spectrum, respectively. A process of 'interleaved nod-and-shuffle' will be applied to permit quantum noise-limited sky subtraction. Using VPH gratings, spectral resolutions of 3000 and 7000 are provided. The full spectral range is covered in a single exposure at R=3000, and in two exposures in the R=7000 mode. The use of transmissive coated optics, VPH gratings and optimized mirror coatings ensures a throughput (including telescope atmosphere and detector) > 30

machine_text: In this study, we investigate the formation and collapse of quiescent cloud cores induced by dynamic compressions. The motivation for our research is to better understand the key physical processes that trigger the formation and collapse of quiescent cloud cores. These cores are crucial in the formation of stars, planets, and other astronomical objects. Identifying the factors that contribute to the formation and collapse of these cloud cores, as well as understanding the dynamics of their evolution, will ultimately improve our understanding of the universe and how it has evolved over time.Our key approach in this work involves numerical simulations, which allow us to investigate the behavior of cloud cores under dynamic compression conditions. We employ a three-dimensional, magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) simulation model to study the effect of compressing a pre-existing cloud core. Our simulation setup includes a hydrostatic initial equilibrium cloud that is subjected to a pulse-driven shock compression. By tracking the evolution of the cloud core under these conditions, we are able to analyze the mechanisms that drive its formation and collapse.The problem that this work attempts to solve is the lack of a comprehensive understanding of the physical processes that govern the formation and collapse of quiescent cloud cores. By studying these processes within the framework of our simulation model, we aim to develop a more detailed understanding of these phenomena and their role in the formation of astronomical objects. Our findings will be relevant to researchers studying the evolution of the universe and the conditions that led to the formation of stars and other celestial bodies.

human_text: (Abridged) We present numerical hydrodynamical simulations of the formation, evolution and gravitational collapse of isothermal molecular cloud cores. A compressive wave is set up in a constant sub-Jeans density distribution of radius r = 1 pc. As the wave travels through the simulation grid, a shock-bounded spherical shell is formed. The inner shock of this shell reaches and bounces off the center, leaving behind a central core with an initially almost uniform density distribution, surrounded by an envelope consisting of the material in the shock-bounded shell, with a power-law density profile that at late times approaches a logarithmic slope of -2 even in non-collapsing cases. The resulting density structure resembles a quiescent core of radius < 0.1 pc, with a Bonnor-Ebert-like (BE-like) profile, although it has significant dynamical differences: it is initially non-self-gravitating and confined by the ram pressure of the infalling material, and consequently, growing continuously in mass and size. With the appropriate parameters, the core mass eventually reaches an effective Jeans mass, at which time the core begins to collapse. Thus, there is necessarily a time delay between the appearance of the core and the onset of its collapse, but this is not due to the dissipation of its internal turbulence as it is often believed. These results suggest that pre-stellar cores may approximate Bonnor-Ebert structures which are however of variable mass and may or may not experience gravitational collapse, in qualitative agreement with the large observed frequency of cores with BE-like profiles.

machine_text: In this study, we conduct a multi-wavelength analysis of 18um-selected galaxies in the AKARI/IRC monitor field towards the North Ecliptic Pole. The motivation behind our research is to study the role of infrared (IR) luminous galaxies in galaxy formation and evolution. Our methodology involved cross-matching the AKARI/IRC 18um-selected galaxy sample with the Herschel/PACS and SPIRE maps, as well as the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) database. We performed a spectral energy distribution (SED) fitting to derive the physical parameters of the galaxies, such as star formation rate, dust temperature, and luminosity.Our results show that the majority of the galaxies were classified as infrared-luminous, with high star formation rates and dust temperatures. We also found that these galaxies have higher dust obscuration than the average SDSS galaxy. Furthermore, we observed a trend between the IR luminosity and dust temperature, suggesting a link between dust heating and star formation activity. Finally, we compared our sample with previous studies and found that our selection criteria have successfully identified a substantial number of IR-luminous galaxies at high redshifts.In conclusion, our multi-wavelength analysis has allowed us to gain a better understanding of the physical properties and evolution of IR-luminous galaxies. Our study is relevant to the ongoing efforts to explore the formation and evolution of galaxies in the era of cosmic reionization.

human_text: We present an initial analysis of AKARI 18um-selected galaxies using all 9 photometric bands at 2-24um available in the InfraRed Camera (IRC), in order to demonstrate new capabilities of AKARI cosmological surveys. We detected 72 sources at 18um in an area of 50.2 arcmin^2 in the AKARI/IRC monitor field towards the North Ecliptic Pole (NEP). From this sample, 25 galaxies with probable redshifts z>0.5 are selected with a single colour cut (N2-N3>0.1) for a detailed SED analysis with ground-based BVRi'z'JK data. Using an SED radiative transfer model of starbursts covering the wavelength range UV – submm, we derive photometric redshifts from the optical-MIR SEDs of 18um-selected galaxies. From the best-fit SED models, we show that the IRC all-band photometry is capable of tracing the steep rise in flux at the blue side of the PAH 6.2um emission feature. This indicates that the IRC all-band photometry is useful to constrain the redshift of infrared galaxies, specifically for dusty galaxies with a less prominent 4000A break. Also, we find that the flux dip between the PAH 7.7 and 11.2um emission feature is recognizable in the observed SEDs of galaxies at z 1. By using such a colour anomaly due to the PAH and silicate absorption features, unique samples of ULIRGs at z 1, `silicate-break' galaxies, can be constructed from large cosmological surveys of AKARI towards the NEP, i.e. the NEP-Deep and NEP-Wide survey. This pilot study suggests the possibility of detecting many interesting galaxy properties in the NEP-Deep and Wide surveys, such as a systematic difference in SEDs between high- and low-z ULIRGs, and a large variation of the PAH inter-band strength ratio in galaxies at high redshifts. [abridged]

machine_text: In this study, we analyzed the nature of the short duration Gamma Ray Burst (GRB) 050906. The primary objective of the study was to uncover the physical mechanism behind the burst and its characteristics. We first investigated the spectral properties of this event using data obtained from various observatories, such as the Swift satellite. After a detailed analysis, we discovered that GRB 050906 was a single pulse event with a very hard spectrum, indicating high-energy photons.To explain the observed spectral characteristics of this GRB, we proposed a model that involves the synchrotron radiation of charged particles in a magnetic field. We further applied the synchrotron self-Compton model to explain the high-energy emission observed in this event. Our findings suggest that the magnetic field was likely to be the dominant factor in the production of this GRB.Through this study, we hope to provide a better understanding of the nature of short-duration gamma-ray bursts and their physical mechanisms. This research adds to the growing body of knowledge on astrophysics, especially in high-energy astronomy. The methodology involved obtaining and analyzing data, followed by advanced modeling of the physical processes responsible for GRB 050906. These results can provide future directions for research in high-energy astrophysics and the study of gamma-ray bursts.

machine_text: We present the results of our investigation on the growth behavior of millimeter-thick single-walled carbon nanotube (SWCNT) forests and possible growth mechanisms that give rise to the unique characteristics of these structures. Our motivation for this study stems from the potential of these forests to have large surface areas and high conductivity, which make them ideal for various applications including electrochemical energy storage, sensing, and electronic devices.Our work involves optimizing the growth parameters to obtain uniform and dense SWCNT forests that are several millimeters thick. We investigate the growth window, which refers to the range of growth conditions that enable the formation of the desired structure, as well as the role of the catalyst and gas flow rates in achieving the desired growth behavior. Furthermore, we propose a possible growth mechanism based on the saturation of reactive sites and kinetic limitations that explain the dependence of forest thickness on the growth time.The problem that our work attempts to solve is the lack of understanding of the growth behavior of millimeter-thick SWCNT forests, which hinders their widespread adoption in practical applications. Our study provides insights into the factors that affect the growth of these structures and a possible mechanism that can be used to rationally design and tailor their properties for specific applications.

Our study provides insights into the factors that affect the growth of these structures and a possible mechanism that can be used to rationally design and tailor their properties for specific applications.

human_text: Our group recently reproduced the water-assisted growth method, so-called 'super growth', of millimeter-thick single-walled carbon nanotube (SWNT) forests by using C2H4/ H2/ H2O/ Ar reactant gas and Fe/ Al2O3 catalyst. In this current work, a parametric study was carried out on both reaction and catalyst conditions. Results revealed that a thin Fe catalyst layer (about 0.5 nm) yielded rapid growth of SWNTs only when supported on Al2O3, and that Al2O3 support enhanced the activity of Fe, Co, and Ni catalysts. The growth window for the rapid SWNT growth was narrow, however. Optimum amount of added H2O increased the SWNT growth rate but further addition of H2O degraded both the SWNT growth rate and quality. Addition of H2 was also essential for rapid SWNT growth, but again, further addition decreased both the SWNT growth rate and quality. Because Al2O3 catalyzes hydrocarbon reforming, Al2O3 support possibly enhances the SWNT growth rate by supplying the carbon source to the catalyst nanoparticles. The origin of the narrow window for rapid SWNT growth will also be discussed.

machine_text: Our research aims to explore the Quantum Electrodynamics (QED) of qubits, with the motivation of enhancing the capabilities of quantum computing and communication systems. In our study, we observed the behavior of a qubit in a superconducting circuit in the presence of a applied electromagnetic field. We found that the behavior of a qubit can be modeled as a simple forced oscillator system, which experiences Rabi oscillations when driven by a microwave field. Furthermore, we identified that the qubit exhibits both coherent and incoherent behavior, which is attributed to the qubit environment’s temperature and the strength of the applied field.Our work attempts to solve the existing problem in the field, one of which includes understanding the interaction of qubits with electromagnetic field and its impact on the qubit’s behavior. The study of QED is essential for understanding quantum coherent behavior and harvesting its potential for computation and communication technology. Our findings offer essential insights into the dynamics of qubits in the presence of a driving field and are crucial for designing efficient and error-free quantum computing and communication systems.Thus, our work on Quantum Electrodynamics of qubits demonstrates the significance of exploring the dynamics of qubits in a complex environment, which can be applied to the design and development of advanced quantum technology.

human_text: Systematic description of a spin one-half system endowed with magnetic moment or any other two-level system (qubit) interacting with the quantized electromagnetic field is developed. This description exploits a close analogy between a two-level system and the Dirac electron that comes to light when the two-level system is described within the formalism of second quantization in terms of fermionic creation and annihilation operators. The analogy enables one to introduce all the powerful tools of relativistic QED (albeit in a greatly simplified form). The Feynman diagrams and the propagators turn out to be very useful. In particular, the QED concept of the vacuum polarization finds its close counterpart in the photon scattering off a two level-system leading via the linear response theory to the general formulas for the atomic polarizability and the dynamic single spin susceptibility. To illustrate the usefulness of these methods, we calculate the polarizability and susceptibility up to the fourth order of perturbation theory. These ab initio calculations resolve some ambiguities concerning the sign prescription and the optical damping that arise in the phenomenological treatment. We also show that the methods used to study two-level systems (qubits) can be extended to many-level systems (qudits). As an example, we describe the interaction with the quantized electromagnetic field of an atom with four relevant states: one S state and three degenerate P states.

machine_text: Our research explores the concept of asynchronous games and their potential to promote innocent gameplay without the interference of alternation. In today's world, it has become increasingly difficult to find time to engage in games with others as people live in different time zones and have varying schedules. Asynchronous games provide an opportunity to play without the need for synchronisation and interruption.In our study, we examined the characteristics of asynchronous games and analysed their potential to create a non-alternation gaming environment. We found that these games offer a way to promote simple, innocent gameplay without the need for in-game interference or the pressure of time-limited gameplay.Our methodology involved conducting an in-depth analysis of various asynchronous games and their features, followed by interviews with gamers who had played these games. Our results suggest that asynchronous games are popular within the gaming community because they provide a way to play games without the burden of having to be on at the same time as others.In conclusion, our findings indicate that asynchronous games offer a valuable alternative to synchronous games, providing opportunities for innocent gameplay without the distraction of alternation. In a world where time is precious, asynchronous games provide gamers with the chance to engage in enjoyable gameplay at their own pace.

human_text: The notion of innocent strategy was introduced by Hyland and Ong in order to capture the interactive behaviour of lambda-terms and PCF programs. An innocent strategy is defined as an alternating strategy with partial memory, in which the strategy plays according to its view. Extending the definition to non-alternating strategies is problematic, because the traditional definition of views is based on the hypothesis that Opponent and Proponent alternate during the interaction. Here, we take advantage of the diagrammatic reformulation of alternating innocence in asynchronous games, in order to provide a tentative definition of innocence in non-alternating games. The task is interesting, and far from easy. It requires the combination of true concurrency and game semantics in a clean and organic way, clarifying the relationship between asynchronous games and concurrent games in the sense of Abramsky and Melliès. It also requires an interactive reformulation of the usual acyclicity criterion of linear logic, as well as a directed variant, as a scheduling criterion.

machine_text: In this work, we explore the anatomy of malicious singularities and their impact on computer systems. Our analysis is motivated by the need to better understand the inner workings of these singularities and to develop effective defenses against them. Our research reveals that malicious singularities are often the result of exploiting vulnerabilities in software and hardware systems, and that they can have devastating consequences such as data loss, identity theft, and system compromise.To uncover the anatomy of malicious singularities, we employed a combination of techniques including code analysis, reverse engineering, and experimentation. Through these efforts, we discovered the key features and behaviors of malicious singularities, including their ability to self-replicate, evade detection, and propagate to other systems. Furthermore, we identified specific attack vectors that are commonly used by attackers to exploit vulnerabilities and create malicious singularities.Our research serves as an important step towards developing more effective defenses against malicious singularities. By understanding their anatomy and attack vectors, we can design more robust and secure systems that are better able to withstand attacks. Overall, our work contributes to the development of a safer and more secure computing environment for individuals and organizations alike.

human_text: As well known, the b-boundaries of the closed Friedman world model and of Schwarzschild solution consist of a single point. We study this phenomenon in a broader context of differential and structured spaces. We show that it is an equivalence relation ρ, defined on the Cauchy completed total space E̅ of the frame bundle over a given space-time, that is responsible for this pathology. A singularity is called malicious if the equivalence class [p_0] related to the singularity remains in close contact with all other equivalence classes, i.e., if p_0 ∈cl[p] for every p ∈ E. We formulate conditions for which such a situation occurs. The differential structure of any space-time with malicious singularities consists only of constant functions which means that, from the topological point of view, everything collapses to a single point. It was noncommutative geometry that was especially devised to deal with such situations. A noncommutative algebra on E̅, which turns out to be a von Neumann algebra of random operators, allows us to study probabilistic properties (in a generalized sense) of malicious singularities. Our main result is that, in the noncommutative regime, even the strongest singularities are probabilistically irrelevant.

machine_text: In this paper, we investigate the existence and distribution of rational points on certain elliptic surfaces. The overarching problem we attempt to solve is the determination of the density and structure of rational points on elliptic surfaces over number fields using techniques from algebraic and arithmetic geometry.To address this problem, we focus on surfaces with an elliptic fibration whose fibers are non-isotrivial and have potentially good reduction. We develop a method to construct rational points on such surfaces by combining different algebraic and arithmetic techniques. In particular, we use Falting's theorem to bound the height function of the rational points and adapt the Congruences Method to obtain rational points by checking congruences modulo different primes.Our motivation for this research stems from the importance of understanding the distribution of rational points in algebraic geometry, especially for elliptic surfaces, which play a fundamental role in number theory. Moreover, rational points on elliptic surfaces have applications in cryptography and coding theory.In summary, this paper presents new results on the existence and distribution of rational points on certain elliptic surfaces and provides insights into the geometry and arithmetic of these surfaces. Our methodology and techniques could be applied to other families of elliptic surfaces and thus open up new avenues of research in algebraic geometry and number theory.

In this paper we prove that if degf≤ 3, then there exists a rational base change t↦ϕ(t) such that on the surface E_f∘ϕ there is a non-torsion section. A similar theorem is valid in case when degf=4 and there exists t_0∈ such that infinitely many rational points lie on the curve E_t_0:y^2=x^3+f(t_0)x. Next, we consider a surface E^g:y^2=x^3+g(t), where g∈[t] is a monic polynomial of degree six. Furthermore, if there exists t_0∈ such that on the curve E^t_0:y^2=x^3+g(t_0) there are infinitely many rational points, then the set of these t_0 is infinite. We also present some results concerning diophantine equation of the form x^2-y^3-g(z)=t, where t is a variable.

machine_text: In this paper, we present the milliarcsecond-scale morphology of Compact Steep Spectrum (CSS) sources based on the Faint Images of the Radio Sky at Twenty-centimeters (FIRST) survey. The main goal of this study is to provide insight into the physical processes, such as jet propagation and interaction with the surrounding medium, that govern the evolution of CSS sources. To achieve this, we used a sample of 157 CSS sources identified from the FIRST survey and imaged them using Very Long Baseline Interferometry (VLBI) at 1.6 GHz.Our analysis reveals that the CSS sources display a diverse range of morphologies, including core-jet, double, and triple configurations. We also find that the sources with larger linear sizes exhibit more complex morphologies, which may indicate more powerful jets. Moreover, the radio emission in most of the objects is found to be confined within a few kiloparsecs from the center, which is consistent with the notion that CSS sources are early-stage stages in the evolution of larger radio galaxies.This study highlights the importance of high-resolution imaging and the utility of the FIRST survey for studying the milliarcsecond-scale morphology of radio sources. The results also provide valuable insights into the physical properties of CSS sources, and their evolution, which may have important implications for our understanding of the formation and growth of massive galaxies.

human_text: Multifrequency VLBA observations of the final group of ten objects in a sample of FIRST-based compact steep spectrum (CSS) sources are presented. The sample was selected to investigate whether objects of this kind could be relics of radio-loud AGNs switched off at very early stages of their evolution or possibly to indicate intermittent activity. Initial observations were made using MERLIN at 5 GHz. The sources have now been observed with the VLBA at 1.7, 5 and 8.4 GHz in a snapshot mode with phase-referencing. The resulting maps are presented along with unpublished 8.4-GHz VLA images of five sources. Some of the sources discussed here show a complex radio morphology and therefore a complicated past that, in some cases, might indicate intermittent activity. One of the sources studied - 1045+352 - is known as a powerful radio and infrared-luminous broad absorption line (BAL) quasar. It is a young CSS object whose asymmetric two-sided morphology on a scale of several hundred parsecs, extending in two different directions, may suggest intermittent activity. The young age and compact structure of 1045+352 is consistent with the evolution scenario of BAL quasars. It has also been confirmed that the submillimetre flux of 1045+352 can be seriously contaminated by synchrotron emission.

machine_text: In this work, we present an extensive study on the modelling effects and observational biases that can significantly affect Sunyaev-Zel'dovich (SZ) profiles and scaling relations within galaxy clusters. Our motivation for conducting this research lies in the need to better understand the SZ effect; a phenomenon that has become an essential tool in the measurement of cluster properties. However, the SZ effect is prone to various biases, including contamination by radio sources, calibration uncertainties, and astrophysical uncertainties affecting the modelling of the intracluster medium. Therefore, this work attempts to address these potential biases and modelling effects in SZ profiles to improve astrophysical interpretations and measurements and investigate the uncertainties in scaling relations.We use a sophisticated set of simulations to examine various bias and modelling effects that are not always taken into account in observational studies. human_text: We use high-resolution hydrodynamic re-simulations to investigate the properties of the thermal Sunyaev-Zel'dovich (SZ) effect from galaxy clusters. We compare results obtained using different physical models for the intracluster medium (ICM), and show how they modify the SZ emission in terms of cluster profiles and scaling relations. We also produce realistic mock observations to verify whether the results from hydrodynamic simulations can be confirmed. We find that SZ profiles depend marginally on the modelled physical processes, while they exhibit a strong dependence on cluster mass. The central and total SZ emission strongly correlate with the cluster X-ray luminosity and temperature. The logarithmic slopes of these scaling relations differ from the self-similar predictions by less than 0.2; the normalization of the relations is lower for simulations including radiative cooling. The observational test suggests that SZ cluster profiles are unlikely to be able to probe the ICM physics. The total SZ decrement appears to be an observable much more robust than the central intensity, and we suggest using the former to investigate scaling relations.

machine_text: In this paper, we present a novel wavelet-based algorithm, TRUFAS (Transit Real-time Unsuper-vised Frequency Analysis System), for the fast detection of planetary transits. The search for exoplanets by transit methods is crucial, but the current state-of-the-art algorithms for transit detection are computationally expensive, and their performance decreases with the amount of data analyzed. Our proposed algorithm overcomes this problem by processing large amounts of data in a short time, without sacrificing detection efficiency.The TRUFAS algorithm uses a wavelet-based technique to identify transit-like signals in the time series data. It works in the frequency domain to remove strong systematic errors during the search process. Based on tests done on simulated data and real data, we confirmed that TRUFAS performs better or as well as other algorithms, including the Box Least-Squares (BLS) algorithm. We compared the computed ranks of all algorithms on the same datasets and applied a reliability test to quantify their detection capabilities. The TRUFAS algorithm obtained a high RMS improvement percentage compared to other algorithms, signifying its superior transit detection efficiency.In conclusion, TRUFAS is a powerful tool for the large-scale transit search in the era of big data astronomy. The proposed algorithm overcomes computational limitations of traditional transit detection methods while being efficient and accurate. Furthermore, with its built-in frequency-based error correction and detection reliability assessment, TRUFAS can accelerate the discovery of new exoplanets.

human_text: Aims: We describe a fast, robust and automatic detection algorithm, TRUFAS, and apply it to data that are being expected from the CoRoT mission. Methods: The procedure proposed for the detection of planetary transits in light curves works in two steps: 1) a continuous wavelet transformation of the detrended light curve with posterior selection of the optimum scale for transit detection, and 2) a period search in that selected wavelet transformation. The detrending of the light curves are based on Fourier filtering or a discrete wavelet transformation. TRUFAS requires the presence of at least 3 transit events in the data. Results: The proposed algorithm is shown to identify reliably and quickly the transits that had been included in a standard set of 999 light curves that simulate CoRoT data. Variations in the pre-processing of the light curves and in the selection of the scale of the wavelet transform have only little effect on TRUFAS' results. Conclusions: TRUFAS is a robust and quick transit detection algorithm, especially well suited for the analysis of very large volumes of data from space or ground-based experiments, with long enough durations for the target-planets to produce multiple transit events.

machine_text: In this paper, we present our assessment of the Accretion vs Colliding Wind (AVCW) models for the gamma-ray binary LS I +61 303, which has been a topic of controversy among the astrophysical community. The motivation behind our research was the need to clarify the origin of the gamma-ray emission in this binary. Our methodology involved the use of non-LTE radiative transfer simulation to construct synthetic spectra, which were then compared with the observed data. We also made use of Chandra and HST observations to study the X-ray and optical emission, respectively.Our results suggest that the colliding wind scenario is favored over the accretion scenario since it better reproduces the observed gamma-ray spectrum of LS I +61 303. Furthermore, the colliding wind model is able to explain the observed behavior of the binary on larger timescales. This result is consistent with previous studies that have suggested that colliding wind interactions between high mass stars can produce non-thermal gamma-ray emission.In conclusion, our study provides new insights into the nature of gamma-ray emission in LS I +61 303, and adds to the growing body of evidence that suggests colliding wind models are a viable mechanism for producing non-thermal radiation in high-mass binary systems.

human_text: LS I +61 303 is a puzzling Be/X-ray binary with variable gamma-ray emission at up TeV energies. The nature of the compact object and the origin of the high-energy emission are unclear. One family of models invokes particle acceleration in shocks from the collision between the B-star wind and a relativistic pulsar wind, while another centers on a relativistic jet powered by accretion. Recent high-resolution radio observations showing a putative 'cometary tail' pointing away from the Be star near periastron have been cited as support for the pulsar-wind model. We wish here to carry out a quantitative assessment of these competing models for this extraordinary source. We apply a 3D SPH code for dynamical simulations of both the pulsar-wind-interaction and accretion-jet models. The former yields a description of the shape of the wind-wind interaction surface. The latter provides an estimation of the accretion rate. The results allow critical evaluation of how the two distinct models confront the data in various wavebands under a range of conditions. When one accounts for the 3D dynamical wind interaction under realistic constraints for the relative strength of the B-star and pulsar winds, the resulting form of the interaction front does not match the putative 'cometary tail' claimed from radio observations. On the other hand, dynamical simulations of the accretion-jet model indicate that the orbital phase variation of accretion power includes a secondary broad peak well away from periastron, thus providing a plausible way to explain the observed TeV gamma ray emission toward apastron. We conclude that the colliding-wind model is not clearly established for LS I +61 303, while the accretion-jet model can reproduce many key characteristics of the observed TeV gamma-ray emission.

machine_text: In this study, we investigate the projectile fragmentation of the ^86Kr beam at 64 MeV/nucleon, by using the fragment separator at the Radioactive Ion Beam Factory, Japan. The motivation for this research is to understand the fragmentation mechanism and the production of light and heavy fragments in intermediate energy heavy-ion collisions. This research attempts to provide insight into the production of heavy neutron-rich nuclei, which can be used in various applications in nuclear physics research. By measuring the fragment momenta and charges, we examined the fragmentation pattern and the production cross-sections for various fragments. We found that the production cross-sections for lighter fragments are higher than those for heavier ones, indicating that the light fragments are more readily produced than the heavy ones. We also observed that the isotopic distribution of the fragments is consistent with the statistical model of the fragmentation process. Finally, we compare our results with previous experimental data and theoretical models, highlighting the importance of the projectile-target combination and emphasizing our work's contribution to the understanding of projectile fragmentation at intermediate energies.

human_text: We measured fragmentation cross sections produced using the primary beam of ^86Kr at 64 MeV/nucleon on ^9Be and ^181Ta targets. The cross sections were obtained by integrating the momentum distributions of isotopes with 25<Z<36 measured using the RIPS fragment separator at RIKEN. The cross-section ratios obtained with the ^181Ta and ^9Be targets depend on the fragment masses, contrary to the simple geometrical models. We compared the extracted cross sections to EPAX; an empirical parameterization of fragmentation cross sections. Predictions from current EPAX parameterization severely overestimate the production cross sections of very neutron-rich isotopes. Attempts to obtain another set of EPAX parameters specific to the reaction studied here, to extrapolate the neutron-rich nuclei more accurately have not been very successful, suggesting that accurate predictions of production cross sections of nuclei far from the valley of stability require information of nuclear properties which are not present in EPAX.

machine_text: In this work, we investigate the sets of non-differentiability of Minkowski's question mark function using fractal analysis techniques. Our aim is to provide a deeper understanding of the behavior of this function in terms of its singularities and the nature of its graphs. The problem we attempt to solve is to identify the fractal dimension of these sets and determine their geometric properties.Our methodology relies on the use of the box-counting method and multifractal formalism. We analyze the local behavior of the non-differentiability sets using the local Hölder exponent, and we apply the multifractal formalism to obtain the singularity spectrum of these sets. Furthermore, we discuss the statistical properties of the singularities and study their scaling behavior when we vary the order of the local Hölder exponent.Our results show that the sets of non-differentiability of Minkowski's question mark function exhibit a fractal structure with non-integer fractal dimension and multifractal spectra. We also observe a critical point at which the singularity spectrum undergoes a transition from a continuous to a discrete distribution. Our findings provide novel insights into the singular behavior of Minkowski's question mark function and contribute to the current understanding of fractal geometry in mathematics and physics.

human_text: In this paper we study various fractal geometric aspects of the Minkowski question mark function Q. We show that the unit interval can be written as the union of the three sets Λ_0:={x:Q'(x)=0}, Λ_∞:={x:Q'(x)=∞}, and Λ_∼:={x:Q'(x) does not exist and Q'(x)≠∞}. The main result is that the Hausdorff dimensions of these sets are related in the following way. _H(ν_F)<_H(Λ_∼)= _H (Λ_∞) = _H (ℒ(h_top))<_H(Λ_0)=1.Here, ℒ(h_top) refers to the level set of theStern-Brocot multifractal decomposition at the topological entropyh_top=log2 of the Farey map F, and _H(ν_F) denotes the Hausdorff dimension of the measure of maximal entropy of the dynamical system associated with F. The proofs rely partially on the multifractal formalism for Stern-Brocot intervals and give non-trivial applications of this formalism.

machine_text: In this work, we present a detailed analysis of generic gravitational wave signals produced by the collapse of rotating stellar cores. The motivation behind this research is twofold. Firstly, rotating stellar cores are expected to be the progenitors of many astrophysical events that produce detectable gravitational waves, such as core-collapse supernovae and black hole formation. Secondly, existing models for predicting these signals are limited in their applicability and accuracy, and there is a need to develop more robust and general models.To address this, we use numerical simulations to study the collapse of rotating polytropic stars, varying the equation of state, initial conditions, and rotation rates. We use the spectral Einstein code to compute the gravitational wave signals produced by the collapse, identifying key features in the waveforms such as the presence of multiple oscillations, quasi-normal modes, and frequency modulations. Additionally, we investigate the impact of different parameters on the signal properties, such as the rotational energy and the equation of state.Our results demonstrate a clear connection between the properties of the collapsing star and the resulting gravitational wave signals, highlighting the importance of considering rotating stellar cores as a source of generic gravitational wave signals. This study provides a new framework for understanding and predicting the gravitational wave signals produced by core-collapse events, with potential applications in the field of gravitational wave astronomy.

human_text: We present detailed results from performing general relativistic (GR) simulations of stellar core collapse to a proto-neutron star, using a microphysical equation of state (EoS) as well as an approximate description of deleptonization during the collapse phase. We show that for a wide variety of rotation rates and profiles the gravitational wave (GW) burst signals from the core bounce are of a generic type, already known as Type I in the literature. In addition, for most models the characteristic frequency of the GW burst signal lies in a narrow range around approximately 718 Hz. In our systematic study, using both GR and Newtonian gravity, we identify, individually quantify, and discuss in detail the micro- and macrophysical mechanisms leading to this result, i.e. the effects of rotation, the EoS, and deleptonization. We also discuss the detectability prospects of such GW burst signals by GW detectors, and infer that such a generic type of signal templates will likely facilitate a more efficient search in current and future detectors of both interferometric and resonant type.

machine_text: This paper presents the implementation and performance analysis of Block Locally Optimal Preconditioned Eigenvalue Xolvers (BLOPEX) in hypre and PETSc libraries. The motivation for this work stems from the need to solve large and sparse eigenvalue problems arising in scientific and engineering applications. These problems are computationally intensive and often require the solution of a large number of eigenvalues and vectors. The traditional approach to solving these problems relies on iterative solvers, and the choice of a suitable preconditioner is critical for their convergence and efficiency. BLOPEX offers a flexible and effective framework for constructing preconditioners that take advantage of the spectral properties of the underlying matrix.The main objective of this work is to evaluate the performance of BLOPEX preconditioners in the context of the hypre and PETSc libraries, two widely used software packages for solving linear systems and eigenvalue problems. We assess the scalability, robustness, and accuracy of BLOPEX, as well as its impact on the overall solution time. Our experiments show that BLOPEX can significantly improve the convergence and efficiency of iterative solvers for a wide range of eigenvalue problems. The key ideas behind BLOPEX are to split the preconditioner construction into small, tractable problems based on local matrix blocks and to exploit the Krylov subspace framework for solving the resulting eigenvalue problems. Overall, our work highlights the potential of BLOPEX as a powerful tool for solving large-scale eigenvalue problems.

human_text: We describe our software package Block Locally Optimal Preconditioned Eigenvalue Xolvers (BLOPEX) publicly released recently. BLOPEX is available as a stand-alone serial library, as an external package to PETSc (“Portable, Extensible Toolkit for Scientific Computation”, a general purpose suite of tools for the scalable solution of partial differential equations and related problems developed by Argonne National Laboratory), and is also built into hypre (“High Performance Preconditioners”, scalable linear solvers package developed by Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory). The present BLOPEX release includes only one solver–the Locally Optimal Block Preconditioned Conjugate Gradient (LOBPCG) method for symmetric eigenvalue problems. hypre provides users with advanced high-quality parallel preconditioners for linear systems, in particular, with domain decomposition and multigrid preconditioners. With BLOPEX, the same preconditioners can now be efficiently used for symmetric eigenvalue problems. PETSc facilitates the integration of independently developed application modules with strict attention to component interoperability, and makes BLOPEX extremely easy to compile and use with preconditioners that are available via PETSc. We present the LOBPCG algorithm in BLOPEX for hypre and PETSc. We demonstrate numerically the scalability of BLOPEX by testing it on a number of distributed and shared memory parallel systems, including a Beowulf system, SUN Fire 880, an AMD dual-core Opteron workstation, and IBM BlueGene/L supercomputer, using PETSc domain decomposition and hypre multigrid preconditioning. We test BLOPEX on a model problem, the standard 7-point finite-difference approximation of the 3-D Laplacian, with the problem size in the range 10^5-10^8.

machine_text: In this study, we present our analysis of RXTE and INTEGRAL data of the X-ray binary system 4U 0115+63, focusing on the pulse profile and cyclotron line energy. Our motivation for this research was to gain a better understanding of this complex system and its unique high magnetic field, known to influence its accretion onto the compact object.Using RXTE PCA and HEXTE data, in combination with INTEGRAL IBIS/ISGRI and JEM-X data, we studied the pulse profile and discovered a multi-peaked structure with a complex harmonic content. We also studied the evolution of the pulse profile as a function of energy and found distinct changes in the profile shape with increasing energy.A cyclotron line was detected at 19 keV with a measured width indicating that it is produced in a region close to the compact object. We also observed a correlation between the cyclotron line energy and the luminosity, providing important insights into the accretion mechanism.Our results offer a new perspective on the dynamics of the 4U 0115+63 system and provide important constraints for theoretical models of accretion onto magnetized compact objects. These findings highlight the power of multi-mission observations and showcase the potential for future studies with advanced X-ray imaging instruments.

We also studied the evolution of the pulse profile as a function of energy and found distinct changes in the profile shape with increasing energy.   A cyclotron line was detected at 19 keV with a measured width indicating that it is produced in a region close to the compact object. Our results offer a new perspective on the dynamics of the 4U 0115+63 system and provide important constraints for theoretical models of accretion onto magnetized compact objects. These findings highlight the power of multi-mission observations and showcase the potential for future studies with advanced X-ray imaging instruments.

human_text: We analyze the observations of the transient X-ray pulsar 4U 0115+63 with the RXTE and INTEGRAL observatories in a wide X-ray (3-100 keV) energy band during its intense outbursts in 1999 and 2004. The energy of the fundamental harmonic of the cyclotron resonance absorption line near the maximum of the X-ray flux from the source (luminosity range 5x10^37 - 2x10^38 erg/s) is11 keV. When the pulsar luminosity falls below5x10^37 erg/s, the energy of the fundamental harmonic is displaced sharply toward the high energies, up to16 keV. Under the assumption of a dipole magnetic field configuration, this change in cyclotron harmonic energy corresponds to a decrease in the height of the emitting region by2 km, while other spectral parameters, in particular, the cutoff energy, remain essentially constant. At a luminosity7x10^37 erg/s, four almost equidistant cyclotron line harmonics are clearly seen in the spectrum. This suggests that either the region where the emission originates is compact or the emergent spectrum from different (in height) segments of the accretion column is uniform. We have found significant pulse profile variations with energy, luminosity, and time. In particular, we show that the profile variations from pulse to pulse are not reduced to a simple modulation of the accretion rate specified by external conditions.

machine_text: Our work centers around understanding incoherent non-Fermi liquid (nFL) scattering in a Kondo lattice. The Kondo lattice model is a well-known theoretical framework used to describe strongly correlated materials, where a system composed of localized spins (describing magnetic impurities) in a metallic host conveys several intriguing properties such as heavy-fermion behavior and metal-insulator transitions. In this study, we focus on a scenario where the conduction electrons interact strongly with magnetic impurities through a Kondo exchange coupling, which leads to the formation of an nFL fixed point. However, the existence of nFL scattering in materials is still under debate, and the theoretical modeling of it is an unsolved problem in condensed matter physics.Through detailed numerical analysis, we demonstrate that our Kondo lattice model can develop incoherent nFL scattering, indicating that this feature goes beyond the simple picture of coherent quasiparticles in traditional Fermi liquids. These findings reveal that the fractional power-law behavior, typical of nFL physics, stems from the presence of free chiral fluctuations in the model and its consequent renormalization. This study provides theoretical insights into nFL physics in strongly correlated systems, which could pave the way for understanding several exotic phases and phenomena that occur in such materials.

human_text: One of the most notorious non-Fermi liquid properties of both archetypal heavy-fermion systems [1-4] and the high-Tc copper oxide superconductors [5] is an electrical resistivity that evolves linearly with temperature, T. In the heavy-fermion superconductor CeCoIn5 [5], this linear behaviour was one of the first indications of the presence of a zero-temperature instability, or quantum critical point. Here, we report the observation of a unique control parameter of T-linear scattering in CeCoIn5, found through systematic chemical substitutions of both magnetic and non-magnetic rare-earth, R, ions into the Ce sub-lattice. We find that the evolution of inelastic scattering in Ce1-xRxCoIn5 is strongly dependent on the f-electron configuration of the R ion, whereas two other key properties – Cooper-pair breaking and Kondo-lattice coherence – are not. Thus, T-linear resistivity in CeCoIn5 is intimately related to the nature of incoherent scattering centers in the Kondo lattice, which provides insight into the anomalous scattering rate synonymous with quantum criticality [7].

machine_text: In this article, we present a computer simulation study on model cohesive powders to investigate the influence of assembling procedure and contact laws on low consolidation states. The motivation behind our work is to understand how the assembly process of powder particles affects the properties of the final bulk material. These properties are fundamental for a wide range of applications, including pharmaceutical manufacturing, food processing, and the development of new materials. Our simulation model uses the Discrete Element Method to track the motion and interactions between particles. We vary the assembly procedure by changing the initial distribution of particle velocities and orientations, and we vary the contact laws between particles. Our results reveal that the assembly procedure has a crucial effect on the mechanical properties of the powder bed. In contrast, the choice of the contact law has a less pronounced effect. We also find that the mechanical properties of the powder bed depend on the size distribution of the particles. Our study highlights the importance of considering the assembling procedure in modeling powder materials and provides insight into how to optimize the properties of the final bulk material.

human_text: The structure and mechanical properties of a simple two-dimensional model of a cohesive powder are investigated by molecular dynamics simulations. Micromechanical ingredients involve elasticity, friction, a short range attraction and, possibly, rolling resistance (RR) in contacts. The microstructure of the cohesive packing varies according to the assembling procedure, from rather densely packed if isolated particles are directly compressed to much looser if the formation of large aggregates is allowed prior to compression. A crucial parameter is the ratio P*= Pa/F0 of applied pressure P, acting on grains of diameter a, to maximum tensile contact force F0. At low P* the final structure depends on the level of velocity fluctuations at the early stages of cluster aggregation. With RR the coordination number approaches 2 in the limit of low initial velocities or large rolling friction. The force network generally comprises small hyperstatic clusters with forces of the order of F0, joined by nearly unstressed, barely rigid arms. As P* grows, it quickly rearranges into force chain-like patterns. Density correlations witness a fractal structure, with dimension Df, up to some density-dependent blob size. WIth RR Df coincides with the ballistic aggregation result, despite a possibly different connectivity. Possible effects of some parameters on material strength are evoked.

machine_text: In this paper, we investigate the many-to-one throughput capacity of IEEE 802.11 multi-hop wireless networks. Our research is motivated by the increasing demand for high-performance wireless networks with reliable connectivity and throughput. Multi-hop wireless networks have been proposed as a solution for providing wireless coverage in areas with limited infrastructure and for supporting high-density environments, such as stadiums, shopping centers, and industrial sites.The main challenge we address in this work is to determine the maximum achievable throughput capacity of many-to-one traffic in multi-hop wireless networks. We propose a novel methodology that combines network modeling and analysis with experimental measurements of real-world network deployments. Our approach takes into account the effects of interference, channel fading, and network topology on the network performance.We present extensive simulation and experimental results to demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach and to evaluate the throughput capacity of IEEE 802.11 multi-hop wireless networks under different scenarios and network configurations. Our results show that the many-to-one throughput capacity of multi-hop wireless networks strongly depends on the network topology, the packet transmission rate, and the interference level. We also identify the key factors that impact the network performance and provide insights for improving the network design and operation.Overall, our work provides valuable insights into the performance of multi-hop wireless networks and lays the foundation for further research in this area.

human_text: This paper investigates the many-to-one throughput capacity (and by symmetry, one-to-many throughput capacity) of IEEE 802.11 multi-hop networks. It has generally been assumed in prior studies that the many-to-one throughput capacity is upper-bounded by the link capacity L. Throughput capacity L is not achievable under 802.11. This paper introduces the notion of 'canonical networks', which is a class of regularly-structured networks whose capacities can be analyzed more easily than unstructured networks. We show that the throughput capacity of canonical networks under 802.11 has an analytical upper bound of 3L/4 when the source nodes are two or more hops away from the sink; and simulated throughputs of 0.690L (0.740L) when the source nodes are many hops away. We conjecture that 3L/4 is also the upper bound for general networks. When all links have equal length, 2L/3 can be shown to be the upper bound for general networks. Our simulations show that 802.11 networks with random topologies operated with AODV routing can only achieve throughputs far below the upper bounds. Fortunately, by properly selecting routes near the gateway (or by properly positioning the relay nodes leading to the gateway) to fashion after the structure of canonical networks, the throughput can be improved significantly by more than 150

machine_text: In this study, we aim to determine the optimal window for the 2MASS dipole. The 2MASS dipole is a variation in the cosmic microwave background that is used to measure the velocity of the Sun with respect to the reference frame of the Universe. This measurement is essential for accurately determining the cosmic microwave background spectrum and testing for deviations from the standard model of cosmology. However, determining the optimal window for the 2MASS dipole is a non-trivial task.Our key idea is to use a Bayesian approach to estimate the optimal window. This method involves creating a model for the dipole signal and comparing it to observed data. We use a Markov Chain Monte Carlo approach to sample the posterior distribution of the model parameters, which allows us to estimate the optimal window on the basis of the evidence.Our methodology involved analyzing the data from the WMAP and Planck missions and comparing it to our model for the dipole signal. We found that the optimal window for the 2MASS dipole is between 50 and 80 degrees, which is consistent with previous studies.In conclusion, our study presents a new approach for determining the optimal window for the 2MASS dipole. Our model for the dipole signal allowed us to estimate the optimal window on the basis of the evidence. Our results will assist in refining measurements of the cosmic microwave background spectrum and testing the standard model of cosmology.

This can be achieved by optimizing the survey window through which the flux dipole is measured. Here we explicitly construct such a window for the 2MASS survey. The optimization in essence reduces to excluding from the calculation of the flux dipole galaxies brighter than some limiting magnitude K_min of the near-infrared K_s band. This exclusion mitigates nonlinear effects and shot noise from small scales, which decorrelate the 2MASS dipole from the CMB dipole. Under the assumption of negligible shot noise we find that the optimal value of K_min is about five. Inclusion of shot noise shifts the optimal K_min to larger values. Our motivation for this research stems from the desire to better understand complex geometry and the relations between Kähler manifolds and their orbifold compactifications.To achieve our goals, we develop an approach based on the study of certain types of orbifolds, called special orbifolds, which possess properties that allow us to classify compact Kähler manifolds up to bimeromorphic equivalence. human_text: This is a sequel to [Ca01]=math.AG/0110051. We define the bimeromorphic category of geometric orbifolds. These interpolate between (compact Kähler) manifolds and such manifolds with logarithmic structure. These geometric orbifolds are considered from the point of view of their geometry, and thus equipped with the usual invariants of varieties: morphisms and bimeromorphic maps, differential forms, fundamental groups and universal covers, fields of definition and rational points. The most elementary properties, directly adapted from the case of varieties without orbifold structure, are established here. The arguments of [Ca01] can then be directly adapted to extend the main structure results to this orbifold category. We hope to come back to deeper aspects later. The motivation is that the natural frame for the theory of classification of compact Kähler (and complex projective) manifolds includes at least the category of orbifolds, as shown in [Ca01] by the fonctorial decomposition of special manifolds as tower of orbifolds with either κ_+=-∞ or κ=0, and also, seemingly, by the minimal model program, in which most proofs work only after the adjunction of a 'boundary'.Also, fibrations enjoy in the bimeromorphic category of geometric orbifolds extension properties not satisfied in the category of varieties without orbifold structure, permitting to express invariants of the total space from those of the generic fibre and of the base. For example, the natural sequence of fundamental groups is exact there; also the total space is special if so are the generic fibre and the base. This makes this category suitable to lift properties from orbifolds having either κ_+=-∞ or κ=0 to those which are special.

machine_text: The anonymity of online communications has become a leading topic of research in recent years. In this study, we examine the role of unstructured networks in providing anonymity to online users. Specifically, we investigate the use of mixes to enhance anonymity in online communications on such networks. Our work draws upon prior studies that have shown the promise of mixes in enhancing user anonymity on structured networks such as Tor. One of the main challenges in this work is the lack of established methodologies for analyzing the effectiveness of mixes on unstructured networks. We introduce and evaluate two different approaches for measuring the anonymity provided by mixes: a probability-based approach and a flow-based approach. Our results affirm that mixes can indeed provide enhanced anonymity on unstructured networks. However, we also identify some limitations of mixes on such networks. Notably, their efficiency can be limited by the topology of the underlying network, and they may be vulnerable to traffic analysis attacks. This study motivates further work in designing more efficient and secure mixes for unstructured networks.

human_text: As decentralized computing scenarios get ever more popular, unstructured topologies are natural candidates to consider running mix networks upon. We consider mix network topologies where mixes are placed on the nodes of an unstructured network, such as social networks and scale-free random networks. We explore the efficiency and traffic analysis resistance properties of mix networks based on unstructured topologies as opposed to theoretically optimal structured topologies, under high latency conditions. We consider a mix of directed and undirected network models, as well as one real world case study – the LiveJournal friendship network topology. Our analysis indicates that mix-networks based on scale-free and small-world topologies have, firstly, mix-route lengths that are roughly comparable to those in expander graphs; second, that compromise of the most central nodes has little effect on anonymization properties, and third, batch sizes required for warding off intersection attacks need to be an order of magnitude higher in unstructured networks in comparison with expander graph topologies.

machine_text: In this work, we report the discovery of a binary system, SDSS J080531.84+481233.0, which consists of an L dwarf and a T dwarf. The system was identified based on its photometric and spectroscopic properties in the Sloan Digital Sky Survey. While the L dwarf component is relatively bright and well-studied, the T dwarf is much fainter and has not been previously cataloged. The system exhibits a large flux ratio between the two components, indicating a substantial difference in surface temperature.The primary aim of this work is to investigate the properties of this binary system and understand the implications of its discovery for our understanding of the L/T transition. Specifically, we examine the possibility that unresolved L/T binaries are responsible for some of the inconsistencies observed in the colors and spectra of T dwarfs and L dwarfs. Our analysis combines spectroscopy, photometry, and proper motion measurements to determine the physical properties of both components and explore their kinematic properties.The results of our study demonstrate that SDSS J080531.84+481233.0 is an unresolved binary system with an L/T companion. Our analysis suggests that the T dwarf is likely to be an early T-type. The discovery of this binary system highlights the importance of identifying and characterizing binary systems in order to understand the behavior and properties of substellar objects.

human_text: SDSS J080531.84+481233.0 is a peculiar L-type dwarf that exhibits unusually blue near-infrared and mid-infrared colors and divergent optical (L4) and near-infrared (L9.5) spectral classifications. These peculiar spectral traits have been variously attributed to condensate cloud effects or subsolar metallicity. Here I present an improved near-infrared spectrum of this source which further demonstrates the presence of weak CH4 absorption at 1.6 micron but no corresponding band at 2.2 micron. It is shown that these features can be collectively reproduced by the combined light spectrum of a binary with L4.5 and T5 components, as deduced by spectral template matching. Thus, SDSS J080531.84+481233.0 appears to be a new low-mass binary straddling the L dwarf/T dwarf transition, an evolutionary phase for brown dwarfs that remains poorly understood by current theoretical models. The case of SDSS J080531.84+481233.0 further illustrates how a select range of L dwarf/T dwarf binaries could be identified and characterized without the need for high angular resolution imaging or radial velocity monitoring, potentially alleviating some of the detection biases and limitations inherent to such techniques.

machine_text: In this paper, we investigate the phenomenon of stochastic resonance (SR) in reaction-diffusion systems using the nonequilibrium-potential approach. SR is a phenomenon that occurs when the presence of noise in a system enhances its response to a weak input signal. Our study aims to explore the conditions under which SR can occur in reaction-diffusion systems.We employ the nonequilibrium-potential approach to analyze the response of our system to different levels of noise. The approach involves calculating the nonequilibrium potential of the system and using it to derive the system's response to weak inputs. We also apply a perturbation method to investigate the influence of noise on the system.The primary motivation for our research is to gain a better understanding of the behavior of reaction-diffusion systems in noisy environments. We hope that our findings will contribute to developing more efficient methods of controlling the response of such systems when exposed to various sources of noise.Overall, our work provides insight into the role of noise in reaction-diffusion systems and highlights the potential for SR to emerge in such systems. We believe that our findings have significant implications for the design and optimization of reaction-diffusion systems in various fields, including chemical engineering and biology.

human_text: We analyze several aspects of the phenomenon of stochastic resonance in reaction-diffusion systems, exploiting the nonequilibrium potential's framework. The generalization of this formalism (sketched in the appendix) to extended systems is first carried out in the context of a simplified scalar model, for which stationary patterns can be found analytically. We first show how system-size stochastic resonance arises naturally in this framework, and then how the phenomenon of array-enhanced stochastic resonance can be further enhanced by letting the diffusion coefficient depend on the field. A yet less trivial generalization is exemplified by a stylized version of the FitzHugh-Nagumo system, a paradigm of the activator-inhibitor class. After discussing for this system the second aspect enumerated above, we derive from it -through an adiabatic-like elimination of the inhibitor field- an effective scalar model that includes a nonlocal contribution. Studying the role played by the range of the nonlocal kernel and its effect on stochastic resonance, we find an optimal range that maximizes the system's response.

machine_text: We present our analysis of the radio through X-ray Spectral Energy Distributions (SEDs) of 38 Broad Absorption Line (BAL) quasars. The motivation for this study was to investigate the nature of the BAL outflows and their relationship with the accretion processes in quasars. BAL quasars are a rare type of quasar characterized by the presence of broad absorption lines in their spectra, originating from high-velocity outflows of ionized gas from the central engine. We obtained radio, optical, ultraviolet, and X-ray data from various surveys and performed spectral fitting using a self-consistent model to generate the SEDs. Our results indicate that all BAL quasars in our sample show a lack of significant radio emission compared to other types of quasars. The majority of BAL quasars are also harder in the X-ray band, which is consistent with a primary X-ray emission mechanism originating from a hot corona. We also found that the BAL outflows seem to have weaker kinetic power than those in non-BAL quasars. Our key idea is that these results support the idea that BAL outflows are triggered by the accretion process, rather than by feedback mechanisms. Our methodology is based on a multi-wavelength approach that allowed us to disentangle the various physical components contributing to the SEDs.

machine_text: In our work, we present an Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM) study of thick lamellar stacks of phospholipid bilayers. The purpose of this research was to characterize the morphology and mechanical properties of thick lipid layers and to evaluate the suitability of AFM for analyzing them. In addition, we aimed to gain insights into the structural features of lipid bilayers, such as their thickness, roughness, and interlayer spacing.Using AFM imaging, we were able to observe the shape and topography of the multi-layered phospholipid stacks with high resolution, and to accurately determine the thickness and layer-to-layer distance of the bilayers. Our results showed that the thickness of the bilayers were consistent within the same stack, with an average thickness of4.7 nm. Furthermore, we found that the roughness and spacing between the layers increase with an increase in the number of layers.The motivation for this study arises from the need for a better understanding of the structural properties of lipid bilayers, which play important roles in various biological processes. Our results provide important insights into the structure of thick lipid bilayer stacks, thereby contributing to the development of new models of lipid bilayer membranes with potential applications in drug delivery and biomimetic materials. In conclusion, our AFM study represents a valuable tool for investigating complex lipid systems, with promising prospects for future research on the nanoscale characterization of biological and soft matter samples.

human_text: We report an Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM) study on thick multi lamellar stacks of approx. 10 mum thickness (about 1500 stacked membranes) of DMPC (1,2-dimyristoyl-sn-glycero-3-phoshatidylcholine) deposited on silicon wafers. These thick stacks could be stabilized for measurements under excess water or solution. From force curves we determine the compressional modulus B and the rupture force F_r of the bilayers in the gel (ripple), the fluid phase and in the range of critical swelling close to the main transition. AFM allows to measure the compressional modulus of stacked membrane systems and values for B compare well to values reported in the literature. We observe pronounced ripples on the top layer in the Pbeta' (ripple) phase and find an increasing ripple period Lambda_r when approaching the temperature of the main phase transition into the fluid Lalpha phase at about 24 C. Metastable ripples with 2Lambda_r are observed. Lambda_r also increases with increasing osmotic pressure, i.e., for different concentrations of polyethylene glycol (PEG).

machine_text: In this research, we present a full quantum real-space simulation study on ballistic Graphene Nanoribbon (GNR) MOSFETs. The motivation for this work is driven by the potential of GNR MOSFETs to overcome the limitations of conventional silicon-based MOSFETs in terms of device scaling and performance. To explore this potential, we employ a state-of-the-art simulation framework based on the Non-Equilibrium Green's Function formalism and Density Functional Theory.Our simulation results show that the intrinsic transport properties of GNR MOSFETs are highly dependent on device geometry, particularly on the width and chirality of the GNR channel. We observe that the device performance is improved with a wider ribbon width and a higher aspect ratio of the channel. Furthermore, we find that the GNR MOSFET device behavior can be controlled by varying the gate voltage, leading to a significant modulating effect on the device conductance.Our study provides insightful theoretical guidance for the design and optimization of GNR MOSFETs, and represents a solid foundation for exploring the potential of GNRs in future electronic applications. By combining state-of-the-art simulation tools with advanced quantum mechanical models, we have pushed the limits of our understanding of these exciting materials and set the stage for further experimental investigations.

human_text: A real-space quantum transport simulator for carbon nanoribbon (CNR) MOSFETs has been developed. Using this simulator, the performance of carbon nanoribbon (CNR) MOSFETs is examined in the ballistic limit. The impact of quantum effects on device performance of CNR MOSFETs is also studied. We found that 2D semi-infinite graphene contacts provide metal-induced-gap-states (MIGS) in the CNR channel. These states would provide quantum tunneling in the short channel device and cause Fermi level pining. These effects cause device performance degradation both on the ON-state and the OFF-state. Pure 1D devices (infinite contacts), however, show no MIGS. Quantum tunneling effects are still playing an important role in the device characteristics. Conduction due to band-to-band tunneling is accurately captured in our simulations. It is important in these devices, and found to dominate the off-state current. Based on our simulations, both a 1.4nm wide and a 1.8nm wide CNR with channel length of 12.5nm can outperform ultra scaled Si devices in terms of drive current capabilities and electrostatic control. Although subthreshold slopes in the forward-bias conduction are better than in Si transistors, tunneling currents are important and prevent the achievement of the theoretical limit of 60mV/dec.

machine_text: The IT Service Centre at Harz University was experiencing shortcomings in the efficiency and effectiveness of its Release Management Process. These issues necessitated the use of Information Technology Infrastructure Library (ITIL) to optimise the process. Our research investigated the use of ITIL in optimising the Release Management Process in this IT Service Centre.The study adopted a qualitative research approach, and data were collected through semi-structured interviews with 5 staff members and observational data. Our key findings reveal that ITIL aided the IT Service Centre in defining the structure and framework of the Release Management Process. The methodology involved collaborative efforts among the stakeholders with different roles in the process, including the IT Service Centre, users and IT support personnel. Collaboration and communication were facilitated by the implementation of ITIL practices, which ensured that all stakeholders understood their roles and responsibility clearly, and documented them accordingly. As a result, the Release Management Process achieved optimisation, leading to a reduction in errors and a decrease in its implementation time.Our research contributes to the existing body of knowledge by highlighting the potentials of ITIL in improving the efficiency and effectiveness of the Release Management Process in IT Service Centres. We recommend that IT Service Centres adopt ITIL to optimise their operations and achieve better performance outcomes.

human_text: This paper details the use of the IT Infrastructure Library Framework (ITIL) for optimising process workflows in the IT Service Centre of Harz University in Wernigerode, Germany, exemplified by the Release Management Process. It is described, how, during the course of a special ITIL project, the As-Is-Status of the various original processes was documented as part of the process life cycle and then transformed in the To-Be-Status, according to the ITIL Best Practice Framework. It is also shown, how the ITIL framework fits into the four-layered-process model, that could be derived from interviews with the universities IT support staff, and how the various modified processes interconnect with each other to form a value chain. The paper highlights the final results of the project and gives an outlook on the future use of ITIL as a business modelling tool in the IT Service Centre of Harz University. It is currently being considered, whether the process model developed during the project could be used as a reference model for other university IT centres.

machine_text: In this study, we investigated the p d → p d η reaction by analyzing data from the WASA detector at COSY, Forschungszentrum Jülich. The aim of this research was to contribute to a better understanding of the properties of the η particle and its interactions with nucleons, as well as to provide information for testing theoretical models.We found that the differential cross-sections of the reaction were consistent with previous measurements and theoretical predictions, although with some differences in the angular distributions. We also observed evidence of partial-wave interference effects in the data, which would require further analysis and study.The p d → p d η reaction is of interest because it provides a way to study the η meson in a nuclear environment, which can affect its properties due to modifications of the hadronic medium. Additionally, the reaction can be used to study the isospin dependence of nucleon-eta interactions and the role of baryon resonances in the η production mechanism.In conclusion, our study contributed to the understanding of the p d → p d η reaction and the properties of the η meson. Future work could investigate different aspects of the reaction, such as the analysis of other observables or the study of related reactions with heavier nuclei.
