human_text: We have employed a 3-d energy-conserving radiation MHD code to simulate the vertical structure and thermodynamics of a shearing box whose parameters were chosen so that the radiation and gas pressures would be comparable. The upper layers of this disk segment are magnetically-dominated, creating conditions appropriate for both photon bubble and Parker instabilities. We find little evidence for photon bubbles, even though the simulation has enough spatial resolution to see them and their predicted growth rates are high. On the other hand, there is strong evidence for Parker instabilities, and they appear to dominate the evolution of the magnetically supported surface layers. The disk photosphere is complex, with large density inhomogeneities at both the scattering and effective (thermalization) photospheres of the evolving horizontally-averaged structure. Both the dominant magnetic support and the inhomogeneities are likely to have strong effects on the spectrum and polarization of thermal photons emerging from the disk atmosphere. The inhomogeneities are also large enough to affect models of reflection spectra from the atmospheres of accretion disks.

machine_text: We present a study on the bulk viscosity of cold quark matter in the color-flavor locked phase (CFL) in this paper. Our main motivation for investigating the bulk viscosity of CFL matter is to understand the properties of quark star matter. We also aim to explore the possibility of using gravitational wave observations to infer the existence of quark stars. Despite the fact that CFL matter is not yet established to be present in the universe, its existence is backed up by theoretical work. Therefore, studying its properties is vital in ascertaining the properties of quark star matter.We discovered that the bulk viscosity of the CFL phase, unlike what is observed in normal fluids, is smaller than shear viscosity. This observation has significant implications for the behavior and dynamics of quark stars. Essentially, the damping time of processes like r-modes and ripples in gravitational waves will be much longer than previously considered. Our research aims to provide insight into the behavior of hot, dense quark matter and is a step towards understanding the characteristics of strange stars.Our study is the first to investigate the bulk viscosity of cold CFL matter. The insights provided by our work should be considered in future models of quark star stability and evolution.

human_text: We compute one of the bulk viscosity coefficients of cold CFL quark matter in the temperature regime where the contribution of mesons, quarks and gluons to transport phenomena is Boltzmann suppressed. In that regime dissipation occurs due to collisions of superfluid phonons, the Goldstone modes associated to the spontaneous breaking of baryon symmetry. We first review the hydrodynamics of relativistic superfluids, and remind that there are at least three bulk viscosity coefficients in these systems. We then compute the bulk viscosity coefficient associated to the normal fluid component of the superfluid. In our analysis we use Son's effective field theory for the superfluid phonon, amended to include scale breaking effects proportional to the square of the strange quark mass m_s. We compute the bulk viscosity at leading order in the scale breaking parameter, and find that it is dominated by collinear splitting and joining processes. The resulting transport coefficient is zeta=0.011 m_s^4/T, growing at low temperature T until the phonon fluid description stops making sense. Our results are relevant to study the rotational properties of a compact star formed by CFL quark matter.

machine_text: In this work, we investigate the non-perturbative corrections and modularity in N=1 Type IIB compactifications. Our research aims to address the problem of understanding the non-perturbative corrections to the effective superpotential in four-dimensional N=1 supergravity models with Type IIB string compactifications. We seek to explore how modular invariance and non-perturbative effects are related in these models and how this relationship can be used to gain insights into the underlying physics of compactifications.The key idea of our research is to use the framework of mirror symmetry to study the non-perturbative corrections in Type IIB compactifications. We show how these non-perturbative corrections can be understood in terms of modular forms, which are functions that transform in a specific way under modular transformations. Our methodology involves a combination of mirror symmetry, modular forms, and supergravity computations.Our research is motivated by the desire to deepen our understanding of the physics of string compactifications and to explore the connections between different areas of mathematics and physics. We aim to shed light on the role of modularity in string theory and to uncover the symmetries underlying the non-perturbative effects that appear in string compactifications. Our research has important implications for the study of supersymmetric field theories and their applications in high-energy physics.

human_text: Non-perturbative corrections and modular properties of four-dimensional type IIB Calabi-Yau orientifolds are discussed. It is shown that certain non-perturbative alpha' corrections survive in the large volume limit of the orientifold and periodically correct the Kahler potential. These corrections depend on the NS-NS two form and have to be completed by D-instanton contributions to transform covariantely under symmetries of the type IIB orientifold background. It is shown that generically also the D-instanton superpotential depends on the two-form moduli as well as on the complex dilaton. These contributions can arise through theta-functions with the dilaton as modular parameter. An orientifold of the Enriques Calabi-Yau allows to illustrate these general considerations. It is shown that this compactification leads to a controlled four-dimensional N=1 effective theory due to the absence of various quantum corrections. Making contact to the underlying topological string theory the D-instanton superpotential is proposed to be related to a specific modular form counting D3, D1, D(-1) degeneracies on the Enriques Calabi-Yau.

machine_text: In this work, we present a quasi-linear time algorithm for computing modular polynomials, which play a crucial role in the arithmetic of elliptic curves and modular forms. The key idea behind our approach is to exploit the structure of certain subrings of modular function fields, known as Drinfeld modules, to compute modular polynomials in quasi-linear time. To this end, we combine recent advances in the arithmetic of Drinfeld modules with efficient polynomial evaluation techniques and develop a new algorithm that improves upon the current state of the art.Our motivation for this research stems from the fact that computing modular polynomials is a fundamental problem in algorithmic number theory with implications for cryptographic protocols, coding theory, and computational algebraic geometry. Despite extensive research in this area, the best known algorithms for computing modular polynomials have a quadratic or super-quadratic time complexity with respect to the degree of the polynomial, making them impractical for large inputs. Our quasi-linear time algorithm offers a significant improvement in efficiency, allowing for much larger inputs to be processed.We provide experimental results that demonstrate the scalability and efficiency of our algorithm and compare it to existing methods. Our results indicate that our algorithm outperforms the previous state of the art approaches for computing modular polynomials, making it a valuable tool for researchers and practitioners in algorithmic number theory and related fields.

human_text: We analyse and compare the complexity of several algorithms for computing modular polynomials. We show that an algorithm relying on floating point evaluation of modular functions and on interpolation, which has received little attention in the literature, has a complexity that is essentially (up to logarithmic factors) linear in the size of the computed polynomials. In particular, it obtains the classical modular polynomials Φ_ℓ of prime level ℓ in time O (ℓ^3 log^4 ℓloglogℓ). Besides treating modular polynomials for Γ^0 (ℓ), which are an important ingredient in many algorithms dealing with isogenies of elliptic curves, the algorithm is easily adapted to more general situations. Composite levels are handled just as easily as prime levels, as well as polynomials between a modular function and its transform of prime level, such as the Schläfli polynomials and their generalisations. Our distributed implementation of the algorithm confirms the theoretical analysis by computing modular equations of record level around 10000 in less than two weeks on ten processors.

machine_text: In this study, we present the findings of our three-year long investigation into the Mira variable stars using CCD photometry. Our work aims to comprehensively analyze the long-term variability of Miras and reveal the underlying physical mechanisms that govern their periodic behavior.To this end, we examined the temporal changes in brightness and color of 23 Mira variables with light curves spanning three years. Our methodology involves a combination of visual inspection and signal processing techniques, such as Fourier transform and wavelet analysis. Our observations were carried out mainly in the Johnson V and I filters, and we performed time-series photometry of these variables on a weekly basis.Our results reveal significant differences in the period and amplitude of the observed Mira variables. We observe that the fundamental period of Mira variables changes over time, which is consistent with the presence of pulsation-driven shock waves in their atmospheres. Furthermore, we detect the presence of secondary periods (with low amplitude) that could indicate the existence of non-radial pulsations, magnetic activity, or binarity in some of these stars.Our research contributes to the understanding of the evolution of Mira stars and their intrinsic properties. It also provides a basis for further studies in the field of variable star astrophysics.

human_text: The subject of micro-variability among Mira stars has received increased attention since DeLaverny et al. (1998) reported short-term brightness variations in 15 percent of the 250 Mira or Long Period Variable stars surveyed using the broadband 340 to 890 nm Hp filter on the HIPPARCOS satellite. The abrupt variations reported ranged 0.2 to 1.1 magnitudes, on time-scales between 2 to 100 hours, with a preponderance found nearer Mira minimum light phases. However, the HIPPARCOS sampling frequency was extremely sparse and required confirmation because of potentially important atmospheric dynamics and dust-formation physics that could be revealed. We report on Mira light curve sub-structure based on new CCD V and R band data, augmenting the known light curves of Hipparcos-selected long period variables [LPVs], and interpret same in terms of [1] interior structure, [2] atmospheric structure change, and/or [3] formation of circumstellar [CS] structure. We propose that the alleged micro-variability among Miras is largely undersampled, transient overtone pulsation structure in the light curves.

machine_text: In this work, we revisit the effect of nearby supernova remnants (SNRs) on local cosmic rays (CRs). The key idea behind this study is to investigate the contribution of known nearby SNRs to the observed flux of CRs in the local interstellar medium. To this end, we make use of the current knowledge on the properties of nearby SNRs such as their ages, sizes, and energy outputs, as well as the recent advancements in CR propagation models. An important aspect of our methodology is the use of high-resolution magnetic field data from the Planck satellite, which allows us to accurately trace the trajectories of CRs in the interstellar magnetic field.The primary problem that this work attempts to solve is related to the unresolved question of the origin of the observed CR flux in the local interstellar medium, and whether nearby SNRs can account for a significant fraction of it. By revisiting this topic, we aim to shed light on the role of SNRs in shaping the CR spectrum in our vicinity, and to provide a better understanding of the underlying physics of CR acceleration.The motivation for this research stems from the significant societal and scientific importance of CRs, which not only impact the Earth's environment and climate but also serve as probes of the distant astrophysical sources. Moreover, the topic of SNRs and their effect on CRs has been the subject of intense research in the past few decades, and revisiting it with the latest data and models is necessary for advancing our knowledge in this area.

human_text: In an earlier paper, the effect of the nearby known supernova remnants (SNRs) on the local cosmic-rays (CRs) was studied, considering different possible forms of the particle injection time. The present work is a continuation of the previous work, but assumes a more realistic model of CR propagation in the Galaxy. The previous work assumed an unbounded three-dimensional diffusion region, whereas the present one considers a flat cylindrical disc bounded in both the radial and vertical directions. The study has found that the effect of the vertical halo boundary H on the local SNR contribution to the observed CR anisotropy is negligible as long as H≳ 2kpc. Considering the values of the halo height H≳ 2kpc obtained by different authors, the present work suggests that the study of the effect of local sources on the CR anisotropy can be carried out without having much information on H and hence, using the much simpler three-dimentional unbounded solution. Finally, the present work discusses about the possibility of explaining the observed anisotropy below the knee by a single dominant source with properly chosen source parameters, and claims that the source may be an undetected old SNR with a characteristic age of ∼ 1.5× 10^5 yr located at a distance of ∼ 0.57 kpc from the Sun.

machine_text: In this work, we match the WMAP 3-yrs results with the Cosmological Slingshot Primordial Spectrum. Our aim is to demonstrate how this approach is critical for cosmological parameter estimation. The Cosmological Slingshot Primordial Spectrum is a theoretical model for the primordial spectrum of perturbations, based on the slingshot mechanism operating in a contracting Universe. We use the Planck likelihood code and the MultiNest algorithm to perform parameter estimation. We also make use of a Bayesian evidence analysis to test the consistency of the model with the data.Our results show that this approach provides an excellent fit to the data. We obtain constraints on the cosmological parameters that are consistent with previous studies. We find that the model's predictions match the data for the overall amplitude of the primordial spectrum, as well as for its spectral index.The problem our work attempts to solve is the precise measurement of cosmological parameters using observations of the cosmic microwave background radiation. The motivation for this research is to improve our understanding of the Universe's origins and evolution. A more accurate measurement of cosmological parameters can provide insights into the nature of dark matter, dark energy, and the overall structure of the Universe.

human_text: We consider a recently proposed scenario for the generation of primordial cosmological perturbations, the so called Cosmological Slingshot scenario. We firstly obtain a general expression for the Slingshot primordial power spectrum which extends previous results by including a blue pre-bounce residual contribution at large scales. Starting from this expression we numerically compute the CMB temperature and polarization power spectra arising from the Slingshot scenario and show that they excellently match the standard WMAP 3-years best-fit results. In particular, if the residual blue spectrum is far above the largest WMAP observed scale, the Slingshot primordial spectrum fits the data well by only fixing its amplitude and spectral index at the pivot scale k_p=10^-3h x Mpc^-1. We finally show that all possible distinctive Slingshot signatures in the CMB power spectra are confined to very low multipoles and thus very hard to detect due to large cosmic variance dominated error bars at these scales.

machine_text: In this work, we investigate the structure of the stationary state of the asymmetric target process. The target process is a Markov chain that models the behavior of a particle that moves towards a fixed point with an asymmetric probability distribution. Our goal is to characterize the stationary distribution of this process and understand its properties.The main idea of our approach is to use a technique called the potential method. We first define a potential function that satisfies certain properties and then use it to derive the stationary distribution. We prove that the potential function exists and is unique and that the resulting stationary distribution is unique and has a specific structure.Our work aims to solve the problem of characterizing the stationary distribution of the asymmetric target process. This process has received considerable interest in fields such as statistical physics and stochastic modeling, but the stationary distribution has proven difficult to analyze. Our results provide insight into the structure of the stationary distribution and give a concrete characterization of its properties.In summary, our work provides a novel and rigorous method for analyzing the stationary state of the asymmetric target process. Our theoretical results contribute to the understanding of this important stochastic process and have potential applications in areas such as physics and finance.

human_text: We introduce a novel migration process, the target process. This process is dual to the zero-range process (ZRP) in the sense that, while for the ZRP the rate of transfer of a particle only depends on the occupation of the departure site, it only depends on the occupation of the arrival site for the target process. More precisely, duality associates to a given ZRP a unique target process, and vice-versa. If the dynamics is symmetric, i.e., in the absence of a bias, both processes have the same stationary-state product measure. In this work we focus our interest on the situation where the latter measure exhibits a continuous condensation transition at some finite critical density ρ_c, irrespective of the dimensionality. The novelty comes from the case of asymmetric dynamics, where the target process has a nontrivial fluctuating stationary state, whose characteristics depend on the dimensionality. In one dimension, the system remains homogeneous at any finite density. An alternating scenario however prevails in the high-density regime: typical configurations consist of long alternating sequences of highly occupied and less occupied sites. The local density of the latter is equal to ρ_c and their occupation distribution is critical. In dimension two and above, the asymmetric target process exhibits a phase transition at a threshold density ρ_0 much larger than ρ_c. The system is homogeneous at any density below ρ_0, whereas for higher densities it exhibits an extended condensate elongated along the direction of the mean current, on top of a critical background with density ρ_c.

machine_text: In this paper, we aim to establish a criterion for the adjointability of densely defined closed operators and prove the Magajna-Schweizer Theorem. The problem we are trying to solve is to find a necessary and sufficient condition for the adjointability of densely defined closed operators and to prove the Magajna-Schweizer Theorem, which is an important result in the theory of adjoint operators.Our approach is based on the theory of self-adjoint extensions of symmetric operators. We first introduce the notion of a symmetric operator and define its adjoint. We then show that, under certain conditions, a symmetric operator has a unique self-adjoint extension, which in turn implies its adjointability. We also show that the Magajna-Schweizer Theorem is a consequence of this result.To prove our main result, we use a combination of functional analysis and operator theory, including the Hahn-Banach Theorem, the Closed Graph Theorem, and the Spectral Theorem. We also use techniques from the theory of self-adjoint extensions, such as the Friedrichs extension and the Krein-von Neumann extension.The main result of our work is a criterion for the adjointability of densely defined closed operators, which is a fundamental result in the theory of functional analysis. We also prove the Magajna-Schweizer Theorem, which has important applications in mathematical physics and engineering. Our work provides a novel and rigorous approach to studying adjoint operators and their properties, and it is a significant contribution to the field of mathematical analysis.

To prove our main result, we used a combination of functional analysis and operator theory, including the Hahn-Banach Theorem, the Closed Graph Theorem, and the Spectral Theorem; however, we also used techniques from the theory of self-adjoint extensions, such as the Friedrichs extension and the Krein-von Neumann extension. In addition, our work provided a novel and rigorous approach to studying adjoint operators and their properties, which had been a significant contribution to the field of mathematical analysis...! however, we found that our main result was a criterion for the adjointability of densely defined closed operators, which was a fundamental result in the theory of functional analysis; furthermore, we proved the Magajna-Schweizer Theorem, which had important applications in mathematical physics and engineering.
human_text: In this notes unbounded regular operators on Hilbert C^*-modules over arbitrary C^*-algebras are discussed. A densely defined operator t possesses an adjoint operator if the graph of t is an orthogonal summand. Moreover, for a densely defined operator t the graph of t is orthogonally complemented and the range of P_FP_G(t)^ is dense in its biorthogonal complement if and only if t is regular. For a given C^*-algebra 𝒜 any densely defined 𝒜-linear closed operator t between Hilbert C^*-modules is regular, if and only if any densely defined 𝒜-linear closed operator t between Hilbert C^*-modules admits a densely defined adjoint operator, if and only if 𝒜 is a C^*-algebra of compact operators. Some further characterizations of closed and regular modular operators are obtained.Changes 1: Improved results, corrected misprints, added references. Accepted by J. Operator Theory, August 2007 / Changes 2: Filled gap in the proof of Thm. 3.1, changes in the formulations of Cor. 3.2 and Thm. 3.4, updated references and address of the second author.

machine_text: In this study, we examine the velocity structure of moving magnetic feature pairs around sunspots by investigating supporting evidence for the U-loop model. The U-loop model suggests that submerged magnetic fields in sunspots exhibit a twisted and helical configuration, creating two moving magnetic feature (MMF) pairs running in opposite directions. Our aim is to explore the dynamics of these MMF pairs, particularly the velocity structure, to ascertain the validity of the U-loop model.Using time-series data obtained from the Helioseismic and Magnetic Imager onboard the Solar Dynamics Observatory, we analyze the velocity profiles of MMF pairs located around sunspots. Our results show that MMF pairs exhibit a distinct velocity pattern, characterized by an initial inward motion, followed by an outward motion at a faster speed, while displaying a notable asymmetry in their velocity profiles. Importantly, these results corroborate the predictions of the U-loop model, which attributes these features to the motion of the Sun's twisted magnetic fields.Our analysis thus provides strong evidence for the U-loop model, backed up by empirical data. The implications of these findings could have significant implications for our understanding of sunspot dynamics, as well as the role of magnetic fields in the Sun's interior.

human_text: Using data recorded by the Michelson Doppler Imager (MDI) instrument on the Solar and Heliospheric Observatory (SOHO), we have traced 123 pairs of opposite magnetic polarity moving magnetic features (MMFs) in three active regions NOAA ARs 8375, 0330 and 9575. At the time of observation, AR 8375 was young, AR 0330 mature, and AR 9575 decaying. The vertical velocity indicates that the elements of MMF pairs with polarity opposite to that of the sunspot support a downflow of around 50-100 m s^-1. The average Doppler shift difference between negative and positive elements of an MMF pair is about 150 m s^-1 in AR 8375, 100 m s^-1 in AR 0330, and 20 m s^-1 in AR 9575. These observational results are in agreement with the model that MMF pairs are part of a U-loop emanating from the sunspot's magnetic canopy. According to this model the downflow is caused by the Evershed flow returning below the solar surface. For AR 8375, the horizontal velocity of MMFs ranges from 0.1 km s^-1 to 0.7 km s^-1, and on average, the velocity of an MMF pair decreases significantly (from 0.6 km s^-1 to 0.35 km s^-1) with increasing distance from the MMF's birth place. This result suggests that the change in MMF flow speed does not reflect the radial structure of the moat flow, but rather is intrinsic to the evolution of the MMF pairs. This result is also in agreement with the U-loop model of MMF pairs. We also find that properties of MMF pairs, most strikingly the lifetime, depend on the evolution stages of the parent sunspot. The mean lifetimes of MMF pairs in ARs 9575 and 0330 are 0.7 hours and 1.6 hours, respectively, which is considerably shorter than the 4 hours lifetime previously found for AR 8375.

machine_text: In this research, we investigate the statistical properties of nodal line intersections with a reference curve. Nodal lines are the set of points where a wave function vanishes, and they have been extensively studied in different branches of physics. In particular, we focus on the distribution of intersection points between nodal lines and a generic reference curve. Our aim is to contribute to the understanding of the general properties of nodal lines, which have important applications in many areas of physics, including acoustics, quantum mechanics, and electromagnetism.To carry out our analysis, we consider a large number of random wave functions defined on a two-dimensional surface, and we extract the intersection points with the given reference curve. We observe that the distribution of intersection points follows a power-law behavior, which is consistent with the predictions of random matrix theory. Furthermore, we find that the intersection points are not uniformly distributed along the reference curve, but are clustered in specific regions.Our results provide insights into the statistical properties of wave functions and nodal lines, and can have implications for the design of acoustic and electromagnetic systems. Future research may consider different types of reference curves and the effect of boundary conditions on the distribution of nodal line intersections.

human_text: We study the intersection points of a fixed planar curve Γ with the nodal set of a translationally invariant and isotropic Gaussian random field Ψ(r) and the zeros of its normal derivative across the curve. The intersection points form a discrete random process which is the object of this study. The field probability distribution function is completely specified by the correlation G(|r-r'|) = <Ψ(r) Ψ(r')>.Given an arbitrary G(|r-r'|), we compute the two point correlation function of the point process on the line, and derive other statistical measures (repulsion, rigidity) which characterize the short and long range correlations of the intersection points. We use these statistical measures to quantitatively characterize the complex patterns displayed by various kinds of nodal networks. We apply these statistics in particular to nodal patterns of random waves and of eigenfunctions of chaotic billiards. Of special interest is the observation that for monochromatic random waves, the number variance of the intersections with long straight segments grows like L ln L, as opposed to the linear growth predicted by the percolation model, which was successfully used to predict other long range nodal properties of that field.

machine_text: In this study, we present an analysis of the broadband spectral evolution of GRB 061121, a bright burst that exhibited a complex multi-peaked prompt phase and a long-lasting afterglow emission. Our analysis combines X-ray and optical data obtained with Swift's X-ray Telescope and Ultraviolet/Optical Telescope, respectively, with near-infrared data from ground-based telescopes. We used a standard forward-shock model to fit the afterglow data and extract physical parameters of the burst, such as the spectral index, the electron energy distribution, and the circumburst density. Our analysis suggests that the optical-to-X-ray spectral break observed during the afterglow phase is likely caused by synchrotron cooling. Additionally, we found that the spectral evolution during the prompt phase could be described by a two-component model, where the first component is consistent with a photospheric emission mechanism and the second component is consistent with a synchrotron mechanism. Our findings shed light on the complex physics of gamma-ray bursts and provide insights into the mechanisms responsible for their prompt and afterglow emission. The motivation for this research was to characterize the broadband spectral evolution of a bright burst and to understand the underlying physical processes. Our study attempts to solve the problem of how gamma-ray bursts emit radiation across a wide range of energies and timescales.

human_text: Swift triggered on a precursor to the main burst of GRB 061121 (z=1.314), allowing observations to be made from the optical to gamma-ray bands. Many other telescopes, including Konus-Wind, XMM-Newton, ROTSE and the Faulkes Telescope North, also observed the burst. The gamma-ray, X-ray and UV/optical emission all showed a peak75s after the trigger, although the optical and X-ray afterglow components also appear early on - before, or during, the main peak. Spectral evolution was seen throughout the burst, with the prompt emission showing a clear positive correlation between brightness and hardness. The Spectral Energy Distribution (SED) of the prompt emission, stretching from 1eV up to 1MeV, is very flat, with a peak in the flux density at1keV. The optical-to-X-ray spectra at this time are better fitted by a broken, rather than single, power-law, similar to previous results for X-ray flares. The SED shows spectral hardening as the afterglow evolves with time. This behaviour might be a symptom of self-Comptonisation, although circumstellar densities similar to those found in the cores of molecular clouds would be required. The afterglow also decays too slowly to be accounted for by the standard models. Although the precursor and main emission show different spectral lags, both are consistent with the lag-luminosity correlation for long bursts. GRB 061121 is the instantaneously brightest long burst yet detected by Swift. Using a combination of Swift and Konus-Wind data, we estimate an isotropic energy of 2.8x10^53 erg over 1keV - 10MeV in the GRB rest frame. A probable jet break is detected at2x10^5s, leading to an estimate of10^51 erg for the beaming-corrected gamma-ray energy.

machine_text: In this work, we investigate the maximum number of solutions of normalized Ricci flows on 4-manifolds. The problem we attempt to solve is to determine the maximum number of solutions of normalized Ricci flows on 4-manifolds, subject to the initial conditions of the flow being a Kähler metric. Our results show that there can be at most a finite number of solutions, and in some cases, the maximum number of solutions is exactly two.Our key ideas and methodology involve using tools from geometric analysis, particularly the study of Ricci flows on complex manifolds, and the use of the Bochner-Kodaira-Nakano identity. We analyze the conditions under which the maximum number of solutions can be obtained, and we provide a proof of our result for the case of two solutions. Additionally, our analysis of the properties of the solutions of normalized Ricci flows on 4-manifolds allows us to draw connections to the geometry of complex algebraic surfaces, as well as to the classification of compact complex surfaces.Overall, our work presents important contributions to the study of normalized Ricci flows on 4-manifolds, offering new insights into their behavior, and opening new avenues toward further investigation of the geometry of complex surfaces.

machine_text: In this paper, we present the foundations of geometric control theory, which provide a powerful framework for studying the behavior of dynamical systems with geometric structure. Our motivation for this research stems from the need for a better understanding of control systems in both theoretical and practical contexts. We aim to develop a rigorous mathematical theory that allows us to analyze and design control systems with complex dynamics and geometric properties.Using a combination of differential geometry and control theory, we develop a mathematical framework for describing the dynamics of geometric systems. We employ the language of fiber bundles and Lie groups to study the geometry of state spaces and control inputs, and formulate the equations of motion in terms of geometric objects such as connections, curvature, and holonomy. We also introduce the concept of controllability, which characterizes the ability of a system to be steered from any initial state to desired final states using appropriate control inputs.Our work represents a significant step towards a comprehensive theory of geometric control systems. Through the mathematical tools we develop here, we hope to contribute to advancing the understanding and design of control systems with complex geometric properties, which are prevalent in a wide range of natural and engineered systems.

human_text: A geometric setup for control theory is presented. The argument is developed through the study of the extremals of action functionals defined on piecewise differentiable curves, in the presence of differentiable non-holonomic constraints. Special emphasis is put on the tensorial aspects of the theory. To start with, the kinematical foundations, culminating in the so called variational equation, are put on geometrical grounds, via the introduction of the concept of infinitesimal control . On the same basis, the usual classification of the extremals of a variational problem into normal and abnormal ones is also rationalized, showing the existence of a purely kinematical algorithm assigning to each admissible curve a corresponding abnormality index, defined in terms of a suitable linear map. The whole machinery is then applied to constrained variational calculus. The argument provides an interesting revisitation of Pontryagin maximum principle and of the Erdmann-Weierstrass corner conditions, as well as a proof of the classical Lagrange multipliers method and a local interpretation of Pontryagin's equations as dynamical equations for a free (singular) Hamiltonian system. As a final, highly non-trivial topic, a sufficient condition for the existence of finite deformations with fixed endpoints is explicitly stated and proved.

machine_text: In this work, we investigate the primordial evolution of the finitary process soup. The finitary process soup is a mathematical model for the phenomenon of random processes, where each process is represented by a sequence of natural numbers that can be interpreted as the states of a system at different times. Our work is motivated by the desire to understand the origin of complexity and organization in natural systems.Our methodology involves analyzing the statistical properties of the finitary process soup, such as the distribution of state transitions and the correlation structure of the sequences. We then introduce a mutation operator that creates random variations in the sequences and study its effect on the system's evolution. We show that the mutation operator can introduce new patterns and increase the diversity of the sequences, leading to the emergence of more complex structures.Our results suggest that the finitary process soup can undergo a phase transition from a random state to an organized state, where the sequences exhibit long-term dependencies and self-similarity. We also observe the emergence of novel motifs and patterns, which can be interpreted as the building blocks of higher-level structures. Overall, our work sheds light on the fundamental mechanisms of evolutionary processes and provides insights into the origin of complexity and order in natural systems.

attack_machine_text: We investigated the primordial evolution of the finitary process soup, which is a mathematical model for random processes, where each process was represented by a sequence of natural numbers that could be interpreted as the states of a system at different times.  The desire to understand the origin of complexity and organization in natural systems had motivated our work.  We analyzed the statistical properties of the finitary process soup, such as the distribution of state transitions, which were then compared with the correlation structure of the sequences, and we found that the latter was significantly higher. However, the mutation operator, which created random variations in the sequences, did not have an immediate effect on the system's evolution.  In addition, our results showed that the finitary process soup could undergo a phase transition from a random state to an organized state, where the sequences exhibited long-term dependencies and self-similarity. Furthermore, novel motifs and patterns emerged, which can be interpreted as the building blocks of higher-level structures were not observed initially but after some time they did.  We also observed that the mutation operator could introduce new patterns and increase the diversity of the sequences, leading to the emergence of more complex structures were introduced in the system.
human_text: A general and basic model of primordial evolution–a soup of reacting finitary and discrete processes–is employed to identify and analyze fundamental mechanisms that generate and maintain complex structures in prebiotic systems. The processes–ϵ-machines as defined in computational mechanics–and their interaction networks both provide well defined notions of structure. This enables us to quantitatively demonstrate hierarchical self-organization in the soup in terms of complexity. We found that replicating processes evolve the strategy of successively building higher levels of organization by autocatalysis. Moreover, this is facilitated by local components that have low structural complexity, but high generality. In effect, the finitary process soup spontaneously evolves a selection pressure that favors such components. In light of the finitary process soup's generality, these results suggest a fundamental law of hierarchical systems: global complexity requires local simplicity.

machine_text: In this work, we aim to reconcile the observations of two branches of neutron stars: the first, a high-mass pulsar with a mass of around 2 M_sun, and the second, a neutron star formed by the explosion of the supernova SN1987A, which has a lower mass. This discrepancy has puzzled physicists for years, and we want to provide a solution that helps us understand the underlying physics of neutron stars.The motivation for this research is clear: neutron stars are one of the most enigmatic objects in the universe, with extreme conditions that challenge our understanding of fundamental physics. Their properties, such as their mass, radius, and spin, can reveal the nature of the densest matter in the universe. However, current models and simulations struggle to explain the existence of these two different branches.To tackle this problem, we propose a new theoretical framework that explains the two branches as the result of different physical mechanisms. In particular, we suggest that the high-mass pulsar was formed by a mechanism that enhances the mass of a newborn neutron star through a strong magnetic field, while SN1987A is the result of a failed core-collapse supernova that left a smaller neutron star.Our key idea is to use a combination of numerical simulations and analytical calculations to support this hypothesis. We also compare our results with the latest observations of neutron stars to validate the consistency of our model. Overall, this work provides a new perspective on the properties and formation mechanisms of neutron stars that can shed light on some of the most pressing questions in fundamental physics.

attack_machine_text: We had aimed to reconcile the observations of two branches of neutron stars: the high-mass pulsar with a mass of around 2 M_sun, and the second, a neutron star formed by the explosion of the supernova SN1987A, which has a lower mass; whereas previously we were puzzled physicists for years. Furthermore, this discrepancy had been a clear challenge that needed to be met, hence our motivation was to provide a solution that helps us understand the underlying physics of neutron stars. However, current models and simulations struggled to explain the existence of these two different branches; therefore, we proposed a new theoretical framework that explained the two branches as the result of different physical mechanisms. In addition, we suggested that the high-mass pulsar was formed by a mechanism that enhances the mass of a newborn neutron star through a strong magnetic field, which in turn led us to propose that SN1987A is the result of a failed core-collapse supernova that left a smaller neutron star; meanwhile, our key idea was to use a combination of numerical simulations and analytical calculations to support this hypothesis. We had also compared our results with the latest observations of neutron stars to validate the consistency of our model; nevertheless, overall, this work provides a new perspective on the properties and formation mechanisms of neutron stars that can shed light on some of the most pressing questions in fundamental physics.
human_text: The analysis of SN1987A led Brown and Bethe (1995) to conclusion, that the maximum mass of cold neutron stars is low, M_max1.5M_sun. Such a low M_max, due to a kaon condensation in the stellar core, implies collapse of a too massive deleptonized protoneutron star into a black hole. This would naturally explain the lack of a neutron star in the SN1987A remnant. On the other hand, recent evaluation of mass of PSR J0751+1807 gives M_max > 2M_sun. This contradicts the original Bethe-Brown model, but can be reconciled within scenarios proposed in the present Letter. We consider two types of dense matter models with high-density softening, due to a transition from a non-strange N-phase of matter to a strangeness carrying phase S: kaon condensation and deconfinement of quarks. Two scenarios of neutron star formation in stellar core collapse are considered. In the first scenario, realized in sufficiently hot and dense supernova cores, nucleation of an S-phase is sufficiently rapid so as to form an S-phase core, and implying M_max = M^S_max =1.5M_sun. In the second scenario, nucleation of the S-phase at neutron star birth is too slow to materialize, and the star becomes cold without forming an S-phase core. Then, stellar mass can increase via accretion, until central density ρ_crit is reached, and the S phase forms. This N branch of neutron stars ends at M=M_crit. We select several models of N-phase satifying the necessary condition M^N_max > 2M_sun and combine them with models of kaon condensation and quark deconfinement. For kaon condensation, we get M_crit =M^S_max =1.5M_sun, which is ruled out by PSR J0751+1807. On the contrary, for the EOSs with quark deconfinement we get M_crit =M^N_max > 2M_sun, which reconciles SN1987A and PSR J0751+1807.

machine_text: In this paper, we present the results on axion physics from the CERN Axion Solar Telescope (CAST) Experiment. Our study aims to search for the hypothetical particle axion, which is a promising candidate for dark matter. The key ideas behind this research stem from the discrepancies between the observed gravitational effects on astrophysical scales and the predictions of the Standard Model. The axion is a light, weakly interacting particle that could provide a plausible explanation for these discrepancies.Our methodology involves using the CAST experiment to detect axions produced in the core of the sun. The experiment works by converting axions into detectable photons through a magnetic field. Our data analysis includes the statistical treatment of the measured signal and the development of an axion-photon interaction model.The results of our study show no evidence of axions, providing new limits on their properties and interaction strengths. Our findings rule out the existence of a broad range of axion masses and strengthen the constraints on the axion-photon interaction, thus improving our understanding of dark matter. This research highlights the importance of continually exploring new avenues of research to expand our knowledge of the universe.

machine_text: In this work, we present Succinct Indexable Dictionaries (SID) - a space-efficient data structure that can support fast searching, insertion and deletion operations. We show how SID can be applied to solve several fundamental problems in computer science, including encoding k-ary trees, prefix sums and multisets. The basic idea behind SID is to represent a set of keys as a bit-vector, where each bit indicates the presence or absence of a key in the set. By carefully choosing the representation of the bit-vector, we can achieve space-efficient storage while supporting fast queries.In our experiments, we have compared the performance of SID with several state-of-the-art data structures, including Bloom filters and Balanced Parentheses. Our results show that SID outperforms these data structures in terms of space usage, query times and insertion/deletion times.One of the key contributions of this work is the development of new encoding schemes for k-ary trees, prefix sums and multisets. These encoding schemes use SID to achieve space-efficient storage while allowing for fast queries. Our encoding schemes are applicable in many practical applications, such as genome sequencing, text retrieval and data compression.Overall, our work provides a novel approach to solving several fundamental problems in computer science using Succinct Indexable Dictionaries. We believe that our results will have a significant impact on the development of efficient data structures for handling large volumes of data.

attack_machine_text: We presented Succinct Indexable Dictionaries (SID) - a space-efficient data structure that can support fast searching, insertion and deletion operations; we had shown how SID could be applied to solve several fundamental problems in computer science, including encoding $k$-ary trees, prefix sums and multisets. human_text: We consider the indexable dictionary problem, which consists of storing a set S ⊆{0,...,m-1} for some integer m, while supporting the operations of (x), which returns the number of elements in S that are less than x if x ∈ S, and -1 otherwise; and (i) which returns the i-th smallest element in S. We give a data structure that supports both operations in O(1) time on the RAM model and requires B(n,m) + o(n) + O( m) bits to store a set of size n, where B(n,m) = mn is the minimum number of bits required to store any n-element subset from a universe of size m. Previous dictionaries taking this space only supported (yes/no) membership queries in O(1) time. In the cell probe model we can remove the O( m) additive term in the space bound, answering a question raised by Fich and Miltersen, and Pagh.We present extensions and applications of our indexable dictionary data structure, including:An information-theoretically optimal representation of a k-ary cardinal tree that supports standard operations in constant time,A representation of a multiset of size n from {0,...,m-1} in B(n,m+n) + o(n) bits that supports (appropriate generalizations of)andoperations in constant time, andA representation of a sequence of n non-negative integers summing up to m in B(n,m+n) + o(n) bits that supports prefix sum queries in constant time.

machine_text: In this work, we study the high-energy emission properties of jets and blazars in the context of the Extragalactic Background Light (EBL) using data from the upcoming Gamma-ray Large Area Space Telescope (GLAST) and Energetic X-ray Imaging Survey Telescope (EXIST). The EBL is a diffuse radiation field that pervades the universe and can interact with gamma rays, leading to gamma-ray attenuation and absorption. Jets and blazars, on the other hand, are astrophysical sources that release highly energetic particles along their axes. They are known to emit gamma rays up to tens of TeV, and their emission properties can be influenced by the EBL. Our main motivation is to understand the interplay between these two astrophysical phenomena.We employ a multi-wavelength observational approach to study the spectral and temporal behavior of jets and blazars across different energy bands. Additionally, we carry out theoretical modeling to interpret our observations and extract physical information about the sources. Our results suggest that the EBL has a significant impact on the gamma-ray emission from blazars, which can be used to infer the EBL density. We also find evidence for spectral variability and flaring activity in several sources, which can provide insights into the acceleration and emission mechanisms of high-energy particles in jets and blazars. Finally, we discuss the implications of our findings for future surveys with GLAST and other high-energy observatories.

human_text: The synergy of GLAST and the proposed EXIST mission as the Black Hole Finder Probe in the Beyond Einstein Program is remarkable. With its full-sky per orbit hard X-ray imaging (3-600 keV) and 'nuFnu' sensitivity comparable to GLAST, EXIST could measure variability and spectra of Blazars in the hard X-ray synchrotron component simultaneous with GLAST ( 10-100GeV) measures of the inverse Compton component, thereby uniquely constraining intrinsic source spectra and allowing measured high energy spectral breaks to measure the cosmic diffuse extra-galactic background light (EBL) by determining the intervening diffuse IR photon field required to yield the observed break from photon-photon absorption. Such studies also constrain the physics of jets (and parameters and indeed the validity of SSC models) and the origin of the >100 MeV gamma-ray diffuse background likely arising from Blazars and jet-dominated sources. An overview of the EXIST mission, which could fly in the GLAST era, is given together with a synopsis of other key synergies of GLAST-EXIST science.

machine_text: In this work, we present the results of a Fourier resolved spectroscopy analysis of the low-mass X-ray binary 4U 1728-34. Our investigation focused on deciphering the spectral and temporal properties of the binary system using high-resolution X-ray spectra obtained by the Reflection Grating Spectrometer on board the XMM-Newton satellite.The primary aim of our study was to investigate the possible presence of a high-frequency QPO (HFQPO) in the power spectrum of 4U 1728-34. Our methodology involved the use of Fourier analysis to resolve the X-ray spectrum into narrow frequency bands and investigate the properties of the corresponding power spectra.Our analysis revealed the presence of a broad bump centered around 30 Hz in the power spectral density distribution. Contrary to our expectations, we did not find evidence for the existence of a coherent HFQPO in the frequency range of 30-100 Hz. Furthermore, our results suggest that the observed variability is likely due to the combination of several incoherent frequency components.Overall, this study provides new insights into the spectral and temporal properties of low-mass X-ray binaries and reveals that the HFQPO phenomenon might be more elusive than previously thought. Our findings contribute to advancing the field of X-ray astronomy and have implications for the interpretation of similar systems.

human_text: Using archival RXTE data we derive the 2-16 keV Fourier-resolved spectra of the Atoll source 4U 1728-34 in a sequence of its timing states as its low QPO frequency spans the range between 6 and 94 Hz. The increase in the QPO frequency accompanies a spectral transition of the source from its island to its banana states. The banana-states' Fourier-resolved spectra are well fitted by a single blackbody component with kT ∼ 2-3 keV depending on the source position in the color – color diagram and the Fourier frequency, thus indicating that this spectral component is responsible for the source variability on these timescales. This result is in approximate agreement with similar behavior exhibited by the Z sources, suggesting that, as in that case, the boundary layer – the likely source of the thermal component – is supported by radiation pressure. Furthermore, it is found that the iron line at ∼6.6 keV, clearly present in the averaged spectra, not apparent within the limitations of our measurements in the frequency-resolved spectra irrespective of the frequency range. This would indicate that this spectral component exhibits little variability on time scales comprising the interval 10^-2-10^2 seconds. In the island state the single blackbody model proved inadequate, particularly notable in our lowest frequency band (0.008-0.8 Hz). An absorbed powerlaw or an additive blackbody plus hard powerlaw model was required to obtain a satisfactory fit. Statistics do not allow unambiguous discrimination between these possible scenarios.

machine_text: In this work, we investigate the application of Newton's law in the context of supersymmetric braneworld models. human_text: We study the propagation of gravitons within 5-D supersymmetric braneworld models with a bulk scalar field. The setup considered here consists of a 5-D bulk spacetime bounded by two 4-D branes localized at the fixed points of an S^1/Z_2 orbifold. There is a scalar field ϕ in the bulk which, provided a superpotential W(ϕ), determines the warped geometry of the 5-D spacetime. This type of scenario is common in string theory, where the bulk scalar field ϕ is related to the volume of small compact extra dimensions. We show that, after the moduli are stabilized by supersymmetry breaking terms localized on the branes, the only relevant degrees of freedom in the bulk consist of a 5-D massive spectrum of gravitons. Then we analyze the gravitational interaction between massive bodies localized at the positive tension brane mediated by these bulk gravitons. It is shown that the Newtonian potential describing this interaction picks up a non-trivial contribution at short distances that depends on the shape of the superpotential W(ϕ). We compute this contribution for dilatonic braneworld scenarios W(ϕ) = e^αϕ (where α is a constant) and discuss the particular case of 5-D Heterotic M-theory: It is argued that a specific footprint at micron scales could be observable in the near future.

machine_text: In this work, we propose a route towards the estimation of the cosmological constant Lambda within the framework of conformally coupled phantom cosmology. The main idea is to investigate the dynamics of the scalar field coupled conformally to gravity and dark matter. This allows us to understand the origin of the cosmological constant and its relation to the scalar field potential. We adopt two different approaches to obtain the cosmological constant Lambda. Firstly, we derive an expression for Lambda from the effective potential of the scalar field. Secondly, we consider the cosmological perturbation theory to extract the Lambda value.The motivation for this research is to explore the role of the scalar field potential in the evolution of the universe, with emphasis on the estimation of the cosmological constant Lambda. The cosmological constant problem, related to the fine-tuning issue, is a fundamental problem in modern cosmology. Using conformally coupled phantom cosmology, we aim to provide a natural explanation for the origin of Lambda without the necessity of such fine-tuning procedures.Our work attempts to solve the problem of the origin of the cosmological constant within this framework. By estimating Lambda using the two approaches developed, we expect to obtain a value that can be compared to observations in order to test the validity of conformally coupled phantom cosmology. These results can also shed light on alternative explanations for dark energy, usually attributed to the cosmological constant.

human_text: In this letter we investigate acceleration in the flat cosmological model with a conformally coupled phantom field and we show that acceleration is its generic feature. We reduce the dynamics of the model to a 3-dimensional dynamical system and analyze it on a invariant 2-dimensional submanifold. Then the concordance FRW model with the cosmological constant Λ is a global attractor situated on a 2-dimensional invariant space. We also study the behaviour near this attractor, which can be approximated by the dynamics of the linearized part of the system. We demonstrate that trajectories of the conformally coupled phantom scalar field with a simple quadratic potential crosses the cosmological constant barrier infinitely many times in the phase space. The universal behaviour of the scalar field and its potential is also calculated. We conclude that the phantom scalar field conformally coupled to gravity gives a natural dynamical mechanism of concentration of the equation of state coefficient around the magical value w_eff=-1. We demonstrate route to Lambda through the infinite times crossing the w_eff=-1 phantom divide.

machine_text: In this work, we investigate the in-plane structure and ordering at liquid sodium surfaces and interfaces using ab initio molecular dynamics simulations. The motivation for this research is rooted in the lack of knowledge regarding the local organization of liquid sodium at its surfaces and interfaces, despite the abundance of experimental and theoretical studies on bulk sodium. Understanding the structural and ordering properties of liquid sodium is critical for the development of sodium-based energy systems, such as sodium-ion batteries.Our simulations reveal that the local structure of liquid sodium at its surface is different from that of the bulk, with a preference for the formation of compact atomic clusters. Moreover, we find that the structure of the interface between liquid sodium and a graphite surface is determined by the mutual influence of surface reconstruction and ionic ordering, resulting in a periodic stacking of sodium layers on graphite. Our findings provide valuable insights into the behavior of liquid sodium at its surfaces and interfaces, with implications for the design and optimization of sodium-based energy systems.The key ideas and methodology in our research involve the application of ab initio molecular dynamics, which provides a first-principles understanding of complex systems without the need for experimental data. Our simulations were performed using density functional theory, and the resulting electronic and atomic structures were analyzed using visualization and statistical tools. Our approach provides a powerful and efficient means of exploring complex liquid-solid interfaces for a broad range of materials.

human_text: Atoms at liquid metal surfaces are known to form layers parallel to the surface. We analyze the two-dimensional arrangement of atoms within such layers at the surface of liquid sodium, using ab initio molecular dynamics (MD) simulations based on density functional theory. Nearest neighbor distributions at the surface indicate mostly 5-fold coordination, though there are noticeable fractions of 4-fold and 6-fold coordinated atoms. Bond angle distributions suggest a movement toward the angles corresponding to a six-fold coordinated hexagonal arrangement of the atoms as the temperature is decreased towards the solidification point. We rationalize these results with a distorted hexagonal order at the surface, showing a mixture of regions of five and six-fold coordination. The liquid surface results are compared with classical MD simulations of the liquid surface, with similar effects appearing, and with ab initio MD simulations for a model solid-liquid interface, where a pronounced shift towards hexagonal ordering is observed as the temperature is lowered.

machine_text: In this work, we present a theoretical framework for studying capillary-induced interactions that extends beyond the common superposition approximation. The motivation for this research arises from the fact that capillary forces play a crucial role in many natural as well as technological processes, ranging from cell adhesion to the behavior of nanoparticles in liquid suspensions. In order to understand these phenomena more accurately, it is necessary to go beyond the traditional assumption of linear superposition of capillary forces.Our approach is based on the concept of non-additive interfacial energies, which takes into account the interaction between the liquid menisci. We develop an analytical model that incorporates both the capillary interactions and the elasticity of the interfacial film, taking into account spatial non-uniformities in the curvature of the liquid-solid interface. We use this model to explore different geometries and material properties, with the goal of predicting and quantifying the interactions between small particles or structures immersed in a liquid.Our results show that capillary-induced interactions can be strongly non-additive, and that this effect becomes increasingly pronounced as the liquid menisci become more curved. We demonstrate the importance of including higher-order terms in the interfacial energy expansion, and highlight different regimes of interaction that can arise depending on the relative size of the particles or structures. Overall, our work provides a more accurate and versatile framework for understanding and predicting capillary forces, and has implications for a broad range of fields.

human_text: Within a general theoretical framework we study the effective, deformation-induced interaction between two colloidal particles trapped at a fluid interface in the regime of small deformations. In many studies, this interaction has been computed with the ansatz that the actual interface configuration for the pair is given by the linear superposition of the interface deformations around the single particles. Here we assess the validity of this approach and compute the leading term of the effective interaction for large interparticle separation beyond this so-called superposition approximation. As an application, we consider the experimentally relevant case of interface deformations owing to the electrostatic field emanating from charged colloidal particles. In mechanical isolation, i.e., if the net force acting on the total system consisting of the particles plus the interface vanishes, the superposition approximation is actually invalid. The effective capillary interaction is governed by contributions beyond this approximation and turns out to be attractive. For sufficiently small surface charges on the colloids, such that linearization is strictly valid, and at asymptotically large separations, the effective interaction does not overcome the direct electrostatic repulsion between the colloidal particles.

machine_text: In this study, we investigate the softening of the stiffness of bottlebrush polymers through mutual interactions. Bottlebrush polymers are macromolecules with a linear backbone and side chains densely packed like the bristles of a brush. Due to their unique structure, they exhibit unique mechanical properties that have potential applications in drug delivery, coatings, and nanocomposites. However, their stiffness often hinders their practical use.To tackle this problem, we explore the mutual interactions between bottlebrushes in a melt using molecular dynamics simulations. Our simulations show that the stiffness of bottlebrushes can be significantly reduced by decreasing the distance between their side chains, leading to a more flexible and easier to manipulate material. Furthermore, we find that the nature of the side chain chemistry and the degree of branching affect the mutual interaction strength and, consequently, the softening effect.Our research provides a deeper understanding of the relationship between the structure and properties of bottlebrush polymers, facilitating their future design and development. By softening the stiffness of bottlebrushes, we improve their processability and enable their use in a wider range of applications.

human_text: We study bottlebrush macromolecules in a good solvent by small-angle neutron scattering (SANS), static light scattering (SLS), and dynamic light scattering (DLS). These polymers consist of a linear backbone to which long side chains are chemically grafted. The backbone contains about 1600 monomer units (weight average) and every second monomer unit carries side-chains with ca. 60 monomer units. The SLS- and SANS data extrapolated to infinite dilution lead to the form factor of the polymer that can be described in terms of a worm-like chain with a contour length of 380 nm and a persistence length of 17.5 nm. An analysis of the DLS data confirm these model parameters. The scattering intensities taken at finite concentration can be modeled using the polymer reference interaction site model. It reveals a softening of the bottlebrush polymers caused by their mutual interaction. We demonstrate that the persistence decreases from 17.5 nm down to 5 nm upon increasing the concentration from dilute solution to the highest concentration 40.59 g/l under consideration. The observed softening of the chains is comparable to the theoretically predicted decrease of the electrostatic persistence length of linear polyelectrolyte chains at finite concentrations.

machine_text: In this paper, we present our X-ray timing observations of PSR J1930+1852 in the Crab-like supernova remnant G54.1+0.3. Our main motivation for this research is to study the timing properties of this pulsar and infer its physical characteristics as well as the characteristics of its environment.We used data from the Chandra X-ray Observatory to carry out an in-depth study of the pulsar's timing properties. Our analysis revealed that PSR J1930+1852 has a stable rotation period with a spin-down rate of (9.1±0.7)×10^−11 s/s. We also detected significant pulse profile variations over time, suggesting the presence of magnetospheric emission modulated by the rotation of the pulsar.Furthermore, we found a correlation between the pulse profile and the X-ray luminosity, with a more complex profile observed at higher X-ray luminosities. This may indicate a change in the accretion flow or magnetosphere-ionosphere coupling. The key methodology used in our study involved modeling the observed pulse profiles, finding the pulse arrival times, and determining the pulsar's timing properties through a series of statistical analyses.In conclusion, our study provides valuable insights into the timing behavior of PSR J1930+1852 in the Crab-like supernova remnant G54.1+0.3. Our results have significant implications for understanding the processes driving the pulsar's emission and its interaction with the surrounding environment.

machine_text: In this research, we investigated the competition between hydrogen-like and isotropic interactions on polymer collapse. We aimed to understand the driving forces behind the collapse of polymer chains in various solvents and to determine the dominance of each interaction type on this process. To achieve this goal, we employed theoretical calculations and simulations based on a coarse-grained model of polymers.Our findings suggest that the strength and orientation of both hydrogen-like and isotropic interactions can significantly affect the collapse behavior of a polymer chain. In particular, we found that hydrogen-like interactions can enhance the collapse, while isotropic interactions can either stabilize or destabilize the collapsed state, depending on their strength and orientation relative to the polymer backbone.The importance of this work lies in providing a deeper understanding of the fundamental physics of polymer collapse and in providing a theoretical basis for designing polymer-based materials with desired properties. Our results can also shed light on the behavior of biological macromolecules, such as proteins and nucleic acids, which are strongly affected by hydrogen-like and isotropic interactions in their native environments.

human_text: We investigate a lattice model of polymers where the nearest-neighbour monomer-monomer interaction strengths differ according to whether the local configurations have so-called “hydrogen-like” formations or not. If the interaction strengths are all the same then the classical θ-point collapse transition occurs on lowering the temperature, and the polymer enters the isotropic liquid-drop phase known as the collapsed globule. On the other hand, strongly favouring the hydrogen-like interactions give rise to an anisotropic folded (solid-like) phase on lowering the temperature. We use Monte Carlo simulations up to a length of 256 to map out the phase diagram in the plane of parameters and determine the order of the associated phase transitions. We discuss the connections to semi-flexible polymers and other polymer models. Importantly, we demonstrate that for a range of energy parameters two phase transitions occur on lowering the temperature, the second being a transition from the globule state to the crystal state. We argue from our data that this globule-to-crystal transition is continuous in two dimensions in accord with field-theory arguments concerning Hamiltonian walks, but is first order in three dimensions.

machine_text: In this study, we simulate the charging of the test mass of the ASTROD I spacecraft due to the impact of solar energetic particles (SEPs). The key objective of this work is to understand and quantify the effect of this charging on the spacecraft's attitude determination and control system (ADCS). The ASTROD I mission aims to measure the gravitational constant with unprecedented accuracy using extremely precise interferometry. The test mass is released in deep space, and the spacecraft follows it at a distance of several thousand kilometers. The measurement accuracy of the test mass's position is critical to achieve the mission's goals.Our team developed a simulation tool that models the particle environment around the spacecraft and calculates the charging of the test mass due to the impacting SEPs. Using this tool, we estimate the temporal variation of the electrostatic potential on the test mass and quantify the charging-induced disturbances of ADCS. Our results show that the charging effect is significant and that the ADCS performance is substantially degraded under certain conditions. Our simulation tool can assist the mission planners in determining the optimal operational scenarios for the ASTROD I spacecraft to achieve the mission's scientific goals.

human_text: As ASTROD I travels through space, its test mass will accrue charge due to galactic cosmic-rays and solar energetic particles incident on the spacecraft. This test mass charge will result in Coulomb forces between the test mass and the surrounding electrodes. In earlier work using the GEANT4 toolkit, we predicted a net charging rate of nearly 9.0 +e/s from cosmic-ray protons between 0.1 and 1000 GeV at solar maximum, and rising to 26.5 +e/s at solar minimum. Here we use GEANT4 to simulate the charging process due to solar energetic particle events and to estimate the magnitude of acceleration noise due to this charging. The predicted charging rates range from 2840 to 64300 +e/s, at peak intensity, for the 4 largest SEP events in September and October 1989. For the 2 larger events, the acceleration disturbances due to charging exceeds the ASTROD I acceleration noise budget requirement. Continuous discharge should be considered for suppressing this charging noise. The acceleration noise during the 2 small events is well below the design target, although during these events, the net charging rate will be dominated by these solar fluxes.

machine_text: In this study, we investigate the catastrophic eruption of magnetic flux ropes in the corona and solar wind with and without the occurrence of magnetic reconnection. Our motivation for this research is to understand the physical mechanisms underlying explosive solar events, which can result in severe space weather impacts on Earth. The problem that this work attempts to solve is to determine the extent to which magnetic reconnection is necessary for the explosive eruption of magnetic flux ropes, and to provide insights into the origin and dynamics of these events.We simulate the eruption of magnetic flux ropes in the corona and solar wind using a three-dimensional magnetohydrodynamic model. Our simulations show that the catastrophic eruption of magnetic flux ropes is possible both with and without magnetic reconnection. However, magnetic reconnection enhances the explosive nature of the eruption and leads to a faster and more energetic release of magnetic energy. In addition, we find that the interplay between magnetic reconnection and the expanded solar wind plays a key role in determining the morphology and dynamics of the resulting eruption.Our results shed light on the fundamental processes that power explosive solar events and have important implications for space weather forecasting and prediction. They also highlight the need for continued research into the complex physics of magnetized plasmas in the solar corona and beyond.

human_text: It is generally believed that the magnetic free energy accumulated in the corona serves as a main energy source for solar explosions such as coronal mass ejections (CMEs). In the framework of the flux rope catastrophe model for CMEs, the energy may be abruptly released either by an ideal magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) catastrophe, which belongs to a global magnetic topological instability of the system, or by a fast magnetic reconnection across preexisting or rapidly-developing electric current sheets. Both ways of magnetic energy release are thought to be important to CME dynamics. To disentangle their contributions, we construct a flux rope catastrophe model in the corona and solar wind and compare different cases in which we either prohibit or allow magnetic reconnection to take place across rapidly-growing current sheets during the eruption. It is demonstrated that CMEs, even fast ones, can be produced taking the ideal MHD catastrophe as the only process of magnetic energy release. Nevertheless, the eruptive speed can be significantly enhanced after magnetic reconnection sets in. In addition, a smooth transition from slow to fast eruptions is observed when increasing the strength of the background magnetic field, simply because in a stronger field there is more free magnetic energy at the catastrophic point available to be released during an eruption. This suggests that fast and slow CMEs may have an identical driving mechanism.

machine_text: Our work presents a novel string-derived Z' model with R-parity violation and stable proton as well as light neutrinos. The motivation for this research lies in the exploration of beyond the Standard Model scenarios and the resolution of certain drawbacks faced by existing models. We begin by constructing a new model using string theory techniques, incorporating a new symmetry U(1)B-L and a scalar field responsible for R-parity violation.Our analysis reveals several significant results. The new symmetry U(1)B-L allows for conservation of baryon number and lepton number in reactions, thus ensuring the stability of protons. The introduction of the scalar field responsible for R-parity violation leads to the production of light neutrinos, a long-standing challenge in many models.Our methodology involves the examination of the particle content, gauge symmetry, and Higgs structure of the new model. We further analyze the constraints imposed by experimental observations on the coupling parameters and mass scales of the model.Overall, our work presents a viable and consistent model with several unique features that addresses fundamental issues in the Standard Model. Our results provide fresh insights into the unification of forces and the origin of neutrino masses, compelling areas of research in theoretical physics and cosmology.
