human_text: The Standard Model indicates the realization of grand unified structures in nature, and can only be viewed as an effective theory below a higher energy cutoff. While the renormalizable Standard Model forbids proton decay mediating operators due to accidental global symmetries, many extensions of the Standard Model introduce such dimension four, five and six operators. Furthermore, quantum gravity effects are expected to induce proton instability, indicating that the higher energy cutoff scale must be above 10^16GeV. Quasi-realistic heterotic string models provide the arena to explore how perturbative quantum gravity affects the particle physics phenomenology. An appealing explanation for the proton longevity is provided by the existence of an Abelian gauge symmetry that suppresses the proton decay mediating operators. Additionally, such a low-scale U(1) symmetry should: allow the suppression of the left-handed neutrino masses by a seesaw mechanism; allow fermion Yukawa couplings to the electroweak Higgs doublets; be anomaly free; be family universal. These requirements render the existence of such U(1) symmetries in quasi-realistic heterotic string models highly non-trivial. We demonstrate the existence of a U(1) symmetry that satisfies all of the above requirements in a class of left-right symmetric heterotic string models in the free fermionic formulation. The existence of the extra Z' in the energy range accessible to future experiments is motivated by the requirement of adequate suppression of proton decay mediation. We further show that while the extra U(1) forbids dimension four baryon number violating operators it allows dimension four lepton number violating operators and R-parity violation.

machine_text: In this paper, we present an investigation of the slow dynamics of a silica melt using Monte Carlo simulations. Our work aims to revisit this well-studied system and generate new insights into its properties. We want to understand the relaxation dynamics of the melt in a temperature range close to the glass transition temperature. The problem we attempt to solve is related to the glass transition phenomenon. In particular, we want to explore how the dynamics of the system evolve when the temperature is lowered and how this is related to the structural properties of the material.Our results show that the dynamics of the silica melt slow down significantly when the temperature is lowered. This is accompanied by a corresponding increase in structural relaxation timescales. We observe that the relaxation time scales with the inverse of the temperature, which is consistent with the temperature dependence of the relaxation dynamics near the glass transition temperature. Furthermore, we find that the relaxation process is non-trivial and displays arrhenius behavior in some temperature ranges. Additionally, our simulations enable us to investigate the slow relaxation dynamics of the system on long timescales.Overall, our work provides new insights into the slow dynamics of the silica melt. Our simulations are consistent with previous experiments and provide additional information about the behavior of the system. Our approach can be applied to other amorphous systems and may provide further insight into the properties of glasses and the glass transition phenomenon.

human_text: We implement a standard Monte Carlo algorithm to study the slow, equilibrium dynamics of a silica melt in a wide temperature regime, from 6100 K down to 2750 K. We find that the average dynamical behaviour of the system is in quantitative agreement with results obtained from molecular dynamics simulations, at least in the long-time regime corresponding to the alpha-relaxation. By contrast, the strong thermal vibrations related to the Boson peak present at short times in molecular dynamics are efficiently suppressed by the Monte Carlo algorithm. This allows us to reconsider silica dynamics in the context of mode-coupling theory, because several shortcomings of the theory were previously attributed to thermal vibrations. A mode-coupling theory analysis of our data is qualitatively correct, but quantitative tests of the theory fail, raising doubts about the very existence of an avoided singularity in this system. We discuss the emergence of dynamic heterogeneity and report detailed measurements of a decoupling between translational diffusion and structural relaxation, and of a growing four-point dynamic susceptibility. Dynamic heterogeneity appears to be less pronounced than in more fragile glass-forming models, but not of a qualitatively different nature.

machine_text: The Hamiltonian formalism has proven to be a powerful tool for studying the dynamics of physical systems, including those in cosmology. In this work, we apply the Hamiltonian approach to the Friedmann cosmology model, which describes the large-scale evolution of the universe. Our goal is to obtain a Hamiltonian formulation of the model and investigate its quantization.The motivation for this research is twofold. Firstly, it allows us to study the quantum properties of the universe, providing a theoretical framework for understanding phenomena such as the cosmic microwave background or the formation of galaxies. Secondly, it allows us to test the validity of fundamental physical theories, such as general relativity, in the high-energy regime where they are expected to break down.The key ideas of our approach involve identifying the canonical variables of the Friedmann model, constructing the corresponding Hamiltonian, and imposing appropriate quantization conditions. Our methodology involves combining analytical calculations with numerical simulations, such as solving the Schrodinger equation for the system's wave function.Our main results include the derivation of a Hamiltonian formalism for the Friedmann model, as well as preliminary calculations for its quantum properties. We discuss the implications of our findings for the broader field of cosmology, highlighting the potential for future research in this area.

human_text: We propose a Hamiltonian formalism for a generalized Friedmann-Roberson-Walker cosmology model in the presence of both a variable equation of state (EOS) parameter w(a) and a variable cosmological constant Λ(a), where a is the scale factor. This Hamiltonian system containing 1 degree of freedom and without constraint, gives Friedmann equations as the equation of motion, which describes a mechanical system with a variable mass object moving in a potential field. After an appropriate transformation of the scale factor, this system can be further simplified to an object with constant mass moving in an effective potential field. In this framework, the Λ cold dark matter model as the current standard model of cosmology corresponds to a harmonic oscillator. We further generalize this formalism to take into account the bulk viscosity and other cases. The Hamiltonian can be quantized straightforwardly, but this is different from the approach of the Wheeler-DeWitt equation in quantum cosmology.

machine_text: In longitudinal studies, individual heterogeneity can pose challenges when using statistical models to understand the relationship between a predictor and an outcome. This problem is especially prevalent in studies on student achievement, as individual differences in factors such as socioeconomic status and prior academic ability can impact student outcomes. To address this issue, our work proposes the use of mixed-effects models, which allow for the modeling of individual-specific variation as random effects. By controlling for individual heterogeneity in this way, we can mitigate bias and enhance the accuracy of our estimates.Our methodology was applied to a longitudinal student achievement dataset from a large urban school district in the United States. We used mixed-effects models to study the relationship between classroom quality and student achievement over time while controlling for individual-level factors, such as prior academic performance. Our analyses revealed that, after accounting for individual heterogeneity, classroom quality was significantly associated with student achievement.These results have important implications for policymakers and educators interested in improving student outcomes in urban schools. By identifying the importance of classroom quality and accounting for individual differences, our work provides a more accurate understanding of how to support student success in these contexts. Overall, our approach demonstrates the importance of controlling for individual heterogeneity in longitudinal models and offers a valuable tool for researchers working with similar datasets, both in education and in other disciplines.

human_text: Longitudinal data tracking repeated measurements on individuals are highly valued for research because they offer controls for unmeasured individual heterogeneity that might otherwise bias results. Random effects or mixed models approaches, which treat individual heterogeneity as part of the model error term and use generalized least squares to estimate model parameters, are often criticized because correlation between unobserved individual effects and other model variables can lead to biased and inconsistent parameter estimates. Starting with an examination of the relationship between random effects and fixed effects estimators in the standard unobserved effects model, this article demonstrates through analysis and simulation that the mixed model approach has a “bias compression” property under a general model for individual heterogeneity that can mitigate bias due to uncontrolled differences among individuals. The general model is motivated by the complexities of longitudinal student achievement measures, but the results have broad applicability to longitudinal modeling.

This program uses realistic scientific models to evaluate the effectiveness of different asteroid deflection strategies.The problem this work attempts to solve is the need to develop and implement an effective asteroid deflection strategy to protect our planet from a potentially catastrophic impact. By providing a thorough analysis of the key ideas and methodologies for asteroid deflection, this work aims to contribute to the development of effective asteroid deflection strategies and inform policy decisions related to planetary defense.

machine_text: In our work titled 'The absolute Galois group acts faithfully on the connected components of the moduli space of surfaces of general type,' we explore the relationship between the absolute Galois group and the moduli space of surfaces of general type. This area of study has been a topic of interest for many years, as mathematicians seek a deeper understanding of how the Galois group interacts with various mathematical structures.Our research focuses on the problem of understanding the action of the absolute Galois group on the connected components of the moduli space of surfaces of general type. We aim to show that this action is faithful, meaning that no two non-isomorphic components are mapped to the same component by the Galois group. This is an important result because it provides insight into the underlying structure of the moduli space and contributes to our understanding of the relationship between the Galois group and algebraic geometry.To achieve this, we use a combination of algebraic and geometric techniques, including the study of étale covers and the use of Kähler differentials. Our approach is based on a deep understanding of both algebraic geometry and Galois theory, and we employ a formal academic and scientific writing voice throughout our work. human_text: We show that the Galois group Gal( /) operates faithfully on the set of connected components of the moduli spaces of surfaces of general type, and also that for each element σ∈ Gal( /) different from the identity and from complex conjugation, there is a surface of general type such that X and the Galois conjugate variety X^σ have nonisomorphic fundamental groups. The result was announced by the second author at the Alghero Conference 'Topology of algebraic varieties' in september 2006. Before the present paper was actually written, we received a very interesting preprint by Robert Easton and Ravi Vakil (<cit.>), where it is proven, with a completely different type of examples, that the Galois group Gal( /) operates faithfully on the set of irreducible components of the moduli spaces of surfaces of general type. We also give other simpler examples of surfaces with nonisomorphic fundamental groups which are Galois conjugate, hence have isomorphic algebraic fundamental groups.

machine_text: In this work, we investigate the collective states of odd-mass nuclei within the framework of the Interacting Vector Boson Model (IVBM). Our motivation for this research lies in the fact that odd-mass nuclei are essential to the study of nuclear structure and are important for understanding nuclear phenomena like nuclear reactions and radioactive decay.We use the IVBM to investigate the properties of odd-mass nuclei and study their excitation spectra and electromagnetic transition rates. The IVBM considers a nucleon as a composite system that can interact with other nucleons within the nucleus via the exchange of vector bosons. This model is particularly useful for the description of nuclear collective states, such as rotational bands and vibrations.Our methodology involves using computer simulations based on the IVBM to study the properties of odd-mass nuclei. We examine several isotones and isotopes of different elements and analyze the spectra and transition rates of these nuclei.Our results show that the IVBM is capable of describing the collective states of odd-mass nuclei with reasonable accuracy. We find that the electromagnetic transition rates and excitation energies of these states are consistent with experimental data, indicating that the IVBM can provide a useful framework for understanding the properties of odd-mass nuclei. Overall, our study contributes to the ongoing efforts to understand the structure of atomic nuclei and the properties of the strong nuclear force.

human_text: A supersymmetric extension of the dynamical symmetry group Sp^B(12,R) of the Interacting Vector Boson Model (IVBM), to the orthosymplectic group OSp(2Ω/12,R) is developed in order to incorporate fermion degrees of freedom into the nuclear dynamics and to encompass the treatment of odd mass nuclei. The bosonic sector of the supergroup is used to describe the complex collective spectra of the neighboring even-even nuclei and is considered as a core structure of the odd nucleus. The fermionic sector is represented by the fermion spin group SO^F(2Ω)⊃ SU^F(2).The so obtained, new exactly solvable limiting case is applied for the description of the nuclear collective spectra of odd mass nuclei. The theoretical predictions for different collective bands in three odd mass nuclei, namely ^157Gd, ^173Yb and ^163Dy from rare earth region are compared with the experiment. The B(E2) transition probabilities for the ^157Gd and ^163Dy between the states of the ground band are also studied. The important role of the symplectic structure of the model for the proper reproduction of the B(E2) behavior is revealed. The obtained results reveal the applicability of the models extension.

machine_text: In this study, we aimed to simulate heme using the Density Functional Theory plus Hubbard U correction (DFT+U) and investigate the accuracy of spin-state energetics. Heme is an essential protein in many biological processes, including oxygen transport and electron transfer. The accurate determination of its spin-state energetics is crucial for understanding its functional mechanism. However, the spin-state energetics of heme are a challenging problem because of the strong electron correlation effects. In this study, we first validated the DFT+U approach by comparing our results with experimental data. We then compared our calculations with those from the DFT approach, which neglects electron correlation effects, and found that the DFT+U approach consistently gave a lower energy for the high-spin state than the DFT approach. Furthermore, we demonstrated that the inclusion of U significantly improves the accuracy of the energy predictions by taking into account the electron correlation effects. These findings reveal the importance of including electron correlation effects in simulating spin-state energetics of heme, and the DFT+U approach provides a reliable method for such simulations. This work paves the way for more accurate simulations of heme and other systems with strong electron correlation effects, and thus contributes to the advancement of computational chemistry and materials science.

human_text: We investigate the DFT+U approach as a viable solution to describe the low-lying states of ligated and unligated iron heme complexes. Besides their central role in organometallic chemistry, these compounds represent a paradigmatic case where LDA, GGA, and common hybrid functionals fail to reproduce the experimental magnetic splittings. In particular, the imidazole pentacoordinated heme is incorrectly described as a triplet by all usual DFT flavors. In this study we show that a U parameter close to 4 eV leads to spin transitions and molecular geometries in quantitative agreement with experiments, and that DFT+U represents an appealing tool in the description of iron porphyrin complexes, at a much reduced cost compared to correlated quantum-chemistry methods. The possibility of obtaining the U parameter from first-principles is explored through a self-consistent linear-response formulation. We find that this approach, which proved to be successful in other iron systems, produces in this case some overestimation with respect to the optimal values of U.

human_text: Yang's theorem forbids the process Z^0 → 2γ in any Poincaré invariant theory if photons are bosons and their two-particle states transform under the Poincaré group in the standard way (under the standard coproduct of the Poincaré group). This is an important result as it does not depend on the assumptions of quantum field theory. Recent work on noncommutative geometry requires deforming the above coproduct by the Drinfel'd twist. We prove that Z^0 → 2γ is forbidden for the twisted coproduct as well. This result is also independent of the assumptions of quantum field theory. As an illustration of the use of our general formulae, we further show that Z^0 →ν + ν is forbidden for the standard or twisted coproduct of the Poincaré group if the neutrino is massless, even if lepton number is not conserved. This is a special case of our general result that a massive particle of spin j cannot decay into two identical massless particles of the same helicity if j is odd, regardless of the coproduct used.

human_text: To study the effects of galactic winds on the stellar metallicity distributions and on the evolution of Draco and Ursa Minor dwarf spheroidal galaxies, we compared the predictions of several chemical evolution models, adopting different prescriptions for the galactic winds, with the photometrically-derived stellar metallicity distributions of both galaxies. The chemical evolution models for Draco and Ursa Minor, which are able to reproduce several observational features of these two galaxies, such as the several abundance ratios, take up-to-date nucleosynthesis into account for intermediate-mass stars and supernovae of both types, as well as the effect of these objects on the energetics of the systems. For both galaxies, the model that best fits the data contains an intense continuous galactic wind, occurring at a rate proportional to the star formation rate. Models with a wind rate assumed to be proportional only to the supernova rate also reproduce the observed SMD, but do not match the gas mass, whereas the models with no galactic winds fail to reproduce the observed SMDs. In the case of Ursa Minor, the same model as in previous works reproduces the observed distribution very well with no need to modify the main parameters of the model. The model for Draco, on the other hand, is slightly modified. The observed SMD requires a model with a lower supernova type Ia thermalization efficiency (η_SNeIa = 0.5 instead of η_SNeIa = 1.0) in order to delay the galactic wind, whereas all the other parameters are kept the same. The model results, compared to observations, strongly suggest that intense and continuous galactic winds play a very important role in the evolution of local dSphs.

human_text: Recent results from the HESS gamma ray telescope have shown the presence of both a diffuse, extended, flux of gamma rays above0.4 TeV and discrete sources in and near the Galactic Centre. Here, we put forward a possible explanation in terms of the diffusion of cosmic ray protons from a succession of supernova remnants (SNR) in the SgrA* region of the Galaxy plus a contribution from SNR in the rest of the Galactic Centre Region, to be called the Galactic Centre Ridge (GCR). Protons are favoured over electrons because the mG magnetic fields in the Region will attenuate energetic electrons severely. Prominent features are the need for 'anomalous diffusion' of the protons in the whole region and the adoption of low efficiency for SNR acceleration in the high density regions. The latter is related by us to the well-known low 'cosmic ray gradient' in the Galaxy. A corroborating feature is the close correlation of inferred cosmic ray intensity with the smoothed intensity of 5 GHZ radio radiation. We attribute this to the presence of the SNR in the GCR.

machine_text: In this work, we present a systematic method for performing unitarity analysis of non-Abelian gauge invariant actions with a mass. The key idea involves constructing a ghost-free and unitary S-matrix through the renormalization and gauge fixing procedure. We apply this methodology to a specific model, the non-Abelian gauge invariant action with a mass, and show that it satisfies both ghost-free and unitary constraints.The main problem this work attempts to solve is the consistent formulation of non-Abelian gauge theories with a mass. While massive gauge bosons are necessary to account for the weak force in the standard model, the presence of mass terms in the usual gauge invariant Lagrangians leads to ghost fields, which spoil unitarity and causality. Our approach thus provides a crucial step towards the development of a self-consistent formulation of massive non-Abelian gauge theories.Our results demonstrate that it is possible to construct a consistent and unitary S-matrix for non-Abelian gauge invariant theories with a mass. This proof of unitarity provides strong evidence that the proposed methodology can be used to avoid the well-known issues of ghost fields and maintain the consistency of theories with massive gauge bosons. We believe that our work will contribute to a deeper understanding of the nature of fundamental forces in particle physics, and may have important implications for the development of quantum field theories.

human_text: In previous work done by us and coworkers, we have been able to construct a local, non-Abelian gauge invariant action with a mass parameter, based on the nonlocal gauge invariant mass dimension two operator F1/D^2F. The renormalizability of the resulting action was proven to all orders of perturbation theory, in the class of linear covariant gauges. We also discussed the perturbative equivalence of the model with ordinary massless Yang-Mills gauge theories when the mass is identically zero. Furthermore, we pointed out the existence of a BRST symmetry with corresponding nilpotent charge. In this paper, we study the issue of unitarity of this massive gauge model. Firstly, we provide a short review how to discuss the unitarity making use of the BRST charge. Afterwards we make a detailed study of the most general version of our action, and we come to the conclusion that the model is not unitary, as we are unable to remove all the negative norm states from the physical spectrum in a consistent way.

machine_text: In this work, we explore the formation and collisional evolution of Kuiper Belt Objects (KBOs). The Kuiper belt is a region of the outer solar system beyond the orbit of Neptune that is home to a diverse population of small icy bodies. Understanding the formation and evolution of these objects can give insight into the early history of our solar system.Our work attempts to solve the problem of how KBOs formed and what processes have shaped their current population. We focus on collisional evolution and how collisions between KBOs have sculpted the size distribution and physical properties of the population.We use a combination of numerical simulations and analytical models to explore these questions. We simulate the collisional evolution of the KBO population over the age of the solar system and compare our results to observations.Our key findings include the importance of collisional grinding in shaping the sizes of KBOs, the role of giant planet migration in stirring up the Kuiper belt and triggering collisions, and the potential for a large population of sub-kilometer-sized objects that have not been detected yet.Overall, our work sheds light on the complex processes that have shaped the Kuiper belt and provides a framework for further exploration of this fascinating region of our solar system.

human_text: This chapter summarizes analytic theory and numerical calculations for the formation and collisional evolution of KBOs at 20–150 AU. We describe the main predictions of a baseline self-stirring model and show how dynamical perturbations from a stellar flyby or stirring by a giant planet modify the evolution. Although robust comparisons between observations and theory require better KBO statistics and more comprehensive calculations, the data are broadly consistent with KBO formation in a massive disk followed by substantial collisional grinding and dynamical ejection. However, there are important problems reconciling the results of coagulation and dynamical calculations. Contrasting our current understanding of the evolution of KBOs and asteroids suggests that additional observational constraints, such as the identification of more dynamical families of KBOs (like the 2003 EL61 family), would provide additional information on the relative roles of collisional grinding and dynamical ejection in the Kuiper Belt. The uncertainties also motivate calculations that combine collisional and dynamical evolution, a `unified' calculation that should give us a better picture of KBO formation and evolution.

machine_text: In this study, we investigate the use of the InterHourly-Variability (IHV) index of geomagnetic activity to derive the long-term variation of solar wind speed. The problem we attempt to solve is the lack of a reliable method to estimate long-term variations in solar wind speed, which is crucial for space weather prediction and forecasting. Our approach utilizes the IHV index, which is a statistical measure of magnetic field variations within each hour, as it provides a more accurate representation of the geomagnetic activity associated with solar wind variations on longer timescales.We analyzed the IHV index and solar wind speed data from 1963 to 2010 and found a strong correlation coefficient of 0.85 between the two parameters. Our study also reveals that the long-term variation in solar wind is influenced by both changes in the solar wind speed and geomagnetic activity, with the latter playing a more dominant role. We further validated our results by comparing them with the interplanetary magnetic field strength, demonstrating the robustness of our method.Our motivation for this research is to provide a more accurate and reliable method of estimating long-term variations in solar wind speed, which is critical for space weather prediction and forecasting. Our findings can be utilized by space weather centers, scientists, and engineers to improve space weather forecasts and mitigate potential impacts on technological infrastructure.

Our approach utilizes the IHV index, which is a statistical measure of magnetic field variations within each hour, as it provides a more accurate representation of the geomagnetic activity associated with solar wind variations on longer timescales.   We analyzed the IHV index and solar wind speed data from 1963 to 2010 and found a strong correlation coefficient of 0.85 between the two parameters. Our study also reveals that the long-term variation in solar wind is influenced by both changes in the solar wind speed and geomagnetic activity, with the latter playing a more dominant role. We further validated our results by comparing them with the interplanetary magnetic field strength, demonstrating the robustness of our method.   Our motivation for this research is to provide a more accurate and reliable method of estimating long-term variations in solar wind speed, which is critical for space weather prediction and forecasting. Our findings can be utilized by space weather centers, scientists, and engineers to improve space weather forecasts and mitigate potential impacts on technological infrastructure.

human_text: We describe the derivation of the InterHourly Variability (IHV) index of geomagnetic activity. The IHV-index for a geomagnetic element is mechanically derived from hourly values as the sum of the unsigned differences between adjacent hours over a seven-hour interval centered on local midnight. The index is derived separately for stations in both hemispheres within six longitude sectors using only local night hours. It is intended as a long-term index. Available data allows derivation of the index back well into the 19th century. On a time scale of a 27-day Bartels rotation, IHV averages for stations with corrected geomagnetic latitude less than 55 degrees are strongly correlated with midlatitude range indices. Assuming a constant calibration of the aa-index we find that observed yearly values of aa before the year 1957 are 2.9 nT too small compared to values calculated from IHV using the regression constants based on 1980-2004. We interpret this discrepancy as an indication that the calibration of the aa index is in error before 1957. There is no such problem with the ap index. Rotation averages of IHV are also strongly correlated with solar wind parameters (BV^2). On a time scale of a year combining the IHV-index and the recently-developed Inter-Diurnal Variability (IDV) index (giving B) allows determination of solar wind speed, V, from 1890-present. Over the120-year series, the yearly mean solar wind speed varied from a low of 303 km/s in 1902 to a high value of 545 km/s in 2003. The calculated yearly values of the product BV using B and V separately derived from IDV and IHV agree quantitatively with (completely independent) BV derived from the amplitude of the diurnal variation of the H component in the polar caps since 1926 and sporadically beyond.

machine_text: We present an integral field spectroscopic study of the extended emission-line region (EELR) of the high redshift quasar 4C 37.43. Motivated by the need to gain a deeper understanding of the environment surrounding quasars at earlier cosmic times, we use observations obtained with the Multi Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE) instrument mounted on the Very Large Telescope (VLT). Our key idea is to study the EELR, a region of ionized gas located far beyond the host galaxy, through a spatially resolved analysis of its kinematic properties, line ratios and ionization mechanisms. Our methodology consists of a combination of techniques such as spectral extraction, flux calibration, continuum subtraction, and emission-line fitting, which together allow us to obtain a detailed spatially resolved picture of the EELR. Our results indicate the presence of complex kinematic patterns, including the detection of outflowing gas in close proximity to the quasar, as well as strong evidence for an ionization gradient within the EELR. Our findings suggest a possible connection between the quasar and the EELR, indicating that the EELR may be ionized by the quasar itself or by a collimated outflowing wind from the central engine.

human_text: We present Gemini integral field spectroscopy and Keck II longslit spectroscopy of the extended emission-line region (EELR) around the quasar 4C 37.43. The velocity structure of the ionized gas is complex and cannot be explained globally by a simple dynamical model. The spectra from the clouds are inconsistent with shock or “shock + precursor” ionization models, but they are consistent with photoionization by the quasar nucleus. The best-fit photoionization model requires a low-metallicity (12+log(O/H) < 8.7) two-phase medium, consisting of a matter-bounded diffuse component with a unity filling-factor (N1 , T15000 K), in which are embedded small, dense clouds (N400 , T10^4 K). The high-density clouds are transient and can be re-generated through compressing the diffuse medium by low-speed shocks (V_S ≲100 ). Our photoionization model gives a total mass for the ionized gas of about 3x10^10 M_sun, and the total kinetic energy implied by this mass and the observed velocity field is2x10^58 ergs. The fact that luminous EELRs are confined to steep-spectrum radio-loud quasars, yet show no morphological correspondence to the radio jets, suggests that the driving force producing the 4C 37.43 EELR was a roughly spherical blast wave initiated by the production of the jet. That such a mechanism seems capable of ejecting a mass comparable to that of the total interstellar medium of the Milky Way suggests that “quasar-mode” feedback may indeed be an efficient means of regulating star formation in the early universe.

machine_text: In this work, we investigate the potential of using Large Eddy Simulations (LES) to model Highly Turbulent Solutions (HTS) of the Linearly Accelerated Navier-Stokes-alpha (LANS-alpha) equation. The motivation for this research stems from the need to improve the accuracy of turbulence simulations for various applications in engineering and science, where direct numerical simulations can be computationally expensive.We begin by simulating HTS solutions of the LANS-alpha equation using high-order numerical methods. Our results show that these solutions exhibit highly nonlinear, intermittent turbulent dynamics that are difficult to model accurately. The simulation data is then used to inform the development of an LES model, which we show can capture the large-scale features of the turbulence while significantly reducing the computational cost.Ultimately, our work demonstrates the potential of LES for accurately modeling HTS solutions of the LANS-alpha equation, and thus for improving turbulence simulations in a variety of fields. Our findings also suggest that further investigation into LES models for other types of turbulence may yield similar benefits, providing a pathway towards more efficient and accurate simulations of complex flow phenomena.

human_text: We compute solutions of the Lagrangian-Averaged Navier-Stokes alpha-model (LANS) for significantly higher Reynolds numbers (up to Re 8300) than have previously been accomplished. This allows sufficient separation of scales to observe a Navier-Stokes (NS) inertial range followed by a 2nd LANS inertial range. The analysis of the third-order structure function scaling supports the predicted l^3 scaling; it corresponds to a k^(-1) scaling of the energy spectrum. The energy spectrum itself shows a different scaling which goes as k^1. This latter spectrum is consistent with the absence of stretching in the sub-filter scales due to the Taylor frozen-in hypothesis employed as a closure in the derivation of LANS. These two scalings are conjectured to coexist in different spatial portions of the flow. The l^3 (E(k) k^(-1)) scaling is subdominant to k^1 in the energy spectrum, but the l^3 scaling is responsible for the direct energy cascade, as no cascade can result from motions with no internal degrees of freedom. We verify the prediction for the size of the LANS attractor resulting from this scaling. From this, we give a methodology either for arriving at grid-independent solutions for LANS, or for obtaining a formulation of a LES optimal in the context of the alpha models. The fully converged grid-independent LANS may not be the best approximation to a direct numerical simulation of the NS equations since the minimum error is a balance between truncation errors and the approximation error due to using LANS instead of the primitive equations. Furthermore, the small-scale behavior of LANS contributes to a reduction of flux at constant energy, leading to a shallower energy spectrum for large alpha. These small-scale features, do not preclude LANS to reproduce correctly the intermittency properties of high Re flow.

human_text: The cosmic abundance of the 3-He isotope has important implications for many fields of astrophysics. We are using the 8.665 GHz hyperfine transition of 3-He+ to determine the 3-He/H abundance in Milky Way HII regions and planetary nebulae. This is one in a series of papers in which we discuss issues involved in deriving accurate 3-He/H abundance ratios from the available measurements. Here we describe the ionization correction we use to convert the 3-He+/H+ abundance, y3+, to the 3-He/H abundance, y3. In principle the nebular ionization structure can significantly influence the y3 derived for individual sources. We find that in general there is insufficient information available to make a detailed ionization correction. Here we make a simple correction and assess its validity. The correction is based on radio recombination line measurements of H+ and 4-He+, together with simple core-halo source models. We use these models to establish criteria that allow us to identify sources that can be accurately corrected for ionization and those that cannot. We argue that this effect cannot be very large for most of the sources in our observational sample. For a wide range of models of nebular ionization structure we find that the ionization correction factor varies from 1 to 1.8. Although large corrections are possible, there would have to be a conspiracy between the density and ionization structure for us to underestimate the ionization correction by a substantial amount.

machine_text: In this work, we investigate the role of magnetic turbulence in the formation of planetesimals near the snow line in protoplanetary disks. The snow line, defined as the distance from the central star where water can exist in solid form, is a critical region for the formation of planetary embryos. However, the mechanism through which dust grains in this region accumulate remains poorly understood. To address this problem, we simulate the evolution of a protoplanetary disk including the effects of magnetic turbulence. Our simulations demonstrate that grain retention in the snow line region is greatly enhanced by the presence of magnetic turbulence. Specifically, we find that the turbulence generates high pressure regions that enable the accumulation of sub-millimeter-sized grains into planetesimals. Furthermore, we show that the rate of planetesimal formation is strongly dependent on the properties of the magnetic field, with stronger fields leading to more efficient grain retention. Our results provide insight into the physical processes governing the formation of planetesimals in the snow line region, with implications for the eventual formation of rocky planets in protoplanetary disks.

human_text: The first challenge in the formation of both terrestrial planets and the cores of gas giants is the retention of grains in protoplanetary disks. In most regions of these disks, gas attains sub-Keplerian speeds as a consequence of a negative pressure gradient. Hydrodynamic drag leads to orbital decay and depletion of the solid material in the disk, with characteristic timescales as short as only a few hundred years for meter-sized objects at 1 AU. In this paper, we suggest a particle retention mechanism which promotes the accumulation of grains and the formation of planetesimals near the water sublimation front or “snow line.” This model is based on the assumption that, in the regions most interesting for planet formation, the viscous evolution of the disk is due to turbulence driven by the magneto-rotational instability (MRI) in the surface layers of the disk. The depth to which MRI effectively generates turbulence is a strong function of the grain size and abundance. A sharp increase in the grain-to-gas density ratio across the snow line reduces the column depth of the active layer. As the disk evolves towards a quasi-steady-state, this change in the active layer creates a local maximum in radial distribution of the gas surface density and pressure, causing the gas to rotate at super-Keplerian speed and halting the inward migration of grains. This senario presents a robust process for grain retention which may aid in the formation of proto-gas-giant cores preferentially near the snow line.

machine_text: In this paper, we explore the resonant state in quantum mechanics and its computation. The motivation for this research is rooted in the fundamental importance of resonances in many areas of physics and chemistry, such as nuclear physics, particle physics, and quantum chemistry. Resonances are characterized by their complex energy eigenvalues, which correspond to a metastable state that decays over time.Our key idea is to derive an analytical expression for the resonant state by solving the Schrödinger equation with a complex potential function. We use the finite element method to discretize the problem and solve it numerically, comparing the results with the analytical solutions. We also investigate the effect of the parameters of the potential on the resonant state, such as the depth, width, and position of the potential well.The problem we attempt to solve is to provide a reliable and efficient method for computing the resonant state and understanding its properties in various physical systems. Our results show that the resonant state is highly sensitive to the potential parameters, and its eigenvalue and eigenfunction can be used to characterize the system. This work can contribute to the design of materials and devices that utilize resonant states, such as catalysis, superconductivity, and nanophotonics.

human_text: The resonant state of the open quantum system is studied from the viewpoint of the outgoing momentum flux. We show that the number of particles is conserved for a resonant state, if we use an expanding volume of integration in order to take account of the outgoing momentum flux; the number of particles would decay exponentially in a fixed volume of integration. Moreover, we introduce new numerical methods of treating the resonant state with the use of the effective potential. We first give a numerical method of finding a resonance pole in the complex energy plane. The method seeks an energy eigenvalue iteratively. We found that our method leads to a super-convergence, the convergence exponential with respect to the iteration step. The present method is completely independent of commonly used complex scaling. We also give a numerical trick for computing the time evolution of the resonant state in a limited spatial area. Since the wave function of the resonant state is diverging away from the scattering potential, it has been previously difficult to follow its time evolution numerically in a finite area.

human_text: On the basis of the nonisometric transformations subgroup of the SO(4.2) group, the nonlinear time inhomogeneity one-parameter conformal transformations are constructed. The connection between the group parameter and the Hubble constant H0 is established. It is shown that the existence of an anomalous blue-shifted frequency drift is a pure kinematic manifestation of the time inhomogeneity induced by the Universe expansion. This conclusion is confirmed via a generalization of the standard Special Relativity clock synchronization procedure to the space expanding case. The obtained formulae are in accordance with the observable Pioneer Anomaly effect. The anomalous blue-shifted drift is universal, does not depend on the presence of graviting centers and can be, in principle, observed on any frequencies under suitable experimental conditions. The explicit analytic expression for the speed of recession–intergalactic distance ratio is obtained in the form of a function of the red shift z valid in the whole range of its variation. In the small z limit this expression exactly reproduces the Hubble law. The maximum value of this function at z=0.475 quantitatively corresponds to the experimentally found value z(exp) = 0.46 +/- 0.13 of the transition from the decelerated to the accelerated expansion of the Universe.

machine_text: We present a study on the nonlinear dynamics of infectious diseases transfer, with possible applications for the case of tubercular infection. Our work is motivated by the problem of understanding the spread and persistence of infectious diseases in populations, which is a fundamental issue of public health. The key idea of our approach is based on the use of mathematical models that capture the dynamics of the host-pathogen interactions, taking into account the effects of demographic and environmental factors.We propose a compartmental model that accounts for the transmission of tuberculosis infection, including the possible reactivation of latent infections and the impact of drug therapy. We obtain analytical expressions for the basic reproduction number, which is a key threshold parameter that determines the conditions for the disease to persist in the population. We also perform numerical simulations of the model, which allow us to analyze the effects of different interventions strategies, such as vaccination and quarantine.Our results show that the dynamics of tuberculosis infection is highly nonlinear, exhibiting a rich variety of patterns, including periodic oscillations, complex attractors, and chaotic behavior. We discuss the implications of these findings for the control of the disease, and the development of new therapies and vaccines. Our work contributes to the growing field of mathematical epidemiology, providing insights into the complex dynamics of infectious diseases transfer.

human_text: In this paper, we model a nonlinear dynamics of infectious diseases transfer. Particularly, we study possible applications to tubercular infection in models with different profiles (peak values) of the population density dependence on spatial coordinates. Our approach is based on the well known method of instantons which has been used by the authors to describe kinetics of adiabatic chemical reactions as a function of the heat-bath temperature and other system parameters. In our approach, we use 'social temperature' T as one of the controlling parameters. Increase of T leads to acceleration of the infectious diseases transfer. The 'blockage' effect for the infectious diseases transfer has been demonstrated in the case when peak values (in the population density) are equal to one and under condition that the 'social temperature' is low. Existence of such effect essentially depends from environment 'activity' (social and prophylactic). Results of our modeling qualitatively meet the tuberculosis dynamic spread data in Penza region of Russia.

machine_text: In this work, we present a study on the ongoing galactic accretion, which is a crucial process in galaxy formation and evolution. Understanding this process is necessary to comprehend how galaxies grow and how they acquire new material to fuel the star formation. We approach this problem with simulations and observations of condensed gas in hot halos, which are reservoirs of gas surrounding galaxies. Our simulations reveal that condensed gas in halos may originate from several sources, including gas cooling, inflow, and merger events. Additionally, we find that the amount of condensed gas is significantly affected by various parameters such as halo mass, accretion rate, and AGN feedback.Furthermore, we carry out observational studies on several nearby galaxies using the Hubble Space Telescope. Our observations show that the hot halos contain cooler filaments of gas, which could be the condensed gas predicted by our simulations. These results can help us better understand how galaxies acquire new material, and ultimately, how they grow and evolve over time. Our work sheds new light on the complex process of galactic accretion and emphasizes the need for further observations and simulations to improve our understanding of it.

human_text: Ongoing accretion onto galactic disks has been recently theorized to progress via the unstable cooling of the baryonic halo into condensed clouds. These clouds have been identified as analogous to the High-Velocity Clouds (HVCs) observed in HI in our Galaxy. Here we compare the distribution of HVCs observed around our own Galaxy and extra-planar gas around the Andromeda galaxy to these possible HVC analogs in a simulation of galaxy formation that naturally generates these condensed clouds. We find a very good correspondence between these observations and the simulation, in terms of number, angular size, velocity distribution, overall flux and flux distribution of the clouds. We show that condensed cloud accretion only accounts for0.2 M_solar / year of the current overall Galactic accretion in the simulations. We also find that the simulated halo clouds accelerate and become more massive as they fall toward the disk. The parameter space of the simulated clouds is consistent with all of the observed HVC complexes that have distance constraints, except the Magellanic Stream which is known to have a different origin. We also find that nearly half of these simulated halo clouds would be indistinguishable from lower-velocity gas and that this effect is strongest further from the disk of the galaxy, thus indicating a possible missing population of HVCs. These results indicate that the majority of HVCs are consistent with being infalling, condensed clouds that are a remnant of Galaxy formation.

machine_text: The Variable Star One-shot Project (VSOP) is an ongoing initiative aimed at generating comprehensive photometric and spectroscopic data for a wide range of variable stars. In this paper, we present a summary of the project and announce the release of our first batch of data. Our major motivation is to improve our understanding of the nature of variable stars and their underlying causes, which are fundamental to a range of astrophysical studies. Our methodology involves the use of robotic telescopes that carry out multiple automated observations of a given star in a single night, allowing us to capture changes in brightness and color on short time-scales. Our first data release includes photometry and spectroscopy for 62 targets, encompassing a range of variable star types, including eclipsing binaries, pulsating stars and cataclysmic variables. We report on our findings, such as the detection of a likely outburst of an eclipsing binary, and the notable phase shifts observed in certain pulsating stars. Overall, the initial results from the VSOP project demonstrate the benefits of comprehensive monitoring of variable stars and the potential for uncovering new phenomena in the field.

human_text: The Variable Star One-shot Project (VSOP) is aimed at (1) providing the variability type and spectral type of all unstudied variable stars, (2) process, publish, and make the data available as automatically as possible, and (3) generate serendipitous discoveries. This first paper describes the project itself, the acquisition of the data, the dataflow, the spectroscopic analysis and the on-line availability of the fully calibrated and reduced data. We also present the results on the 221 stars observed during the first semester of the project. We used the high-resolution echelle spectrographs HARPS and FEROS in the ESO La Silla Observatory (Chile) to survey known variable stars. Once reduced by the dedicated pipelines, the radial velocities are determined from cross correlation with synthetic template spectra, and the spectral types are determined by an automatic minimum distance matching to synthetic spectra, with traditional manual spectral typing cross-checks. The variability types are determined by manually evaluating the available light curves and the spectroscopy. In the future, a new automatic classifier, currently being developed by members of the VSOP team, based on these spectroscopic data and on the photometric classifier developed for the COROT and Gaia space missions, will be used. We confirm or revise spectral types of 221 variable stars from the GCVS. We identify 26 previously unknown multiple systems, among them several visual binaries with spectroscopic binary individual components. We present new individual results for the multiple systems V349 Vel and BC Gru, for the composite spectrum star V4385 Sgr, for the T-Tauri star V1045 Sco, and for DM Boo which we re-classify as a BY Draconis variable. The complete data release can be accessed via the VSOP web site.

machine_text: In this work, we explore the capacity of a spiking neural network (SNN) with layered associative architecture to encode information using different neuronal firing patterns. Specifically, we investigate the effects of sparsity and density of neuronal activity on the network's ability to learn and retrieve patterns of input. Our motivation for this research comes from recent findings suggesting that biological neural networks, like the brain, use sparse coding to represent complex information effectively. However, sparse coding requires a large number of neurons to represent a given input, which may be costly in terms of metabolic resources. In contrast, dense coding uses fewer neurons but may result in more overlapping neural representations, potentially leading to interference and decreased discrimination ability.To explore these tradeoffs, we trained an SNN with a layered architecture on a set of visual stimuli and varied the sparsity and density of neuronal activity within each layer. Our results demonstrate that sparser coding improves the network's ability to discriminate between similar patterns, while denser coding is advantageous for learning and recalling diverse patterns. Interestingly, we found that intermediate levels of sparsity and density provide a balance between these competing demands and lead to the most efficient storage and retrieval of information.Overall, this work contributes to our understanding of the role of neuronal firing patterns in information processing and suggests that neural networks may benefit from dynamically adjusting the sparsity and density of their encoding based on the demands of the task.

human_text: A synfire chain is a simple neural network model which can propagate stable synchronous spikes called a pulse packet and widely researched. However how synfire chains coexist in one network remains to be elucidated. We have studied the activity of a layered associative network of Leaky Integrate-and-Fire neurons in which connection we embed memory patterns by the Hebbian Learning. We analyzed their activity by the Fokker-Planck method. In our previous report, when a half of neurons belongs to each memory pattern (memory pattern rate F=0.5), the temporal profiles of the network activity is split into temporally clustered groups called sublattices under certain input conditions. In this study, we show that when the network is sparsely connected (F<0.5), synchronous firings of the memory pattern are promoted. On the contrary, the densely connected network (F>0.5) inhibit synchronous firings. The sparseness and denseness also effect the basin of attraction and the storage capacity of the embedded memory patterns. We show that the sparsely(densely) connected networks enlarge(shrink) the basion of attraction and increase(decrease) the storage capacity.

machine_text: In this research, we investigate the dynamic effects that increase network vulnerability to cascading failures. The aim of our study is to examine how the interplay between network topology and dynamic processes can contribute to the occurrence of cascading failures. We propose a model that considers the spreading of damage in the network as well as the feedback effects that this spreading activity may create.Our methodology consists of simulations that explore the vulnerability of different network configurations under various conditions. We use a combination of measures to assess the network's robustness and identify the factors that enable the propagation of cascading failures. Moreover, we introduce a new measure called the feedback susceptibility index (FSI) that quantifies the influence of feedback effects on the propagation of damage.The motivation for this research stems from the growing dependence of modern societies on complex networks, such as power grids, transportation systems, and the internet. One of the main challenges for the management of these systems is to prevent or mitigate the impact of cascading failures that can create significant social and economic disruption. Our findings can contribute to a better understanding of the causes and consequences of cascading failures in networks, and inform the design of more resilient network structures.Our results show that network vulnerability to cascading failures increases when feedback effects are strong and when network components have high interdependence. In addition, we find that the network's resilience can be enhanced by removing critical nodes that act as sources of feedback loops. We suggest that the FSI can serve as a useful tool for network managers to assess the risk of cascading failures and plan preventive measures.

human_text: We study cascading failures in networks using a dynamical flow model based on simple conservation and distribution laws to investigate the impact of transient dynamics caused by the rebalancing of loads after an initial network failure (triggering event). It is found that considering the flow dynamics may imply reduced network robustness compared to previous static overload failure models. This is due to the transient oscillations or overshooting in the loads, when the flow dynamics adjusts to the new (remaining) network structure. We obtain upper and lower limits to network robustness, and it is shown that two time scales τ and τ_0, defined by the network dynamics, are important to consider prior to accurately addressing network robustness or vulnerability. The robustness of networks showing cascading failures is generally determined by a complex interplay between the network topology and flow dynamics, where the ratio χ=τ/τ_0 determines the relative role of the two of them.

human_text: The continuum intensity at wavelengths around 1 mm provides an excellent way to probe the solar chromosphere. Future high-resolution millimetre arrays, such as the Atacama Large Millimeter Array (ALMA), will thus produce valuable input for the ongoing controversy on the thermal structure and the dynamics of this layer. Synthetic brightness temperature maps are calculated on basis of three-dimensional radiation (magneto-)hydrodynamic (MHD) simulations. While the millimetre continuum at 0.3mm originates mainly from the upper photosphere, the longer wavelengths considered here map the low and middle chromosphere. The effective formation height increases generally with wavelength and also from disk-centre towards the solar limb. The average intensity contribution functions are usually rather broad and in some cases they are even double-peaked as there are contributions from hot shock waves and cool post-shock regions in the model chromosphere. Taking into account the deviations from ionisation equilibrium for hydrogen gives a less strong variation of the electron density and with it of the optical depth. The result is a narrower formation height range. The average brightness temperature increases with wavelength and towards the limb. The relative contrast depends on wavelength in the same way as the average intensity but decreases towards the limb. The dependence of the brightness temperature distribution on wavelength and disk-position can be explained with the differences in formation height and the variation of temperature fluctuations with height in the model atmospheres.

machine_text: In this study, we present a multiphysics modeling approach to understand the behavior of a carbon nanotube thin film field-emitting diode (CNTFED). The motivation for this research stems from the need to develop high-performance field-emission devices for applications in vacuum electronics, flat-panel displays, and advanced sensors. CNTFEDs have attracted significant attention due to their extraordinary electrical, thermal, and mechanical properties, making them an ideal candidate for field-emission applications.The key idea of this work is to understand the complex interaction between multiple physical phenomena that occur in CNTFEDs during field emission. The multiphysics approach involves the coupling of mechanical, thermal, electrical, and transport models to simulate the complete field-emission process, including the generation, transport, and collision of electrons with the CNT thin film.Our approach provides a comprehensive understanding of the CNTFED system and its key operating parameters, such as the field enhancement factor, current density, and emission properties. This understanding can lead to the development of new designs and optimization strategies for high-performance CNTFEDs. The work attempts to solve the problem of predicting the emission characteristics of CNTFEDs, which is crucial for their practical implementation.Overall, our study provides insights into the fundamental physics governing the behavior of CNTFEDs and serves as a guide for understanding the complex transport phenomena in these systems.

human_text: In this paper, we model the evolution and self-assembly of randomly oriented carbon nanotubes (CNTs), grown on a metallic substrate in the form of a thin film for field emission under diode configuration. Despite high output, the current in such a thin film device often decays drastically. The present paper is focused on understanding this problem. A systematic, multiphysics based modelling approach is proposed. First, a nucleation coupled model for degradation of the CNT thin film is derived, where the CNTs are assumed to decay by fragmentation and formation of clusters. The random orientation of the CNTs and the electromechanical interaction are then modeled to explain the self-assembly. The degraded state of the CNTs and the electromechanical force are employed to update the orientation of the CNTs. Field emission current at the device scale is finally obtained by using the Fowler-Nordheim equation and integration over the computational cell surfaces on the anode side. The simulated results are in close agreement with the experimental results. Based on the developed model, numerical simulations aimed at understanding the effects of various geometric parameters and their statistical features on the device current history are reported.

machine_text: In this study, we investigate the evolution of interstellar dust and stardust within the solar neighbourhood, a topic of fundamental importance for understanding not only the Solar System's formation but also the nature of the universe. We utilize a range of observational data to derive constraints on the properties and abundances of various interstellar dust components in the surrounding regions. These data are combined with state-of-the-art models that simulate the evolution of stardust in the interstellar medium, incorporating processes such as dust production, destruction, and transport via galactic winds. Our findings show that there are clear correlations between elemental abundances and interstellar dust properties, confirming that both dust destruction and production play a significant role in its evolution. Furthermore, we observe that the abundances of certain dust components have evolved differently from the overall metallicity of the interstellar medium, suggesting selective processing and destruction mechanisms. The results obtained from our study have broad implications for our understanding of the chemical evolution and nature of interstellar dust in the Solar System and beyond. The motivation for our work stems from the need to reconcile observations with predictions from theoretical models to form a comprehensive picture of the universe's evolution.

human_text: The abundance evolution of interstellar dust species originating from stellar sources and from condensation in molecular clouds in the local interstellar medium of the Milky Way is studied and the input of dust material to the Solar System is determined. A one-zone chemical evolution model of the Milky Way for the elemental composition of the disk combined with an evolution model for its interstellar dust component similar to that of Dwek (1998) is developed. The dust model considers dust-mass return from AGB stars as calculated from synthetic AGB models combined with models for dust condensation in stellar outflows. Supernova dust formation is included in a simple parameterized form which is gauged by observed abundances of presolar dust grains with supernova origin. For dust growth in the ISM a simple method is developed for coupling this with disk and dust evolution models. The time evolution of the abundance of the following dust species is followed in the model: silicate, carbon, silicon carbide, and iron dust from AGB stars and from SNe as well as silicate, carbon, and iron dust grown in molecular clouds. It is shown that the interstellar dust population is dominated by dust accreted in molecular clouds; most of the dust material entering the Solar System at its formation does not show isotopic abundance anomalies of the refractory elements, i.e., inconspicuous isotopic abundances do not point to a Solar System origin of dust grains. The observed abundance ratios of presolar dust grains formed in SN ejecta and in AGB star outflows requires that for the ejecta from SNe the fraction of refractory elements condensed into dust is 0.15 for carbon dust and is quite small (∼10^-4) for other dust species.

machine_text: In this work, we investigate the use of Super-Poissonian Shot Noise (SPSN) as a measure of dephasing in closed quantum dots. The motivation for this research is to better understand the dephasing process in quantum dots, which is a crucial factor in determining their functionality and feasibility for technological applications.To this end, we performed a series of high-precision measurements of SPSN in a closed quantum dot system. Our results revealed that the SPSN signals in our system were strongly influenced by external noise sources, such as fluctuations in the environment and charge noise from nearby electronic devices. Despite these challenges, we were able to extract reliable SPSN measures, which allowed us to accurately estimate the dephasing time of our system. Our findings have important implications for the development of future quantum dot-based technologies, as they provide insights into the fundamental physics of quantum dot dephasing. The problem that our work attempts to solve is the development of reliable methods for characterizing dephasing in closed quantum dots, which is a key step towards the realization of robust quantum computing and other quantum-based technologies.

human_text: Electron-electron interactions play a major role in determining the low-temperature rate of phase loss of electrons in mesoscopic systems. The study of the dephasing rate is expected to contribute to the understanding of the many-body nature of such systems. Closed quantum dots are of special interest in this respect, due to theoretical predictions suggesting a possible transition temperature below which the dephasing rate vanishes. This prediction has attracted much attention, since closed quantum dots are prime candidates for storage units in quantum computers, and thus their phase coherence properties are of great importance. However, an effective method for measuring the dephasing rate within a closed quantum dot is still lacking. Here we study two-level systems and show that the Fano factor has a sharp peak as a function of the chemical potential, the location of which can be simply related to the dephasing rate. We thus suggest to use the properties of the Fano factor peak in the super-Poissonian regime as a probe for the dephasing rate.

machine_text: In this paper, we address the problem of unambiguous coherent state identification and propose a methodology for searching quantum databases. Identifying coherent states is important for many applications in quantum information processing, such as quantum key distribution and quantum teleportation. However, due to the fundamental uncertainty principle, it is impossible to perfectly distinguish between non-orthogonal coherent states. Moreover, traditional state discrimination methods that rely on measurements may have a high error rate.To tackle this problem, we propose a novel approach that exploits the geometric structure of coherent states. Specifically, we construct a quantum database of coherent states and encode them into a quantum register. Next, we use a quantum search algorithm that relies on the Grover operator and gradients of the fidelity to efficiently locate the desired coherent state. Our method achieves an error rate that is exponentially smaller than traditional methods, and it is optimal in the sense that it saturates the quantum Cramer-Rao bound.We validate our methodology by carrying out numerical simulations and show that it outperforms other existing algorithms. Our results indicate that our approach is scalable, and it can be used in a practical setting. Our work has important implications for quantum information processing and paves the way for new applications in areas such as quantum machine learning and quantum data analysis.

human_text: We consider an unambiguous identification of an unknown coherent state with one of two unknown coherent reference states. Specifically, we consider two modes of an electromagnetic field prepared in unknown coherent states alpha_1 and alpha_2, respectively. The third mode is prepared either in the state alpha_1 or in the state alpha_2. The task is to identify (unambiguously) which of the two modes are in the same state. We present a scheme consisting of three beamsplitters capable to perform this task. Although we don't prove the optimality, we show that the performance of the proposed setup is better than the generalization of the optimal measurement known for a finite-dimensional case. We show that a single beamsplitter is capable to perform an unambiguous quantum state comparison for coherent states optimally. Finally we propose an experimental setup consisting of 2N-1 beamsplitters for unambiguous identification among N unknown coherent states. This setup can be considered as a search in a quantum database. The elements of the database are unknown coherent states encoded in different modes of an electromagnetic field. The task is to specify the two modes that are excited in the same, though unknown, coherent state.

machine_text: In this paper, we present the results of an extrasolar planet census conducted using a space-based microlensing survey. Our main objective was to estimate the number of exoplanets and their distribution in the Milky Way. To achieve this, we analyzed microlensing events that occurred between 2015 and 2018, using data collected by the Korean Microlensing Telescope (KMTNet) and the Spitzer Space Telescope. We identified a total of 396 microlensing events, out of which 45 were caused by planets, with masses ranging from Earth-like planets to Jupiter-like gas giants. Our analysis resulted in the detection of 27 planets, including 5 ultra-short-period planets, 14 super-Earths, and 8 planets with masses equivalent to Neptune or larger. Additionally, our survey allowed us to find a planet orbiting a low-mass star, which is a rare discovery.We found that the frequency of planets increases with decreasing mass, and we estimated the occurrence of planets in the Milky Way to be 0.51 planets per star. Our results also suggest that a significant fraction of rocky planets with masses similar to Earth occupy orbits that are too close to their host star to support life. This study provides an important contribution to the field of exoplanets and lays the groundwork for future surveys, which will allow us to delve deeper into the characterization of exoplanets and their environments.

Our main objective was to estimate the number of exoplanets and their distribution in the Milky Way, which we were able to achieve by analyzing microlensing events that occurred between 2015 and 2018, using data collected by the Korean Microlensing Telescope (KMTNet) and the Spitzer Space Telescope; however, this was not done without first identifying a total of 396 microlensing events, out of which 45 were caused by planets, with masses ranging from Earth-like planets to Jupiter-like gas giants that we had previously detected. We found that these planets were detected using our analysis, which resulted in the detection of 27 planets, including 5 ultra-short-period planets, 14 super-Earths, and 8 planets with masses equivalent to Neptune or larger; in addition, this survey allowed us to find a planet orbiting a low-mass star, which was a rare discovery. Furthermore, we were able to estimate the occurrence of planets in the Milky Way to be 0.51 planets per star, and our results also suggested that a significant fraction of rocky planets with masses similar to Earth occupied orbits that were too close to their host star to support life.
human_text: A space-based gravitational microlensing exoplanet survey will provide a statistical census of exoplanets with masses down to 0.1 Earth-masses and orbital separations ranging from 0.5AU to infinity. This includes analogs to all the Solar System's planets except for Mercury, as well as most types of planets predicted by planet formation theories. Such a survey will provide results on the frequency of planets around all types of stars except those with short lifetimes. Close-in planets with separations < 0.5 AU are invisible to a space-based microlensing survey, but these can be found by Kepler. Other methods, including ground-based microlensing, cannot approach the comprehensive statistics on the mass and semi-major axis distribution of extrasolar planets that a space-based microlensing survey will provide. The terrestrial planet sensitivity of a ground-based microlensing survey is limited to the vicinity of the Einstein radius at 2-3 AU, and space-based imaging is needed to identify and determine the mass of the planetary host stars for the vast majority of planets discovered by microlensing. Thus, a space-based microlensing survey is likely to be the only way to gain a comprehensive understanding of the nature of planetary systems, which is needed to understand planet formation and habitability. The proposed Microlensing Planet Finder (MPF) mission is an example of a space-based microlensing survey that can accomplish these objectives with proven technology and a cost that fits comfortably under the NASA Discovery Program cost cap.

machine_text: We present the results of a novel approach to investigating high redshift damped Lyman-alpha (DLA) galaxies using integral field spectroscopy. This method allows for the simultaneous measurement of both spatial and spectral information, providing a rich dataset for detailed analysis. Our aim was to study the physical properties and environments of these galaxies, which are known to be important in the formation and evolution of galaxies.We selected a sample of 24 DLA galaxies at redshifts between 2 and 4 using a combination of imaging and spectroscopic data. We then performed observations using the Gemini Multi-Object Spectrograph (GMOS) on the Gemini North telescope, using a custom-designed set of slits to cover the entire galaxy. The resulting dataset included spectra of H-alpha, [NII], [SII], and [OIII] emission lines, which allowed us to determine key properties such as star formation rates, metallicity, and the presence of active galactic nuclei.Our analysis revealed a diverse set of galaxy properties, including high star formation rates, low metallicities, and the presence of outflows and multiple kinematic components. We also found evidence for the coexistence of both star-forming and quiescent regions within individual galaxies. These results provide valuable insights into the formation and evolution of galaxies at high redshifts and demonstrate the power of integral field spectroscopy in unraveling their complex physical processes.
