human_text: We search for galaxy counterparts to damped Lyman-alpha absorbers (DLAs) at z>2 towards nine quasars, which have 14 DLAs and 8 sub-DLAs in their spectra. We use integral field spectroscopy to search for Ly-alpha emission line objects at the redshifts of the absorption systems. Besides recovering two previously confirmed objects, we find six statistically significant candidate Ly-alpha emission line objects. The candidates are identified as having wavelengths close to the DLA line where the background quasar emission is absorbed. In comparison with the six currently known Ly-alpha emitting DLA galaxies the candidates have similar line fluxes and line widths, while velocity offsets between the emission lines and systemic DLA redshifts are larger. The impact parameters are larger than 10 kpc, and lower column density systems are found at larger impact parameters. Assuming that a single gas cloud extends from the QSO line of sight to the location of the candidate emission line, we find that the average candidate DLA galaxy is surrounded by neutral gas with an exponential scale length of5 kpc.

machine_text: Our work aims to provide a detailed kinetic study of the ring opening of cycloalkanes, which is a fundamental step in the preparation of various organic chemicals. However, the reaction mechanism of this process is still debated and its kinetics remain poorly understood. To solve this problem, we performed CBS-QB3 calculations, which are considered highly accurate for computing reaction energies and rates, to investigate the ring opening of cycloalkanes.Our key idea was to use computational methods to uncover the reaction mechanism and rate constants of this important organic transformation. We first performed systematic scans of the potential energy surface of ring opening reactions in different cycloalkanes, including cyclobutane, cyclopentane, and cyclohexane, and identified the rate-determining step and other important intermediates. We then calculated the rate constants using transition state theory and examined the effects of different solvents, temperatures, and substituents on the reaction rates.The motivation for our research is twofold. On one hand, a detailed understanding of the reaction kinetics can help optimize the process parameters and design better catalysts for the ring opening of cycloalkanes, which is a crucial step in the production of polymers, fuels, and pharmaceuticals. On the other hand, our study provides a theoretical benchmark for future experimental investigations of this reaction, and offers insights into the general principles governing the reactivity of cyclic molecules.

human_text: This work reports a theoretical study of the gas phase unimolecular decomposition of cyclobutane, cyclopentane and cyclohexane by means of quantum chemical calculations. A biradical mechanism has been envisaged for each cycloalkane, and the main routes for the decomposition of the biradicals formed have been investigated at the CBS-QB3 level of theory. Thermochemical data (δH^0_f, S^0, C^0_p) for all the involved species have been obtained by means of isodesmic reactions. The contribution of hindered rotors has also been included. Activation barriers of each reaction have been analyzed to assess the 1 energetically most favorable pathways for the decomposition of biradicals. Rate constants have been derived for all elementary reactions using transition state theory at 1 atm and temperatures ranging from 600 to 2000 K. Global rate constant for the decomposition of the cyclic alkanes in molecular products have been calculated. Comparison between calculated and experimental results allowed to validate the theoretical approach. An important result is that the rotational barriers between the conformers, which are usually neglected, are of importance in decomposition rate of the largest biradicals. Ring strain energies (RSE) in transition states for ring opening have been estimated and show that the main part of RSE contained in the cyclic reactants is removed upon the activation process.

machine_text: In this paper, we investigate the magnetic fluctuations in n-type high-T_c superconductors to understand the breakdown of fermiology. We first introduce the concept of fermiology, which describes the electronic structures of materials and their relation to their physical properties. However, our findings suggest that this concept may not properly describe the electronic structure of n-type high-T_c superconductors.We conducted our investigation through neutron scattering experiments on a variety of samples. Our methodology allowed us to directly measure the magnetic fluctuations, which are intimately linked to the electronic structure of superconductors. Our experiments showed that the magnetic fluctuations in n-type high-T_c superconductors are significantly different from those predicted by fermiology. Specifically, we observed that the fluctuations are spatially uniform and very weak throughout the sample, in contrast to the expected localized and strong fluctuations.Our results suggest that the breakdown of fermiology in n-type high-T_c superconductors may be due to the presence of a new type of electronic state, rather than a deviation from the conventional fermiology. This has important implications for our understanding of high-T_c superconductors, as well as for the development of future superconducting materials.

human_text: By combining experimental measurements of the quasiparticle and dynamical magnetic properties of optimally electron-doped Pr_0.88LaCe_0.12CuO_4 with theoretical calculations we demonstrate that the conventional fermiology approach cannot possibly account for the magnetic fluctuations in these materials. In particular, we perform tunneling experiments on the very same sample for which a dynamical magnetic resonance has been reported recently and use photoemission data by others on a similar sample to characterize the fermionic quasiparticle excitations in great detail. We subsequently use this information to calculate the magnetic response within the conventional fermiology framework as applied in a large body of work for the hole-doped superconductors to find a profound disagreement between the theoretical expectations and the measurements: this approach predicts a step-like feature rather than a sharp resonance peak, it underestimates the intensity of the resonance by an order of magnitude, it suggests an unreasonable temperature dependence of the resonance, and most severely, it predicts that most of the spectral weight resides in incommensurate wings which are a key feature of the hole-doped cuprates but have never been observed in the electron-doped counterparts. Our findings strongly suggest that the magnetic fluctuations reflect the quantum-mechanical competition between antiferromagnetic and superconducting orders.

machine_text: In this paper, we propose a novel tool for seismologists, the Cumulative Spectral Power (CSP). Our motivation for this research stems from the inadequacy of current methods in identifying small earthquakes buried within noise and larger earthquakes. The CSP is designed to assist in readjusting a dataset in such a way that it highlights the frequency content of small earthquakes and at the same time dampens the frequency content of larger earthquakes and noise. The key idea of this new tool is that it enforces the idea that small earthquakes within a given frequency band can reveal substantive information about the subsurface structure of the Earth. The CSP is created using a moving time window and a cumulative distribution function of the spectral power. Our primary methodology for testing the effectiveness of the CSP is through numerical simulations and field data analysis, which shows that CSP can significantly improve the detection of small earthquakes. We anticipate that this new tool will be critical in unraveling the Earth's subsurface structures and aid seismologists in image reconstruction and monitoring earthquake activity.

human_text: The power spectral density (PSD) function is commonly used to specify seismometer performance. It is derived from the FFT of acceleration and correction is made for the transfer function of the instrument that generated the data. As with any such spectrum of density (`per Hz') type, the noise inherent to a PSD is large. This article illustrates the value of a function that is derived from the PSD and for which the influence of noise is significantly reduced. Called the cumulative spectral power (CSP), it is obtained from the PSD through the noise-reducing process of integration. The maximum of the CSP (corresponding to the longest graphed value of the period) provides a means for estimating the total vibrational power of the earth. The present author has significantly simplified the process of PSD generation. Thus routine graphing is straightforwared-of first the FFT, followed by the generation of both a PSD and its associated CSP. The unique properties of the CSP make it valuable for the study of a variety of earth dynamics. For example, the strking simplicity of a CSP graph generated from a record containing a strong teleseismic earthquake is undoubtedly important to the development and refinement of any viable theory of earthquake dynamics.

machine_text: We present a novel approach in addressing the long-standing problem of calculating scattering amplitudes in strongly coupled (N=4) super Yang-Mills theory via semiclassical strings in anti-de Sitter (AdS) spacetime. Our study aims to provide a deeper understanding of the holographic correspondence between the strongly coupled gauge theory and the weakly coupled gravitational theory in AdS/CFT, which is of utmost importance in developing a complete theory of quantum gravity.Using the formalism of the twistor-string theory, we derive a twistor-space representation of the semiclassical string partition function in AdS. By computing the semiclassical three-point amplitude of scattering states in AdS, we demonstrate the consistency of our approach with the standard CFT correlator calculation in the planar limit. Furthermore, we accurately verify the correspondence of semiclassical strings with the all-loop amplitudes in the gauge theory.Our work significantly advances the understanding of the AdS/CFT correspondence and provides new insights into the nature of string theory and quantum gravity. The methodology, based on the twistor-string formalism, opens new avenues for exploring string theory and gauge theory and lays the groundwork for future research in these fields.

human_text: Very recently in arXiv:0705.0303 Alday and Maldacena gave a string theory prescription for computing (all) planar amplitudes in N=4 supersymmetric gauge theory at strong coupling using the AdS/CFT correspondence. These amplitudes are determined by a classical string solution and contain a universal exponential factor involving the action of the classical string. On the gauge theory side, expressions for perturbative amplitudes at strong coupling were previously proposed only for specific helicities of external particles – the maximally helicity violating or MHV amplitudes. These follow from the exponential ansatz of Bern, Dixon and Smirnov for MHV amplitudes in N=4 SYM. In this paper we examine the amplitudes dependence on helicities and particle-types of external states. We consider the prefactor of string amplitudes and give arguments suggesting that the prefactor at strong coupling should be the same as the Yang-Mills tree-level amplitude for the same process. This implies that scattering amplitudes in N=4 SYM simplify dramatically in the strong coupling limit. It follows from our proposal that in this limit all (MHV and non-MHV) n-point amplitudes are given by the (known) tree-level Yang-Mills result times the helicity-independent (and particle-type-independent) universal exponential.

machine_text: In this study, we investigate the mass loss from Luminous Blue Variables (LBVs) and the quasi-periodic modulations of radio supernovae (SNe). Large-scale mass loss is a defining characteristic of LBVs, which are evolved, massive, and hot stars. However, the mechanism behind such mass loss is yet to be clarified. Moreover, the recent detection of quasi-periodic modulations of radio emission from SNe poses a challenge in understanding the underlying physical process. Therefore, we aim to address these issues by analyzing multi-epoch radio data from a sample of LBVs and SNe using time-frequency analysis techniques.Our analysis demonstrates a complex and variable mass loss process among the LBV sample, indicating that different mechanisms could be involved. We find evidence of periodic oscillations in some of the radio SNe, which could be due to the interaction of SN ejecta with a circumstellar medium, implying that SNe may possess a distinct periodic modality. The findings from our study provide significant insights into the mass loss mechanisms from LBVs and the physical causes of the quasi-periodic modulations of SNe.The motivation for our research lies in the crucial role that LBVs and SNe play in astrophysical processes, such as the synthesis of heavy elements and the formation of black holes. Understanding the mass loss processes and the physical mechanisms driving SNe's radio emission can lead to a better understanding of these fundamental astrophysical phenomena.

human_text: Massive stars, supernovae (SNe), and long-duration gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) have a huge impact on their environment. Despite their importance, a comprehensive knowledge of which massive stars produce which SN/GRB is hitherto lacking. We present a brief overview about our knowledge of mass loss in the Hertzsprung-Russell Diagram (HRD) covering evolutionary phases of the OB main sequence, the unstable Luminous Blue Variable (LBV) stage, and the Wolf-Rayet (WR) phase. Despite the fact that metals produced by “self-enrichment” in WR atmospheres exceed the initial – host galaxy – metallicity, by orders of magnitude, a particularly strong dependence of the mass-loss rate on the initial metallicity is found for WR stars at sub-solar metallicities (1/10 – 1/100 solar). This provides a significant boost to the collapsar model for GRBs, as it may present a viable mechanism to prevent the loss of angular momentum by stellar winds at low metallicity, whilst strong Galactic WR winds may inhibit GRBs occurring at solar metallicities. Furthermore, we discuss recently reported quasi-sinusoidal modulations in the radio lightcurves of SNe 2001ig and 2003bg. We show that both the sinusoidal behaviour and the recurrence timescale of these modulations are consistent with the predicted mass-loss behaviour of LBVs, and we suggest LBVs may be the progenitors of some core-collapse SNe.

Therefore, understanding quantum Hall ferromagnetism in graphene is a critical step towards exploring its potential applications in spintronics. human_text: We study the quantum Hall effect in graphene at filling factors ν= 0 and ν= ±, concentrating on the quantum Hall ferromagnetic regime, within a non-perturbative bosonization formalism. We start by developing a bosonization scheme for electrons with two discrete degrees of freedom (spin-1/2 and pseudospin-1/2) restricted to the lowest Landau level. Three distinct phases are considered, namely the so-called spin-pseudospin, spin, and pseudospin phases. The first corresponds to a quarter-filled (ν=-1) while the others to a half-filled (ν= 0) lowest Landau level. In each case, we show that the elementary neutral excitations can be treated approximately as a set of n-independent kinds of boson excitations. The boson representation of the projected electron density, the spin, pseudospin, and mixed spin-pseudospin density operators are derived. We then apply the developed formalism to the effective continuous model, which includes SU(4) symmetry breaking terms, recently proposed by Alicea and Fisher. For each quantum Hall state, an effective interacting boson model is derived and the dispersion relations of the elementary excitations are analytically calculated. We propose that the charged excitations (quantum Hall skyrmions) can be described as a coherent state of bosons. We calculate the semiclassical limit of the boson model derived from the SU(4) invariant part of the original fermionic Hamiltonian and show that it agrees with the results of Arovas and co-workers for SU(N) quantum Hall skyrmions. We briefly discuss the influence of the SU(4) symmetry breaking terms in the skyrmion energy.

machine_text: In this work, we present constraints on the heavy element abundance in the solar interior through the analysis of frequency separation ratios of low-degree p modes. The heavy element abundance is important for understanding the formation and the evolution of stars, as well as the nucleosynthesis of elements. Previous studies have shown that the solar heavy element abundance is difficult to determine, as it is affected by uncertainties in the input physics used in the solar models and by the limited accuracy of solar observations. In this work, we use the frequency separation ratios of low-degree p modes to reduce the uncertainties in the input physics of the solar models, and to probe the solar heavy element abundance with greater precision.We analyze p modes that are observed by the Solar Dynamics Observatory, and we use an asteroseismic approach to determine the frequency separation ratios. We then use a Bayesian analysis to infer the heavy element abundance from the frequency separation ratios. Our analysis suggests that the solar heavy element abundance is lower than what is predicted by the standard solar model. Our results are consistent with recent studies that indicate a lower heavy element abundance in the solar atmosphere. The methodology presented in this work can be applied to other solar-like stars to improve our understanding of their internal structure and chemical properties.

machine_text: In this paper, we present a study of GLSM's for partial flag manifolds. The partial flag variety is a class of algebraic varieties that plays a central role in algebraic geometry and representation theory. Our goal is to develop a framework for constructing gauge theories that live on these manifolds using the tools of Geometric Langlands-Siegel Modularity (GLSM) theories. The main advantage of GLSM's is that they provide a way to relate geometry and representation theory through modular forms.To achieve our goal, we first describe the geometry of partial flag manifolds and review the theory of GLSM's. We then develop a general method to construct GLSM's for partial flag manifolds using a combination of representation theory, algebraic geometry, and modular forms. Our methodology involves studying the moduli space of stable sheaves on the partial flag manifold and constructing a Hilbert scheme for it. The Hilbert scheme is a moduli space of subschemes of the partial flag manifold that takes into account the stability condition of the sheaves.One of the key ideas behind our work is that the modularity of GLSM's can be used to study the geometry of partial flag manifolds. This has important implications in representation theory and mathematical physics. Our motivation for this research lies in the desire to further understand the relationship between algebraic geometry, representation theory, and modular forms, and to develop new tools for studying moduli spaces and gauge theories.

human_text: In this paper we outline some aspects of nonabelian gauged linear sigma models. First, we review how partial flag manifolds (generalizing Grassmannians) are described physically by nonabelian gauged linear sigma models, paying attention to realizations of tangent bundles and other aspects pertinent to (0,2) models. Second, we review constructions of Calabi-Yau complete intersections within such flag manifolds, and properties of the gauged linear sigma models. We discuss a number of examples of nonabelian GLSM's in which the Kahler phases are not birational, and in which at least one phase is realized in some fashion other than as a complete intersection, extending previous work of Hori-Tong. We also review an example of an abelian GLSM exhibiting the same phenomenon. We tentatively identify the mathematical relationship between such non-birational phases, as examples of Kuznetsov's homological projective duality. Finally, we discuss linear sigma model moduli spaces in these gauged linear sigma models. We argue that the moduli spaces being realized physically by these GLSM's are precisely Quot and hyperquot schemes, as one would expect mathematically.

machine_text: In this work, we investigate the capacity gain achievable through two-transmitter and two-receiver cooperation in wireless communication systems. We develop a cooperative communication scheme called relay beamforming (RBF), designed to maximize the performance of such a system.Our results show that the RBF technique outperforms traditional techniques, such as dual-hop relay (DHR), by increasing the joint capacity of the dual-hop system while satisfying the power budget constraint in each hop. We also compare the RBF scheme with other cooperative techniques such as distributed beamforming (DBF) and amplify-and-forward (AF) schemes, and our results show that RBF outperforms these techniques in terms of capacity.Our methodology is based on the concept of joint signal-to-noise ratio (JSNR) maximization, which leads to the design of an optimal power allocation strategy for the RBF scheme. The RBF protocol relies on the use of two transmitters, one relay, and two receivers, with each transmitter and receiver equipped with two antennas.Our motivation for this research is the need to enhance the capacity of wireless communication systems, which is an essential requirement for future wireless networks, given the increasing demand for high data rates and the limited availability of the radio spectrum. Our proposed RBF technique provides a new solution for boosting network capacity by exploiting the benefits of multi-antenna systems and cooperative communication in a dual-hop configuration.

human_text: Capacity improvement from transmitter and receiver cooperation is investigated in a two-transmitter, two-receiver network with phase fading and full channel state information available at all terminals. The transmitters cooperate by first exchanging messages over an orthogonal transmitter cooperation channel, then encoding jointly with dirty paper coding. The receivers cooperate by using Wyner-Ziv compress-and-forward over an analogous orthogonal receiver cooperation channel. To account for the cost of cooperation, the allocation of network power and bandwidth among the data and cooperation channels is studied. It is shown that transmitter cooperation outperforms receiver cooperation and improves capacity over non-cooperative transmission under most operating conditions when the cooperation channel is strong. However, a weak cooperation channel limits the transmitter cooperation rate; in this case receiver cooperation is more advantageous. Transmitter-and-receiver cooperation offers sizable additional capacity gain over transmitter-only cooperation at low SNR, whereas at high SNR transmitter cooperation alone captures most of the cooperative capacity improvement.

machine_text: In this study, we investigate the radiative transfer effect on ultraviolet (UV) pumping of the 21cm line in the high-redshift Universe. The main objective is to elucidate the impact of the UV background radiation on the excitation of the hyperfine levels of hydrogen. The primary motivation is to understand the properties of the intergalactic medium (IGM) at high redshift, especially the epoch of reionization.Our results show that the UV background radiation suppresses the collisional excitation of the 21cm line by damping the Lyman-alpha radiation that couples the hyperfine levels. This effect reduces the brightness temperature of the 21cm line and affects the spin temperature of hydrogen. Also, we have found that the radiative transfer effect depends on the density and temperature of the IGM, and it is more pronounced in the optically thin regions.To obtain these results, we have used a Monte Carlo radiative transfer code that simulates the propagation of the UV background radiation through the IGM and calculates the level populations and line emissivities of hydrogen. This code has been coupled with a cosmological hydrodynamic simulation that provides the density and temperature distributions of the IGM.In summary, our work highlights the important role of the UV background radiation in shaping the properties of the IGM during the epoch of reionization and demonstrates the need for including the radiative transfer effect in the analysis of future 21cm observational data.

human_text: During the epoch of reionization the 21cm signal is sensitive to the scattering rate of the ultraviolet photons, redshifting across the Lyman_alpha resonance. Here we calculate the photon scattering rate profile for a single ultraviolet source. After taking into account previously neglected natural broadening of the resonance line, we find that photons approach the resonance frequency and experience most scatterings at a significantly smaller distance from the source than naively expected r=(dnu/nu_0)(c/H), where dnu=nu-nu_0 is the initial frequency offset, and the discrepancy increases as the initial frequency offset decreases. As a consequence, the scattering rate P(r) drops much faster with increasing distance than the previously assumed 1/r^2 profile. Near the source (r<1Mpc comoving), the scattering rate of photons that redshift into the Ly_alpha resonance converges to P(r) ∝r^-7/3. The scattering rate of Ly_alpha photons produced by splitting of photons that redshift into a higher resonance (Ly_gamma, Ly_delta, etc.) is only weakly affected by the radiative transfer, while the sum of scattering rates of Ly_alpha photons produced from all higher resonances also converges to P(r) ∝r^-7/3 near the source. At 15<z<35, on scales of0.01-20Mpc/h (comoving), the total scattering rate of Ly_alpha photons from all Lyman resonances is found to be higher by a factor of1+0.3[(1+z)/20]^2/3 than obtained without full radiative transfer. Consequently, during the early stage of reionization, the differential brightness of 21cm signal against the cosmic microwave background is also boosted by a similar factor.

machine_text: In this study, we present a panoramic view of the formation of the Andromeda and Triangulum galaxies by exploring their halo structures. Our analysis reveals intricate networks of stellar streams and satellite galaxies which provide insight into the hierarchical formation of these galaxies in the dark matter halos. We use wide-field photometry data from the Pan-Andromeda Archaeological Survey (PAndAS) and the Next Generation Virgo Cluster Survey (NGVS) to identify and map the halo structures of Andromeda and Triangulum. We then utilize this dataset to construct galactic-scale simulations to better understand the formation and evolution of these galaxies over time.Our work seeks to tackle the longstanding problem of understanding how galaxies like Andromeda and Triangulum form and evolve. By characterizing the halo structures and satellite galaxies surrounding these galaxies, we aim to provide insight into the underlying physical processes responsible for their formation and evolution.We are motivated by the growing understanding of the importance of galaxy interactions and mergers in shaping the properties of galaxies across cosmic time. Our findings suggest that galaxy formation is a complex interplay between dark matter halos, the gas that falls into them, and the feedback mechanisms that regulate star formation within them. Our study provides important insights into the process of galaxy formation, and will lay the foundation for future work in the field.

human_text: We present a deep photometric survey of M31, conducted with the CFHT and INT, covering the inner 50 kpc of the galaxy, the Southern quadrant out to 150 kpc, and extending to M33. This is the first systematic panoramic study of this very outermost region of galaxies. We detect several streams and other large-scale structures, and two new dwarf galaxies: And XV and XVI. The discovery of substructure on the minor axis, together with the fact that the light profile between 0.5 < R < 1.3 follows the exponential “extended disk”, is particularly important in shedding light on the mixed and sometimes conflicting results reported in previous studies. Underlying the substructures lies a faint, metal-poor, smooth and extremely extended halo, reaching out to at least 150 kpc. The smooth halo component in M31 has a profile that can be fit with a Hernquist model of immense scale radius55 kpc, almost a factor of 4 larger than theoretical predictions. Alternatively a power-law with exponent -1.91 +/- 0.11 can be fit to the profile. The total luminosity of this structure is similar to that of the halo of the Milky Way. This vast, smooth, underlying halo is reminiscent of a classical monolithic model and completely unexpected from modern galaxy formation models. M33 is also found to have an extended metal-poor halo component, which can be fit with a Hernquist model also of scale radius55 kpc. These extended slowly-decreasing halos will provide a challenge and strong constraints for further modeling. [Abridged]

machine_text: We present an expansion for self-interacting random walks, which extends the existing formalism in several ways. The motivation for this research has been an increased interest in modeling complex systems, where the interaction between agents is crucial. In particular, we focus on random walks with a long-range interaction, where the probability of moving to a given site depends on the coordinates of all particles in the system, following a power-law distance dependence. While these models have been widely studied in the past, our expansion provides a new tool for computing the moments of the distribution, which can be of crucial importance in many applications.Our expansion is based on the generalization of the Baker-Campbell-Hausdorff formula, which allows us to take into account the higher-order contributions to the evolution of the system. We show that the resulting expression can be expressed in terms of multiple integrals, which require numerical methods to be computed. We compare our results with Monte Carlo simulations, finding excellent agreement in all cases. Finally, we apply our expansion to some relevant examples of self-interacting random walks, such as models of polymer chains or random coalescence, obtaining novel insights into their behavior.Our work contributes to the ongoing effort of developing effective tools for modeling complex systems, where self-interaction plays a fundamental role. We believe that our expansion can be applied to many other models beyond self-interacting random walks, opening new avenues for research in theoretical physics and beyond.

human_text: We derive a perturbation expansion for general self-interacting random walks, where steps are made on the basis of the history of the path. Examples of models where this expansion applies are reinforced random walk, excited random walk, the true (weakly) self-avoiding walk, loop-erased random walk, and annealed random walk in random environment.In this paper we show that the expansion gives rise to useful formulae for the speed and variance of the random walk, when these quantities are known to exist. The results and formulae of this paper have been used elsewhere by the authors to prove monotonicity properties for the speed (in high dimensions) of excited random walk and related models, and certain models of random walk in random environment.We also derive a law of large numbers and central limit theorem (with explicit error terms) directly from this expansion, under strong assumptions on the expansion coefficients. The assumptions are shown to be satisfied by excited random walk in high dimensions with small excitation parameter, a model of reinforced random walk with underlying drift and small reinforcement parameter, and certain models of random walk in random environment under strong ellipticity conditions. This is the extended version of the paper, where we provide all proofs.

machine_text: In this paper, we present the X-ray spectrum of the Broad-Line Radio Galaxy (BLRG) 3C 445, obtained with the Chandra X-ray Observatory. This remarkable spectrum shows a prominent excess at energies above 4 keV, which can be modeled by a broad Gaussian line centered at 6.7 keV, a prominent iron K-alpha line. This feature is characteristic of reflection from cold, dense matter in the vicinity of a supermassive black hole and indicates the presence of a Compton-thick torus in 3C 445. Moreover, we detect two narrow lines at 6.4 keV and 6.7 keV, which are consistent with Fe K-alpha fluorescence and Fe XXV He-like line emission, respectively.The motivation for this research is to understand the nature and properties of the X-ray emission from BLRGs, which is still not well understood. BLRGs are a subclass of radio-loud active galactic nuclei (AGN), which show strong and broad emission lines in their optical spectra. Understanding the relationship between the optical and X-ray emission in these objects is crucial to understand their physical processes and to use them as probes of the evolution of AGN across cosmic time.The problem this work attempts to solve is to provide clear evidence for the presence of a Compton-thick torus in BLRGs, which has previously been suggested by models and indirect observations. Our Chandra observations of 3C 445 allow us to confirm this hypothesis and to discuss the implications for the properties of the black hole accretion flow and the AGN environment.

human_text: We present the results of the analysis of an archival 15 ks XMM-Newton observation of the nearby (z=0.057) radio-loud source 3C445, optically classified as a Broad-Line Radio Galaxy. While the RGS data are of insufficient quality to allow a meaningful analysis, the EPIC data show a remarkable X-ray spectrum. The 2-10 keV continuum is described by a heavily absorbed (Nh1e22 - 1e23 cm-2) power law with photon index Gamma1.4, and strong (R 2) cold reflection. A narrow, unresolved Fe Kalpha emission line is detected, confirming previous findings, with EW 120eV. A soft excess is present below 2 keV over the extrapolation of the hard X-ray power law, which we model with a power law with the same photon index as the hard power law, absorbed by a column density Nh=6e20 cm-2 in excess to Galactic. A host of emission lines are present below 2 keV, confirming previous indications from ASCA, due to H- and He-like O, Mg, and Si. We attribute the origin of the lines to a photoionized gas, with properties very similar to radio-quiet obscured AGN. Two different ionized media, or a single stratified medium, are required to fit the soft X-ray data satisfactorily. The similarity of the X-ray spectrum of 3C445 to Seyferts underscores that the central engines of radio-loud and radio-quiet AGN similarly host both cold and warm gas.

machine_text: In this study, we present efficient simulations of early structure formation and reionization, aimed at investigating the key physical processes that shaped the high-redshift Universe. Our work attempts to solve the computational challenge posed by the need for large-scale simulations that capture the complex interplay between gravity, hydrodynamics, radiative transfer, and non-equilibrium chemistry. The key innovation of our approach is a hybrid technique that combines particle-based N-body simulations with grid-based hydrodynamics and radiative transfer solvers. This hybrid approach allows us to accurately follow the formation of the first galaxies and the reionization of the intergalactic medium, while also maximizing computational efficiency.Our simulations show that the early Universe was a highly dynamic and evolving system, with the first stars and galaxies appearing by redshifts as early as 20. Our results shed light on the role of feedback processes, such as supernovae explosions and ionizing radiation, in regulating the formation of structures and driving the reionization of the Universe. Moreover, our simulations enable us to make predictions for a range of observables, such as the 21-cm signal, that can be used to test cosmological models and constrain the properties of dark matter and dark energy. Our study thus provides a powerful tool for exploring the physics of the early Universe and its observational signatures.

human_text: We present a method to construct semi-numerical “simulations”, which can efficiently generate realizations of halo distributions and ionization maps at high redshifts. Our procedure combines an excursion-set approach with first-order Lagrangian perturbation theory and operates directly on the linear density and velocity fields. As such, the achievable dynamic range with our algorithm surpasses the current practical limit of N-body codes by orders of magnitude. This is particularly significant in studies of reionization, where the dynamic range is the principal limiting factor. We test our halo-finding and HII bubble-finding algorithms independently against N-body simulations with radiative transfer and obtain excellent agreement. We compute the size distributions of ionized and neutral regions in our maps. We find even larger ionized bubbles than do purely analytic models at the same volume-weighted mean hydrogen neutral fraction. We also generate maps and power spectra of 21-cm brightness temperature fluctuations, which for the first time include corrections due to gas bulk velocities. We find that velocities widen the tails of the temperature distributions and increase small-scale power, though these effects quickly diminish as reionization progresses. We also include some preliminary results from a simulation run with the largest dynamic range to date: a 250 Mpc box that resolves halos with masses M >2.2 x10^8 M_sun. We show that accurately modeling the late stages of reionization requires such large scales. The speed and dynamic range provided by our semi-numerical approach will be extremely useful in the modeling of early structure formation and reionization.

machine_text: In this work, we present an investigation of the properties and possible evolution of the HD 98800 protoplanetary disk. This system is known to host four, possibly five, young stars. Our analysis is based on new ALMA observations, which allowed us to resolve two concentric rings in the disk, with estimated radii of 52 and 85 au. We find that the inner ring is optically thin and the outer ring is optically thick, with a gap in between. These characteristics indicate that HD 98800 is a transition disk, suggesting the possibility of ongoing planet formation.Given that HD 98800 is relatively young, with an estimated age of 10 million years, our study provides a unique opportunity to investigate the earliest stages of planet formation. We also analyse the possible mechanisms responsible for the formation of the gap, concluding that it is the result of dynamical interaction with a massive body. Overall, our results provide valuable insights into the early stages of planet formation and the evolution of protoplanetary disks. These findings highlight the potential of ALMA observations to continue advancing our understanding of planet formation.

human_text: We present the mid-infrared spectrum, obtained with the Spitzer Infrared Spectrograph (IRS), of HD 98800, a quadruple star system located in the 10-Myr-old TW Hydrae association. It has a known mid-infrared excess that arises from a circumbinary disk around the B components of the system. The IRS spectrum confirms that the disk around HD 98800 B displays no excess emission below about 5.5 micron, implying an optically thick disk wall at 5.9 AU and an inner, cleared-out region; however, some optically thin dust, consisting mainly of 3-micron-sized silicate dust grains, orbits the binary in a ring between 1.5 and 2 AU. The peculiar structure and apparent lack of gas in the HD 98800 B disk suggests that this system is likely already at the debris disks stage, with a tidally truncated circumbinary disk of larger dust particles and an inner, second-generation dust ring, possibly held up by the resonances of a planet. The unusually large infrared excess can be explained by gravitational perturbations of the Aa+Ab pair puffing up the outer dust ring and causing frequent collisions among the larger particles.

machine_text: Our study focused on investigating the electron-phonon coupling in doped graphene by investigating the impact of an electronic singularity. The motivation for this research stems from the unique properties of graphene including high electrical conductivity, mechanical strength, and large surface area, leading to its potential applications in various fields such as electronics, energy storage, and biomedical applications. However, the electron-phonon coupling in graphene has been a topic of interest due to its importance in determining the electrical and thermal properties of the material.Our research found that the presence of an electronic singularity in doped graphene massively enhances the electron-phonon coupling, leading to a significant increase in the electron energy relaxation rate. This effect was demonstrated through first-principles calculations using density functional theory. The results obtained from this study highlight the potential use of electronic singularities in enhancing the electron-phonon coupling and thus manipulating the electrical and thermal properties of graphene.The problem we aimed to solve through this research was the identification of an efficient method to enhance electron-phonon coupling in doped graphene. This study provides a promising direction towards the development of graphene-based materials with enhanced performance, thereby contributing to the advancement of materials science.

human_text: The nature of the coupling leading to superconductivity in layered materials such as high-Tc superconductors and graphite intercalation compounds (GICs) is still unresolved. In both systems, interactions of electrons with either phonons or other electrons or both have been proposed to explain superconductivity. In the high-Tc cuprates, the presence of a Van Hove singularity (VHS) in the density of states near the Fermi level was long ago proposed to enhance the many-body couplings and therefore may play a role in superconductivity. Such a singularity can cause an anisotropic variation in the coupling strength, which may partially explain the so-called nodal-antinodal dichotomy in the cuprates. Here we show that the topology of the graphene band structure at dopings comparable to the GICs is quite similar to that of the cuprates and that the quasiparticle dynamics in graphene have a similar dichotomy. Namely, the electron-phonon coupling is highly anisotropic, diverging near a saddle point in the graphene electronic band structure. These results support the important role of the VHS in layered materials and the possible optimization of Tc by tuning the VHS with respect to the Fermi level.

machine_text: We present a high-resolution survey of O VI absorption lines in the spectra of 36 low-redshift QSOs. The primary objective of this work is to characterize the physical conditions and statistical properties of O VI absorbers found in the intergalactic medium (IGM). The study aims at addressing the important question of the origin of O VI absorbers - whether they arise solely from photoionization or from a combination of photoionization and collisional ionization.Our analysis of the O VI absorbers reveals a complex interplay between various physical processes that shape the properties of the absorbers. We find that the O VI absorbers have a low Doppler parameter and a wide range of ionization fractions, indicative of a mixed origin. We also find that the O VI absorbers are more prevalent in denser environments and that the metallicity of the absorbers is closely linked to the gas density. The findings of this study suggest that the physical conditions of the IGM are highly complex and that the ionization state of the gas cannot be explained solely by photoionization. These results have important implications for understanding the nature of the IGM and its role in shaping the evolution of galaxies.

For intervening systems [components] with rest-frame equivalent width W_r > 30 mA, the number of O VI absorbers per unit redshift dN/dz = 15.6(+2.9/-2.4) [21.0(+3.2/-2.8)], and this decreases to dN/dz = 0.9(+1.0/-0.5) [0.3(+0.7/-0.3)] for W_r > 300 mA. The number per redshift increases steeply as z_abs approaches z_QSO, and some proximate absorbers have substantially lower H I/O VI ratios. machine_text: Protoplanetary disks around millisecond pulsars have garnered much interest in the scientific community due to their potential to shed light on the formation and evolution of planets in highly compact stellar systems. The PSR 1257 +12 system is a particularly interesting case study, as it boasts three planets orbiting a pulsar with a period of only 6 milliseconds. In this study, we investigate the evolution of protoplanetary disks around millisecond pulsars, specifically in the context of the PSR 1257 +12 system.Our findings reveal that the protoplanetary disk around the PSR 1257 +12 system is likely to have been significantly impacted by the pulsar's radiation. By modeling the radiation pressure exerted on the disk, we demonstrate that the disk would have been truncated at a radius of about 0.1 AU, possibly explaining the relatively compact orbits of the three planets in the system. Additionally, we find that the disk is likely to have been affected by viscous spreading, with a characteristic timescale of around 10,000 years.The motivation for this research stems from the desire to better understand the formation and evolution of planets in highly compact stellar systems. By studying protoplanetary disks around millisecond pulsars such as the PSR 1257 +12 system, we gain insight into the physical processes that govern the formation and migration of planets in such environments. Furthermore, our findings contribute to the broader effort of understanding the diversity of exoplanetary systems and the conditions that give rise to them.

human_text: We model the evolution of protoplanetary disks surrounding millisecond pulsars, using PSR 1257+12 as a test case. Initial conditions were chosen to correspond to initial angular momenta expected for supernova-fallback disks and disks formed from the tidal disruption of a companion star. Models were run under two models for the viscous evolution of disks: fully viscous and layered accretion disk models. Supernova-fallback disks result in a distribution of solids confined to within 1-2 AU and produce the requisite material to form the three known planets surrounding PSR 1257+12. Tidal disruption disks tend to slightly underproduce solids interior to 1 AU, required for forming the pulsar planets, while overproducing the amount of solids where no body, lunar mass or greater, exists. Disks evolving under 'layered' accretion spread somewhat less and deposit a higher column density of solids into the disk. In all cases, circumpulsar gas dissipates on ≲ 10^5 year timescales, making formation of gas giant planets highly unlikely.

machine_text: We present a novel approach to Poisson approximation of non-backtracking random walks, utilizing the power of generating functions. The importance of this problem stems from the fact that non-backtracking random walks are widely used in various areas of computer science, as they provide a natural way of modeling systems where cycles are not allowed. Our motivation for this research is to provide an efficient and reliable approximation technique for the analysis and design of such systems.Our key idea is to represent a non-backtracking random walk as a product of independent factors, where each factor corresponds to a directed edge and the probability of not returning to the previous edge. We then derive the generating function for this factor and use it to calculate the probability generating function (PGF) for the non-backtracking random walk. Finally, we apply the well-known Chen-Stein method to the PGF, obtaining an approximation in terms of the Poisson distribution.Our approach provides a high level of accuracy, as we use exact PGFs and a second-order approximation for the Chen-Stein bound. Additionally, our methodology is very efficient, as it only requires the calculation of PGFs and the use of standard algebraic techniques. We validate our approach through numerical simulations and demonstrate its effectiveness in practical examples. Overall, our work provides a powerful tool for the analysis and optimization of non-backtracking random walks.

attack_machine_text: We presented a novel approach to Poisson approximation of non-backtracking random walks, utilizing the power of generating functions, which was previously unknown. The importance of this problem stemmed from the fact that non-backtracking random walks were widely used in various areas of computer science, as they provided a natural way of modeling systems where cycles were not allowed; however, we will now discuss how our new approach overcame these challenges. Our motivation for this research was to provide an efficient and reliable approximation technique for the analysis and design of such systems, which had previously been lacking in accuracy. We derived the generating function for each factor, representing a non-backtracking random walk as a product of independent factors; furthermore, we used it to calculate the probability generating function (PGF) for the non-backtracking random walk. In addition, we applied the well-known Chen-Stein method to the PGF, obtaining an approximation in terms of the Poisson distribution, which provided a high level of accuracy. Our approach was very efficient, as it only required the calculation of PGFs and the use of standard algebraic techniques; however, this did not compromise its effectiveness in practical examples. human_text: Random walks on expander graphs were thoroughly studied, with the important motivation that, under some natural conditions, these walks mix quickly and provide an efficient method of sampling the vertices of a graph. Alon, Benjamini, Lubetzky and Sodin studied non-backtracking random walks on regular graphs, and showed that their mixing rate may be up to twice as fast as that of the simple random walk. As an application, they showed that the maximal number of visits to a vertex, made by a non-backtracking random walk of length n on a high-girth n-vertex regular expander, is typically (1+o(1))log n/loglog n, as in the case of the balls and bins experiment. They further asked whether one can establish the precise distribution of the visits such a walk makes.In this work, we answer the above question by combining a generalized form of Brun's sieve with some extensions of the ideas in Alon et al. Let N_t denote the number of vertices visited precisely t times by a non-backtracking random walk of length n on a regular n-vertex expander of fixed degree and girth g. We prove that if g=ω(1), then for any fixed t, N_t/n is typically 1/et!+o(1). Furthermore, if g=Ω(loglog n), then N_t/n is typically 1+o(1)/et! uniformly on all t ≤ (1-o(1))log n/loglog n and 0 for all t ≥ (1+o(1))log n/loglog n. In particular, we obtain the above result on the typical maximal number of visits to a single vertex, with an improved threshold window. The essence of the proof lies in showing that variables counting the number of visits to a set of sufficiently distant vertices are asymptotically independent Poisson variables.

machine_text: In this study, we investigate the radion phenomenology in realistic warped space models motivated by the theoretical and experimental challenges to explain the hierarchy of the fermion masses and the existing tension between the precision electroweak measurements and direct searches for new physics. We consider a five-dimensional Randall-Sundrum model with a bulk scalar and fermion fields and a brane-localized Higgs field. We show that the radion and KK-graviton excitations can have important implications for the collider and cosmological observables. In particular, we analyze the effective couplings and decay modes of the radion in the diphoton and diphoton+dijet channels at the Large Hadron Collider and explore the parameter space that can lead to a detectable signal. We find that the radion can have a significant contribution to the diphoton excess observed by ATLAS and CMS experiments around a mass of 750 GeV. Furthermore, we investigate the radion interactions with the cosmic microwave background and dark matter and show that the radion can have effects on the early universe and on the present-day abundance of dark matter. Our study provides insights into the rich phenomenology of warped extra dimensions and highlights the importance of future experimental and observational probes.Keywords: radion phenomenology, warped space models, Randall-Sundrum model, collider physics, dark matter.

human_text: We investigate the phenomenology of the Randall-Sundrum radion in realistic models of electroweak symmetry breaking with bulk gauge and fermion fields, since the radion may turn out to be the lightest particle in such models. We calculate the coupling of the radion in such scenarios to bulk fermion and gauge modes. Special attention needs to be devoted to the coupling to massless gauge fields (photon, gluon), since it is well known that loop effects may be important for these fields. We also present a detailed explanation of these couplings from the CFT interpretation. We then use these couplings to determine the radion branching fractions and discuss some of the discovery potential of the LHC for the radion. We find that the gamma-gamma signal is enhanced over most of the range of the radion mass over the gamma-gamma signal of a SM Higgs, as long as the RS scale is sufficiently low. However, the signal significance depends strongly on free parameters that characterize the magnitude of bare brane-localized kinetic terms for the massless gauge fields. In the absence of such terms, the signal can be be enhanced over the traditional RS1 models (where all standard model fields are localized on the IR brane), but the signal can also be reduced compared to RS1 if the brane localized terms are sizeable. We also show that for larger radion masses, where the gamma-gamma signal is no longer significant, one can use the usual 4 lepton signal to discover the radion.

human_text: We report on 8.4GHz Very Long Baseline Interferometry (VLBI) observations of the type II-P supernova SN2004et in the spiral galaxy NGC 6946, made on 20 February 2005 (151 days after explosion). The Very Large Array (VLA) flux density was 1.23±0.07 mJy, corresponding to an isotropic luminosity at 8.4GHz of (4.45±0.3)×10^25 erg s^-1 Hz^-1 and a brightness temperature of (1.3±0.3)×10^8 K. We also provide an improved source position, accurate to about 0.5 mas in each coordinate. The VLBI image shows a clear asymmetry. From model fitting of the size of the radio emission, we estimate a minimum expansion velocity of 15,700±2,000 km s^-1. This velocity is more than twice the expected mean expansion velocity estimated from a synchrotron self-absorbed emission model, thus suggesting that synchrotron self-absorption is not relevant for this supernova. With the benefit of an optical spectrum obtained 12 days after explosion, we favor an emission model which consists of two hot spots on an underlying expanding shell of width comparable to that of SN 1993J.

machine_text: In this work, we investigate the star-formation activity in low radio luminosity AGN from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS). The motivation for this research stems from the fact that AGNs are known to have a profound impact on their host galaxies, and as such, studying the properties of AGN and their host galaxies is fundamental in understanding the fundamental processes that govern the evolution of galaxies. In particular, the role of AGN in suppressing or promoting star formation in their host galaxies has been a long-standing topic of debate in the field.In an attempt to shed light on this issue, we carried out an analysis of a sample of low radio luminosity AGN selected from the SDSS. Our analysis primarily involved estimating the star-formation activity in the AGN host galaxies using various multi-wavelength diagnostics. The results we obtained suggest that, contrary to previous studies, low radio luminosity AGN can potentially promote significant star formation in their host galaxies. We also find that our sample of low radio luminosity AGN exhibit a wide range of star-formation rates, spanning from completely quiescent to actively star-forming galaxies.In summary, this study provides further insights into the complex interplay between AGN and star formation in their host galaxies and underscores the need for further investigations to fully comprehend the link between these phenomena.

human_text: We investigate faint radio emission from low- to high-luminosity Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN) selected from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS). Their radio properties are inferred by co-adding large ensembles of radio image cut-outs from the FIRST survey, as almost all of the sources are individually undetected. We correlate the median radio flux densities against a range of other sample properties, including median values for redshift, [OIII] luminosity, emission line ratios, and the strength of the 4000A break. We detect a strong trend for sources that are actively undergoing star-formation to have excess radio emission beyond the10^28 ergs/s/Hz level found for sources without any discernible star-formation. Furthermore, this additional radio emission correlates well with the strength of the 4000A break in the optical spectrum, and may be used to assess the age of the star-forming component. We examine two subsamples, one containing the systems with emission line ratios most like star-forming systems, and one with the sources that have characteristic AGN ratios. This division also separates the mechanism responsible for the radio emission (star-formation vs. AGN). For both cases we find a strong, almost identical, correlation between [OIII] and radio luminosity, with the AGN sample extending toward lower, and the star-formation sample toward higher luminosities. A clearer separation between the two subsamples is seen as function of the central velocity dispersion of the host galaxy. For systems with similar redshifts and velocity dispersions, the star-formation subsample is brighter than the AGN in the radio by an order of magnitude. This underlines the notion that the radio emission in star-forming systems can dominate the emission associated with the AGN.

machine_text: The present work offers a detailed optical and X-ray analysis of the cooling flow cluster Z3146, named ARCRAIDER I. Our analysis confirms a strong cD galaxy at the center of the cluster, surrounded by a cooling flow of gas. The spatially resolved spectral analysis shows that the intra-cluster medium (ICM) is hot in the cluster's center and cools down radially, reaching temperatures of around 2 keV at the edge. We also found a clear anti-correlation between temperature and metallicity, where the central ICM is enriched in heavy elements, while the outskirts hold a higher concentration of lighter elements.This research provides essential information about the complex processes involved in the cooling flow mechanism, which is vital for further understanding the evolution of galaxy clusters. Such analyses are necessary to comprehend the cooling flows' fundamental properties and their connection to the galaxy cluster properties. Additionally, studying the metallicity distribution in the ICM not only provides crucial information about the elemental abundances but also helps trace the history of star formation in the cluster.The results obtained in this work serve as a significant contribution to the ever-growing body of knowledge on cluster evolution and can serve as a launching point for further research in this field. The analysis presented here attempts to solve the problem of shedding light on the nature of cooling flows and metallicity distribution, which has been a long-standing source of debate and research in the cosmological community.

human_text: We present a detailed analysis of the medium redshift (z=0.2906) galaxy cluster Z3146 which is part of the ongoing ARCRAIDER project, a systematic search for gravitational arcs in massive clusters of galaxies. The analysis of Z3146 is based on deep optical wide field observations in the B, V and R bands obtained with the WFI@ESO2.2m, and shallow archival WFPC2@HST taken with the F606W filter, which are used for strong as well as weak lensing analyses. Additionally we have used publicly available XMM/Newton observations for a detailed X-ray analysis of Z3146. Both methods, lensing and X-ray, were used to determine the dynamical state and to estimate the total mass. We also identified four gravitational arc candidates. We find this cluster to be in a relaxed state, which is confirmed by a large cooling flow with nominal1600M_⊙per year, regular galaxy density and light distributions and a regular shape of the weak lensing mass reconstruction. machine_text: Our work investigates the phenomenon of chi2 and chi3 harmonic generation in inhomogeneous doubly resonant cavities at critical power levels. The problem stems from the desire to increase the efficiency of nonlinear optical processes, such as frequency conversion, by utilizing the nonlinearity of the medium. In particular, relying on the chirp profile selects the desired mode of harmonic generation.Our research aims to understand the impact of inhomogeneity on the critical power level at which chi2 and chi3 harmonic generation are significantly enhanced. We utilized numerical simulations to investigate the behavior of the inhomogeneous cavity as a function of varying intracavity intensities and chirp profiles. Furthermore, we explored the role of the inhomogeneous medium's refractive index distribution on the observed critical power level.Our results highlight that the inhomogeneity of the resonant cavity significantly enhances the critical power level of the chi2 and chi3 harmonic generation and the role of refractive index distribution must be taken into account. Our research provides insight into the design and optimization of nonlinear optical devices for applications in spectroscopy, microscopy, and telecommunications.

human_text: We derive general conditions for 100 percent frequency conversion in any doubly resonant nonlinear cavity, for both second- and third-harmonic generation via chi2 and chi3 nonlinearities. We find that conversion efficiency is optimized for a certain critical power depending on the cavity parameters, and assuming reasonable parameters we predict 100 percent conversion using milliwatts of power or less. These results follow from a semi-analytical coupled-mode theory framework which is generalized from previous work to include both chi2 and chi3 media as well as inhomogeneous (fully vectorial) cavities, analyzed in the high-efficiency limit where down-conversion processes lead to a maximum efficiency at the critical power, and which is verified by direct finite-difference time-domain (FDTD) simulations of the nonlinear Maxwell equations. Explicit formulas for the nonlinear coupling coefficients are derived in terms of the linear cavity eigenmodes, which can be used to design and evaluate cavities in arbitrary geometries.

machine_text: In this study, we present the observation of electron-hole puddles (EHPs) in graphene using a scanning single electron transistor (SSET). Graphene has aroused great interest in the scientific community due to its unique electronic and physical properties. However, the understanding of its electronic behavior is still incomplete, and the investigation of EHPs is of utmost importance to elucidate the doping and scattering mechanisms in graphene. The problem we aim to solve is to provide a reliable and accurate method for imaging the local electronic properties of graphene, especially in the vicinity of defects or dopants. The key idea of our research is to employ a sensitive and high-resolution SSET as a probe to map the electrostatic potential in graphene and detect the local density of states (LDOS). The methodology consists of fabricating the SSET, depositing the graphene sample on a Si/SiO2 substrate, and scanning the SSET tip over the sample surface. Our results demonstrate the existence of EHPs in graphene and reveal their spatial distribution and size. Moreover, we show that the SSET can image EHPs with sub-10 nm resolution and quantitatively measure their LDOS. Our study sheds light on the fundamental electronic properties of graphene and paves the way for further exploring its applications in nanoelectronics and spintronics.

human_text: The electronic density of states of graphene is equivalent to that of relativistic electrons. In the absence of disorder or external doping the Fermi energy lies at the Dirac point where the density of states vanishes. Although transport measurements at high carrier densities indicate rather high mobilities, many questions pertaining to disorder remain unanswered. In particular, it has been argued theoretically, that when the average carrier density is zero, the inescapable presence of disorder will lead to electron and hole puddles with equal probability. In this work, we use a scanning single electron transistor to image the carrier density landscape of graphene in the vicinity of the neutrality point. Our results clearly show the electron-hole puddles expected theoretically. In addition, our measurement technique enables to determine locally the density of states in graphene. In contrast to previously studied massive two dimensional electron systems, the kinetic contribution to the density of states accounts quantitatively for the measured signal. Our results suggests that exchange and correlation effects are either weak or have canceling contributions.

machine_text: We present a study of the fundamental parameters of helium (He)-weak and He-strong stars. Our aim is to characterize the physical properties of these stars, which are known to have a strong impact on the understanding of stellar evolution. The methodology followed is based on spectral analysis, which allows us to derive the effective temperature, surface gravity, and chemical composition of the stars. Our sample comprises a total of 24 He-weak and 17 He-strong stars, which were analyzed using high-resolution spectroscopy data obtained with the VLT-UVES instrument. The results obtained show that He-weak stars have lower effective temperatures and surface gravities than normal stars, while He-strong stars have higher effective temperatures and surface gravities. We also find that He-strong stars exhibit enhanced metallicity, which suggests that their formation might be related to a specific chemical enrichment process. These findings are of great significance since they provide new insights into the physical properties of He-weak and He-strong stars, which may be useful to improve our understanding of the evolution of massive stars and the origin of chemical elements in the Universe.

human_text: We carried out low resolution spectroscopic observations in the wavelength range 3400-4700 A of 20 He-weak and 8 He-strong stars to determine their fundamental parameters by means of the Divan-Chalonge-Barbier (BCD) spectrophotometric system. For a few He-weak stars we also estimate the effective temperatures and the angular diameters by integrating absolute fluxes observed over a wide spectral range. Non-LTE model calculations are carried out to study the influence of the He/H abundance ratio on the emergent radiation of He-strong stars and on their Teff determination. We find that the effective temperatures, surface gravities and bolometric absolute magnitudes of He-weak stars estimated with the BCD system and the integrated flux method are in good agreement between each other, and they also agree with previous determinations based on several different methods. The mean discrepancy between the visual absolute magnitudes derived using the Hipparcos parallaxes and the BCD values is on average 0.3 mag for He-weak stars, while it is 0.5 mag for He-strong stars. For He-strong stars, we note that the BCD calibration, based on stars in the solar environment, leads to overestimated values of Teff. By means of model atmosphere calculations with enhanced He/H abundance ratios we show that larger He/H ratios produce smaller BD which naturally explains the Teff overestimation. We take advantage of these calculations to introduce a method to estimate the He/H abundance ratio in He-strong stars. The BD of HD 37479 suggests that the Teff of this star remains fairly constant as the star spectrum undergoes changes in the intensity of H and He absorption lines. Data for the He-strong star HD 66765 are reported for the first time.

human_text: Aims: The planetary system around the M star Gliese 581 consists of a hot Neptune (Gl 581b) and two super-Earths (Gl 581c and Gl 581d). The habitability of this system with respect to the super-Earths is investigated following a concept that studies the long-term possibility of photosynthetic biomass production on a dynamically active planet. Methods: A thermal evolution model for a super-Earth is used to calculate the sources and sinks of atmospheric carbon dioxide. The habitable zone is determined by the limits of biological productivity on the planetary surface. Models with different ratios of land / ocean coverage are investigated. Results: The super-Earth Gl 581c is clearly outside the habitable zone, since it is too close to the star. In contrast, Gl 581d is a tidally locked habitable super-Earth near the outer edge of the habitable zone. Despite the adverse conditions on this planet, at least some primitive forms of life may be able to exist on its surface.Therefore, Gl 581d is an interesting target for the planned TPF/Darwin missions to search for biomarkers in planetary atmospheres.

machine_text: In this work, we investigate the control of mechanical systems on Lie groups and their application to ideal hydrodynamics. Our main objective is to develop a control strategy that preserves the geometric properties of the systems, while ensuring optimal behavior. Specifically, we focus on systems that evolve on Lie groups and are subject to external or internal perturbations. Such systems arise in various physical applications, including fluid dynamics, robotics, and spacecraft control.To address these challenges, we propose a novel approach based on Lie-algebraic techniques and the concept of optimal control theory. Our approach enables us to derive explicit control laws that naturally incorporate the underlying geometry of the system, resulting in a unique and effective control strategy.We evaluate our methodology by applying it to a simple model system, and demonstrate its superior performance in comparison to classical control techniques. Moreover, we show the applicability of our approach to ideal hydrodynamics, which confirms the generality of our method and its potential impact on various scientific domains.In summary, this work provides a comprehensive framework for the control of mechanical systems on Lie groups, with promising results in ideal hydrodynamics. Our approach is innovative and promising, leading to potential advances in control engineering, robotics, and fluid dynamics.

human_text: In contrast to the Euler-Poincaré reduction of geodesic flows of left- or right-invariant metrics on Lie groups to the corresponding Lie algebra (or its dual), one can consider the reduction of the geodesic flows to the group itself. The reduced vector field has a remarkable hydrodynamic interpretation: it is a velocity field for a stationary flow of an ideal fluid. Right- or left-invariant symmetry fields of the reduced field define vortex manifolds for such flows.Consider now a mechanical system, whose configuration space is a Lie group and whose Lagrangian is invariant to left translations on that group, and assume that the mass geometry of the system may change under the action of internal control forces. Such system can also be reduced to the Lie group. With no controls, this mechanical system describes a geodesic flow of the left-invariant metric, given by the Lagrangian, and thus its reduced flow is a stationary ideal fluid flow on the Lie group. The standard control problem for such system is to find the conditions, under which the system can be brought from any initial position in the configuration space to another preassigned position by changing its mass geometry. We show that under these conditions, by changing the mass geometry, one can also bring one vortex manifold to any other preassigned vortex manifold.

machine_text: In this work, we present a new approach to the Generalized Twistor Transform and Dualities in quantum field theory, aimed at providing a fresh perspective on the description of particles with spin, beyond the cases of free and massless fields. Specifically, we propose a novel formalism based on the introduction of a spinorial wave function, which encapsulates the relevant geometric and algebraic properties of spacetime and spin degrees of freedom. Our approach allows us to naturally incorporate both chiral and spinor structures, and enables us to establish new connections between different classes of theories, such as conformal field theory, super Yang-Mills, and gravity.The motivation for this research lies in the need for a deeper understanding of the fundamental aspects of particle physics and their relation to the underlying geometry of spacetime. In particular, our work provides insights into the algebraic and geometric structures that govern the behavior of particles with spin in various theories, and sheds light on the role of duality symmetries in their description. Moreover, our results have potential applications in the study of high-energy physics and the unification of the fundamental forces of nature. Overall, our work provides a novel formalism for describing particles with spin beyond the free and massless cases, and opens new avenues for exploring the interplay between geometry, algebra, and quantum mechanics.

human_text: A generalized twistor transform for spinning particles in 3+1 dimensions is constructed that beautifully unifies many types of spinning systems by mapping them to the same twistor, thus predicting an infinite set of duality relations among spinning systems with different Hamiltonians. Usual 1T-physics is not equipped to explain the duality relationships and unification between these systems. We use 2T-physics in 4+2 dimensions to uncover new properties of twistors, and expect that our approach will prove to be useful for practical applications as well as for a deeper understanding of fundamental physics. Unexpected structures for a new description of spinning particles emerge. A unifying symmetry SU(2,3) that includes conformal symmetry SU(2,2)=SO(4,2) in the massless case, turns out to be a fundamental property underlying the dualities of a large set of spinning systems, including those that occur in high spin theories. This may lead to new forms of string theory backgrounds as well as to new methods for studying various corners of M theory. In this paper we present the main concepts, and in a companion paper we give other details.

machine_text: In this work, we investigate the phenomenon of Multiple Parton Scattering (MPS) in nuclei, specifically focusing on quark-quark scattering. The problem we aim to solve is to obtain a better understanding of the scattering process of quarks in a nuclear environment. While the concept of MPS has been extensively studied, the specific details of the quark-quark scattering process in atomic nuclei remain unclear.To tackle this problem, we employ a theoretical approach that utilizes the Color Glass Condensate (CGC) effective field theory. We calculate the MPS probability of a nucleon in a nucleus to suffer two or more scattering events with a second parton. We also investigate the impact parameter dependence of our model.Our results show that the MPS probability increases with the atomic number of the nucleus and the energy of the scattering event. Additionally, the impact parameter dependence of the MPS probability shows that the probability is higher for peripheral collisions. We further demonstrate that the introduction of a quark-quark scattering mechanism effectively damps the previously found enhancement of the n-parton distribution for small parton separations.In summary, our work provides insights into the quark-quark scattering process in nuclei by investigating the MPS phenomenon. We employ a theoretical framework that allows us to make quantitative predictions, with our results showing the atomic number and collision energy dependence of the MPS probability. Our findings have the potential to impact the understanding of particle physics and refine existing models in the field.
