human_text: We study the mixing time of a systematic scan Markov chain for sampling from the uniform distribution on proper 7-colourings of a finite rectangular sub-grid of the infinite square lattice, the grid. A systematic scan Markov chain cycles through finite-size subsets of vertices in a deterministic order and updates the colours assigned to the vertices of each subset. The systematic scan Markov chain that we present cycles through subsets consisting of 2x2 sub-grids and updates the colours assigned to the vertices using a procedure known as heat-bath. We give a computer-assisted proof that this systematic scan Markov chain mixes in O(log n) scans, where n is the size of the rectangular sub-grid. We make use of a heuristic to compute required couplings of colourings of 2x2 sub-grids. This is the first time the mixing time of a systematic scan Markov chain on the grid has been shown to mix for less than 8 colours. We also give partial results that underline the challenges of proving rapid mixing of a systematic scan Markov chain for sampling 6-colourings of the grid by considering 2x3 and 3x3 sub-grids.

machine_text: In this research, we propose a novel method of using images to create a Hierarchical Grid Spatial Index (HGSI) for efficient retrieval of spatial data. Motivated by the increasing demand for fast and accurate processing of spatial data in various domains, we aim to develop a powerful indexing technique that can handle the massive and complex data sets commonly encountered in modern applications. Our model consists of two major components: an image representation module that generates a visual summary of the spatial distribution of data points, and a hierarchical indexing module that uses the visual summary to construct a multi-level grid structure for efficient indexing and retrieval.Our experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed method in comparison to existing spatial indexing methods. Specifically, our HGSI model shows superior performance in terms of query efficiency, scalability, and accuracy. Furthermore, we provide an in-depth analysis and explanation of the key ideas and methodology underlying our model, highlighting its strengths and limitations.Overall, our research contributes to the advancement of spatial data management and analysis by providing a powerful and efficient indexing technique that can handle increasingly complex and massive data sets. We believe that our work has significant potential for use in various domains such as geospatial analysis, environmental monitoring, and urban planning.

human_text: This paper presents a hybrid approach to spatial indexing of two dimensional data. It sheds new light on the age old problem by thinking of the traditional algorithms as working with images. Inspiration is drawn from an analogous situation that is found in machine and human vision. Image processing techniques are used to assist in the spatial indexing of the data. A fixed grid approach is used and bins with too many records are sub-divided hierarchically. Search queries are pre-computed for bins that do not contain any data records. This has the effect of dividing the search space up into non rectangular regions which are based on the spatial properties of the data. The bucketing quad tree can be considered as an image with a resolution of two by two for each layer. The results show that this method performs better than the quad tree if there are more divisions per layer. This confirms our suspicions that the algorithm works better if it gets to look at the data with higher resolution images. An elegant class structure is developed where the implementation of concrete spatial indexes for a particular data type merely relies on rendering the data onto an image.

machine_text: In this work, we present a novel QoS routing protocol that leverages soft constraint logic programming (SCLP) for both unicast and multicast communication in wireless ad hoc networks. The proposed protocol seeks to address the key issue of providing efficient and reliable QoS routing services in these networks, which are characterized by their dynamic topology, resource constraints, and unpredictable interference.Our research is motivated by the need for QoS-aware routing protocols that can dynamically adapt to network conditions, prioritize traffic based on user-defined service requirements, and optimize network resource utilization. Existing QoS routing solutions often rely on traditional mathematical programming techniques that may be too rigid or computationally intensive. By contrast, SCLP provides a flexible framework for encoding QoS requirements, preferences, and constraints as soft rules, which can be easily updated as network conditions change.We adopt a formal academic and scientific writing voice to present our methodology and key ideas. Overall, our approach involves formulating QoS routing as a constraint satisfaction problem, applying SCLP to generate optimized routes that satisfy user-defined QoS requirements, and incorporating a soft re-optimization mechanism to adapt to changes in network conditions.Our experimental evaluations demonstrate that the proposed protocol offers significant improvements in QoS performance metrics compared to other state-of-the-art QoS routing protocols. These results highlight the potential of SCLP-based approaches for addressing QoS routing challenges in ad hoc networks.

Overall, our approach involves formulating QoS routing as a constraint satisfaction problem, applying SCLP to generate optimized routes that satisfy user-defined QoS requirements, and incorporating a soft re-optimization mechanism to adapt to changes in network conditions.  Our experimental evaluations demonstrate that the proposed protocol offers significant improvements in QoS performance metrics compared to other state-of-the-art QoS routing protocols. These results highlight the potential of SCLP-based approaches for addressing QoS routing challenges in ad hoc networks.

human_text: We present a formal model to represent and solve the unicast/multicast routing problem in networks with Quality of Service (QoS) requirements. To attain this, first we translate the network adapting it to a weighted graph (unicast) or and-or graph (multicast), where the weight on a connector corresponds to the multidimensional cost of sending a packet on the related network link: each component of the weights vector represents a different QoS metric value (e.g. bandwidth, cost, delay, packet loss). The second step consists in writing this graph as a program in Soft Constraint Logic Programming (SCLP): the engine of this framework is then able to find the best paths/trees by optimizing their costs and solving the constraints imposed on them (e.g. delay < 40msec), thus finding a solution to QoS routing problems. Moreover, c-semiring structures are a convenient tool to model QoS metrics. At last, we provide an implementation of the framework over scale-free networks and we suggest how the performance can be improved.

machine_text: In this work, we aim to investigate the building up of the disk galaxy M33 and the evolution of the metallicity gradient. Our goal is to shed light on the mechanisms responsible for the creation of the disk structure and on the way in which the chemical composition of the gas is modified during its evolution.In order to achieve this, we have analyzed a sample of young star clusters in M33 using high resolution spectroscopy. Our results indicate that there is a clear correlation between the metallicity of the clusters and their distance from the center of the galaxy. This suggests that the metallicity gradient in M33 has been established over a long period of time through a combination of gas accretion and star formation.Furthermore, we have developed a model that takes into account the effects of accretion, star formation, and outflow on the chemical evolution of the galaxy. Our analysis shows that the observed metallicity gradient can be reproduced by our model, providing a solid theoretical framework for the observed phenomenon.Overall, our work provides new insights into the formation and evolution of M33, and more broadly into the mechanisms driving the evolution of disk galaxies. Our approach, which combines observational data and theoretical modeling, represents a powerful tool for understanding the complex processes taking place in these systems.

human_text: The evolution of radial gradients of metallicity in disk galaxies and its relation with the disk formation are not well understood. Theoretical models of galactic chemical evolution make contrasting predictions about the time evolution of metallicity gradients. To test chemical evolution models and trace the star formation and accretion history of low luminosity disk galaxies we focus on the Local Group galaxy M33. We analyze O/H and S/H abundances in planetary nebulae, Hii regions, and young stars, together with known [Fe/H] abundances in the old stellar population of M33. With a theoretical model, we follow the time evolution of gas (diffuse and condensed in clouds), stars, and chemical abundances in the disk of M33, assuming that the galaxy is accreting gas from an external reservoir. Our model is able to reproduce the available observational constraints on the distribution of gas and stars in M33 and to predict the time evolution of several chemical abundances. In particular, we find that a model characterized by a continuous infall of gas on the disk, at a rate of Ṁ_ inf≈ 1 M_⊙ yr^-1, almost constant with time, can also account for the relatively high rate of star formation and for the shallow chemical gradients. Supported by a large sample of high resolution observations for this nearby galaxy, we conclude that the metallicity in the disk of M33 has increased with time at all radii, with a continuous flattening of the gradient over the last ∼ 8 Gyr.

machine_text: In this work, we explore the use of neutral networks to map DNA sequences to three-dimensional shapes. This is an important problem in structural biology, as the shape of a molecule largely determines its function. However, determining the three-dimensional structure of a protein is difficult and time-consuming, and traditional experimental methods can only provide limited information. Therefore, computational methods that can accurately predict protein structures are highly desirable.The key idea behind our approach is to use neutral networks to address the immense complexity of sequence-to-structure mapping. Neutral networks are sets of sequences that have similar folding energies, allowing for the exploration of alternative folding pathways. We trained a neural network on a dataset of sequence-structure pairs and then used it to generate a large number of alternative structures for each sequence. We then clustered these structures to identify distinct folding paths and used them to refine our predictions.Our methodology resulted in accurate predictions of protein structure, even for sequences with little sequence similarity to known structures. We believe the use of neutral networks has great potential for the development of improved computational methods for predicting protein structure. This work has important implications for the design of new drugs and the understanding of biological systems, and it represents an exciting direction for future research in structural biology.

human_text: In this paper we present a novel framework for sequence to shape maps. These combinatorial maps realize exponentially many shapes, and have preimages which contain extended connected subgraphs of diameter n (neutral networks). We prove that all basic properties of RNA folding maps also hold for combinatorial maps. Our construction is as follows: suppose we are given a graph H over the {1 >...,n} and an alphabet of nucleotides together with a symmetric relation ℛ, implied by base pairing rules. Then the shape of a sequence of length n is the maximal H subgraph in which all pairs of nucleotides incident to H-edges satisfy ℛ. Our main result is to prove the existence of at least √(2)^n-1 shapes with extended neutral networks, i.e. shapes that have a preimage with diameter n and a connected component of size at least (1+√(5)/2)^n+(1-√(5)/2)^n. Furthermore, we show that there exists a certain subset of shapes which carries a natural graph structure. In this graph any two shapes are connected by a path of shapes with respective neutral networks of distance one. We finally discuss our results and provide a comparison with RNA folding maps.

machine_text: In this study, we investigated the fluidization of a shallow granular layer which was vertically oscillated, by focusing on the emergence of a granular gas phase. The motivation for our research stems from the growing interest in the dynamics of granular systems and their applications in numerous industrial and environmental settings. The idea is to gain a deeper understanding of the mechanisms that govern fluidization dynamics in granular layers and to identify the key factors that control the transition from solid-like to fluid-like behavior.The granular layer was vertically excited by a harmonically oscillating plate, and the resulting dynamics were tracked by high-speed imaging and dense particle tracking. We observed the formation of a granular gas phase, controlled by the amplitude and frequency of the plate vibration, and its subsequent evolution into a homogeneous fluidized state. Meanwhile, we analyzed the spatial and temporal variations of granular temperature, velocity distributions, and particle collisions, and we also quantified the granular gas fraction as a function of the oscillation parameters.Our work attempts to solve the fundamental problem of understanding the conditions and dynamics that give rise to fluidization in granular materials. It contributes to the existing literature by providing quantitative measurements of the granular gas fraction, which can serve as a benchmark for future modeling and simulation efforts. This research has potential implications in a range of fields, such as industrial processes, materials science, and geophysics.

human_text: Molecular dynamics simulations are used to study fluidization of a vertically vibrated, three-dimensional shallow granular layer. As the container acceleration is increased above g, the granular temperature and root mean square particle displacement increase, gradually fluidizing the layer. For nearly elastic particles, or low shaking frequencies, or small layer depths, the end of the fluidization process is marked by an abrupt increase in the granular temperature and rms particle displacement. The layer is then fully fluidized since macroscopic, fluid-like phenomena such as convection rolls and surface waves are observed. Increasing the total dissipation (by either decreasing the restitution coefficient or increasing the total number of particles) decreases the increase in granular temperature and rms particle displacement at fluidization, and shifts the increase to higher accelerations. Increasing the frequency also decreases the magnitude of the jump, and shifts the change to lower accelerations.

machine_text: In this work, we investigate the possibility of obtaining an almost supersymmetric Standard Model from intersecting D6-branes on the Z_6' orientifold. We focus on the compactification of type IIA string theory on a toroidal background with orientifold planes. We consider a six-dimensional orbifold obtained by dividing a six-dimensional torus by a Z_6' orientation, which leads to orientifold planes and D6-branes at fixed points. We study the low-energy effective theory of the D6-branes and analyze the spectrum of chiral matter under the Standard Model gauge group. We find that the resulting spectrum contains all the particles of the Standard Model, except for the right-handed neutrinos, and that the Yukawa couplings are generated by instanton effects.Our work aims to address the problem of obtaining a realistic model of particle physics from string theory. The success of the Standard Model of particle physics in explaining the experimental data leaves little room for new physics beyond the Standard Model at low energies. String theory provides a consistent framework for quantum gravity that unifies all fundamental forces, but constructing a realistic model of particle physics from string theory is a challenging task.Our approach involves the use of intersecting D6-branes and the Z_6' orientifold, which is a particularly interesting model due to its rich phenomenology. Intersecting branes provide a geometric realization of the chiral matter spectrum, while the orientifold projection allows for the cancellation of tadpoles and the breaking of supersymmetry. Our methodology involves a detailed analysis of the low-energy effective theory of the D6-branes and the computation of instanton-generated Yukawa couplings. Our results show that a realistic model of the Standard Model can be obtained from string theory using the methods of intersecting branes and orientifolds.

human_text: Intersecting stacks of supersymmetric fractional branes on the Z_6' orientifold may be used to construct the supersymmetric Standard Model. If a,b are the stacks that generate the SU(3)_colour and SU(2)_L gauge particles, then, in order to obtain just the chiral spectrum of the (supersymmetric) Standard Model (with non-zero Yukawa couplings to the Higgs mutiplets), it is necessary that the number of intersections a ∩b of the stacks a and b, and the number of intersections a ∩b' of a with the orientifold image b' of b satisfy (a ∩b,a ∩b')=(2,1) or (1,2). It is also necessary that there is no matter in symmetric representations of the gauge group, and not too much matter in antisymmetric representations, on either stack. Fractional branes having all of these properties may be constructed on the Z_6' orientifold. We construct a (four-stack) model with two further stacks, each with just a single brane, which has precisely the matter spectrum of the supersymmetric Standard Model, including a single pair of Higgs doublets. However, the gauge group is SU(3)_colour x SU(2)_L x U(1)_Y x U(1)_H. Only the Higgs doublets are charged with respect to U(1)_H.

machine_text: In this paper, we explore the feasibility of testing string theory with Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) experiments. While the Standard Model of particle physics has been highly successful in explaining the particle physics interactions up to the TeV scale, it falls short of providing a consistent framework for incorporating gravity. String theory, on the other hand, is a theoretical framework that aims to reconcile quantum mechanics and gravity at all energy scales.To test string theory using CMB, we focused on three key predictions of the theory. First, string theory predicts that the universe has extra dimensions beyond our four visible dimensions, which could manifest themselves as distortions in the CMB. Second, the theory predicts the existence of cosmic strings - topological defects formed during the universe's early phase transitions - that could produce gravitational waves affecting the CMB. Finally, string theory predicts the presence of specific patterns in the CMB that could arise from the so-called 'brane inflation'.We simulated CMB maps with these predictions and compared them with the latest Planck data. Our results suggest that the presence of extra dimensions would affect the overall CMB power spectrum, while cosmic strings could leave imprints in the CMB temperature and polarization maps. We also found that brane inflation could leave detectable signatures in the CMB temperature and polarization maps in the form of specific patterns.In conclusion, we demonstrate that CMB experiments can provide a powerful tool for testing string theory predictions and potentially provide indirect evidence for the existence of extra dimensions, cosmic strings, and brane inflation.

Current limit on the ratio of tensor to scalar perturbations, r=T/S, is r < 0.3, future detection may take place for r > 10^-2-10^-3. At present all known string theory inflation models predict tensor modes well below the level of detection. Therefore a possible experimental discovery of tensor modes may present a challenge to string cosmology.The strongest bound on r in string inflation follows from the observation that in most of the models based on the KKLT construction, the value of the Hubble constant H during inflation must be smaller than the gravitino mass. For the gravitino mass in the usual range, m_3/2 < O(1) TeV, this leads to an extremely strong bound r < 10^-24. A discovery of tensor perturbations with r > 10^-3 would imply that the gravitinos in this class of models are superheavy, m_3/2 > 10^13 GeV. This would have important implications for particle phenomenology based on string theory.

human_text: The paper is devoted to classification problem of finite dimensional complex none Lie filiform Leibniz algebras. Actually, the observations show there are two resources to get classification of filiform Leibniz algebras. The first of them is naturally graded none Lie filiform Leibniz algebras and the another one is naturally graded filiform Lie algebras. Using the first resource we get two disjoint classes of filiform Leibniz algebras. The present paper deals with the second of the above two classes, the first class has been considered in our previous paper. The algebraic classification here means to specify the representatives of the orbits, whereas the geometric classification is the problem of finding generic structural constants in the sense of algebraic geometry. Our main effort in this paper is the algebraic classification. We suggest here an algebraic method based on invariants. Utilizing this method for any given low dimensional case all filiform Leibniz algebras can be classified. Moreover, the results can be used for geometric classification of orbits of such algebras.

human_text: We report on follow-up observations of the GRB 060927 using the ROTSE-IIIa telescope and a suite of larger aperture ground-based telescopes. An optical afterglow was detected 20 s after the burst, the earliest rest-frame detection of optical emission from any GRB. Spectroscopy performed with the VLT about 13 hours after the trigger shows a continuum break at lambda8070 A produced by neutral hydrogen absorption at z 5.6. We also detect an absorption line at 8158 A which we interpret as SiII at z=5.467. Hence, GRB 060927 is the second most distant GRB with a spectroscopically measured redshift. The shape of the red wing of the spectral break can be fitted by a damped Lyalpha profile with a column density with log(N_HI/cm^-2)22.5. We discuss the implications of this work for the use of GRBs as probes of the end of the dark ages and draw three main conclusions: i) GRB afterglows originating from z>6 should be relatively easy to detect from the ground, but rapid NIR monitoring is necessary to ensure that they are found; ii) The presence of large HI column densities in some GRBs host galaxies at z>5 makes the use of GRBs to probe the reionization epoch via spectroscopy of the red damping wing challenging; iii) GRBs appear crucial to locate typical star-forming galaxies at z>5 and therefore the type of galaxies responsible for the reionization of the universe.

human_text: A general theory of innovation and progress in human society is outlined, based on the combat between two opposite forces (conservatism/inertia and speculative herding 'bubble' behavior). We contend that human affairs are characterized by ubiquitous “bubbles”, which involve huge risks which would not otherwise be taken using standard cost/benefit analysis. Bubbles result from self-reinforcing positive feedbacks. This leads to explore uncharted territories and niches whose rare successes lead to extraordinary discoveries and provide the base for the observed accelerating development of technology and of the economy. But the returns are very heterogeneous, very risky and may not occur. In other words, bubbles, which are characteristic definitions of human activity, allow huge risks to get huge returns over large scales. We outline some underlying mathematical structure and a few results involving positive feedbacks, emergence, heavy-tailed power laws, outliers/kings/black swans, the problem of predictability and the illusion of control, as well as some policy implications.

machine_text: In this study, we present the metallicity gradient of the nearby spiral galaxy M 33, based on the chemical abundances of HII regions obtained from long-slit optical spectroscopy. The metallicity gradient is a fundamental property of spiral galaxies, reflecting their chemical evolution and star formation history. However, the nature of the metallicity gradient in M 33 has been controversial, with some studies suggesting a steep gradient and others suggesting a flat gradient or even an inverse gradient.Our results show that M 33 has a mild negative metallicity gradient, with a slope of -0.034 dex/kpc. The metallicity gradient is steeper in the inner part of the galaxy than in the outer part, consistent with the idea of inside-out disk growth. We also find that the metallicity gradient flattens beyond a galactocentric radius of 3 kpc, which may indicate the transition from disk-dominated to halo-dominated regions.The main motivation for this research is to better understand the chemical enrichment history of M 33 and its relation to other spiral galaxies. The metallicity gradient is a key diagnostic of the interplay between gas inflow, star formation, and gas outflow in disk galaxies. Our results provide new insights into the evolution of M 33 and its role in the broader context of galaxy formation and evolution.

human_text: We present spectroscopic observations of a sample of 72 emission-line objects, including mainly HII regions, in the spiral galaxy M 33. Spectra were obtained with the multi-object, wide field spectrograph AF2/WYFFOS at the 4.2m WHT telescope. Line intensities, extinction, and electron density were determined for the whole sample of objects. The aim of the present work was to derive chemical and physical parameters of a set of HII regions, and from them the metallicity gradient. Electron temperatures and chemical abundances were derived for the 14 HII regions where both [OII] and [OIII] emission line fluxes were measured, including the electron temperature sensitive emission line [OIII] 436.3 nm and in a few cases [NII] 575.5 nm. The ionization correction factor (ICF) method was used to derive the total chemical abundances. The presence of abundance gradients was inferred from the radial behaviour of several emission-line ratios, and accurately measured from chemical abundances directly derived in 14 HII regions. The oxygen abundances of our HII regions, located in the radial region from2 to7.2 kpc, gave an oxygen gradient -0.054+/-0.011 dex/kpc The overall oxygen gradient for M 33 obtained using ours and previous oxygen determinations in a large number of HII regions with direct electron temperature determination as well as abundance in young stars presented a two slope shape: -0.19 dex/kpc for the central regions (R<3kpc), and -0.038dex/kpc for the outer regions (R>=3kpc).

machine_text: In this paper, we present optimal bounds for the Green function of half-spaces for the relativistic α-stable process. The main goal of this work is to develop an understanding of the behavior of the Green function of the half-space for this particular type of process.The motivation behind this research stems from the fact that the Green function is a fundamental quantity in the study of stochastic processes, and understanding its properties is central in harmonizing various areas of mathematical analysis. In addition, the α-stable process is a well-known stochastic process in signal processing, finance, and physics, and developing optimal bounds for its Green function has the potential to shed new light on its statistical and spatial properties.The key idea in our work is to construct two-sided bounds for the Green function using refined estimates for potentials of signed measures. These bounds provide a more precise estimate of the behavior of the Green function close to the boundary and reveal important new asymptotic regimes. Our methodology involves delicate analysis of positive and negative potentials of suitable measures and careful control of the constants arising in the estimates.Overall, our work is a significant contribution to the study of α-stable processes and has the potential to impact a wide range of fields where these processes arise.

human_text: The purpose of this paper is to find optimal estimates for the Green function of a half-space of the relativistic α-stable process with parameter m onspace. This process has an infinitesimal generator of the form mI-(m^2/αI-Δ)^α/2, where 0<α<2, m>0, and reduces to the isotropic α-stable process for m=0. Its potential theory for open bounded sets has been well developed throughout the recent years however almost nothing was known about the behaviour of the process on unbounded sets. The present paper is intended to fill this gap and we provide two-sided sharp estimates for the Green function for a half-space. As a byproduct we obtain some improvements of the estimates known for bounded sets specially for balls. The advantage of these estimates is a clarification of the relationship between the diameter of the ball and the parameter m of the process.The main result states that the Green function is comparable with the Green function for the Brownian motion if the points are away from the boundary of a half-space and their distance is greater than one. On the other hand for the remaining points the Green function is somehow related the Green function for the isotropic α-stable process. For example, for d≥3, it is comparable with the Green function for the isotropic α-stable process, provided that the points are close enough.

machine_text: In this paper, we present the results of the study of molecular gas in the nucleus of NGC4569, a galaxy presenting a strong bar feature. This research was conducted as part of the Molecular gas in NUclei of GAlaxies (NUGA) VII project. The motivation for this work stems from the need to understand the role of gas inflow in the formation and evolution of galactic nuclei. Previous studies have suggested that gas is transported towards the nuclear region through spiral arms and bars and plays a crucial role in triggering starburst activity.Our aim was to investigate the distribution and kinematics of molecular gas in the nucleus of NGC4569. Through observations with the IRAM-30m telescope, we obtained maps of the CO(1–0) and CO(2–1) emission lines. We observed a strong concentration of molecular gas at the center of the galaxy, coincident with the nucleus. We also observed a clear velocity gradient along the major axis of the galaxy, consistent with gas inflow towards the nucleus.Our findings provide further evidence for the crucial role of bar-driven gas inflows towards the nucleus of galaxies. Our work adds to the understanding of the mechanisms responsible for the formation and evolution of galactic nuclei, with implications for our understanding of the evolution of galaxies as a whole.

Furthermore, we observed a strong concentration of molecular gas at the center of the galaxy, coincident with the nucleus; we also observed a clear velocity gradient along the major axis of the galaxy, which was consistent with gas inflow towards the nucleus  Our findings provided further evidence for the crucial role of bar-driven gas inflows towards the nucleus of galaxies. In addition to this, our work added to the understanding of the mechanisms responsible for the formation and evolution of galactic nuclei, with implications for our understanding of the evolution of galaxies as a whole; however, we had also shown that previous studies were not sufficient  We had shown that gas inflows are crucial for galaxy evolution, so it was necessary to conduct further research on this topic.
human_text: This work is part of the NUGA survey of CO emission in nearby active galaxies. We present observations of NGC4569, a member of the Virgo Cluster. We analyse the molecular gas distribution and kinematics in the central region and we investigate a possible link to the strong starburst present at the nucleus. 70

machine_text: In this work, we present the first Hubble Space Telescope (HST) Fine Guidance Sensor (FGS) parallax measurements for AM CVn stars. We obtained astrometric data over five consecutive epochs with HST's FGS and used a maximum likelihood estimator to obtain parallax and proper motion measurements. Our study included the two known double-degenerate pulsating systems, HP Librae and V396 Herculis, and one non-pulsating AM CVn star, SDSS J1240-01. Our results show precise parallaxes of 3.91 ± 0.10 mas, 4.25 ± 0.09 mas, and 7.18 ± 0.60 mas, respectively, providing the first direct distance estimates to these systems.From these parallax measurements, we calculated the absolute magnitudes and inferred the masses of the components in the systems. Combining these with radial velocity observations, we derived the inclination angles and masses more accurately, enabling us to place the systems on the mass-transfer tracks. Our study shows that HP Lib and V396 Her have a high mass ratio and are close to the minimum period expected for AM CVn systems. Furthermore, SDSS J1240-01 has a mass ratio close to unity, implying that it is an intermediate polar candidate. We also discuss the implications of our results on the theoretical models of AM CVn systems and the production of gravitational waves. Our study provides an important step towards a more complete understanding of the AM CVn population and their astrophysical consequences.

human_text: We present absolute parallaxes and relative proper motions for five AM CVn stars, which we obtained using the Fine Guidance Sensors on board the Hubble Space Telescope. Our parallax measurements translate into distances d(AM CVn)=606+135-93 pc, d(HP Lib)=197+14-12 pc, d(CR Boo)=337+44-35 pc, d(V803 Cen)=347+32-27 pc, and d(GP Com)=75+2-2 pc. From these distances we estimate the space density of AM CVn stars and suggest that previous estimates have been too high by about an order of magnitude. We also infer the mass accretion rates which allows us to constrain the masses of the donor stars, and we show that relatively massive, semi-degenerate donor stars are favored in all systems except GP Com. Finally, we give updated estimates for their gravitational-wave signals, relevant for future space missions such as the proposed Laser Interferometer Space Antenna (LISA), based on their distances and the inferred masses of the binary components. We show that all systems but GP Com are excellent candidates for detection with LISA.

machine_text: We present a comprehensive study of the electrical and optical properties of ferromagnetic Cobalt doped Zinc Oxide (ZnO) nanoparticles, exhibiting a metal-insulator transition (MIT). We investigate the effect of Cobalt doping on the electronic structure and magnetic properties of ZnO nanoparticles. We synthesized nanoparticles using a chemical co-precipitation technique and characterized their structural, magnetic, electrical, and optical properties using various techniques. Our electrical transport measurements show a transition from metallic to insulating behavior at a critical temperature. Furthermore, optical measurements indicate that the material's optical properties change as we approach the MIT temperature, revealing a critical behavior that is consistent with a metal-insulator phase transition. Importantly, our results support the observation that the magnetic behavior of the nanoparticles becomes ferromagnetic and persists at high temperatures near the MIT. Finally, our work provides a fundamental understanding of the origin of the MIT in Cobalt doped ZnO nanoparticles, which has significant implications for the development of novel materials with promising spintronics and optoelectronics applications.

human_text: The observed correlation of oxygen vacancies and room temperature ferromagnetic ordering in Co doped ZnO1-o nanoparticles reported earlier (Naeem et al Nanotechnology 17, 2675-2680) has been further explored by transport and optical measurements. In these particles room temperature ferromagnetic ordering had been observed to occur only after annealing in forming gas. In the current work the optical properties have been studied by diffuse reflection spectroscopy in the UV-Vis region and the band gap of the Co doped compositions has been found to decrease with Co addition. Reflections minima are observed at the energies characteristic of Co+2 d-d (tethrahedral symmetry) crystal field transitions, further establishing the presence of Co in substitutional sites. Electrical transport measurements on palletized samples of the nanoparticles show that the effect of a forming gas is to strongly decrease the resistivity with increasing Co concentration. For the air annealed and non-ferromagnetic samples the variation in the resistivity as a function of Co content are opposite to those observed in the particles prepared in forming gas. The ferromagnetic samples exhibit an apparent change from insulator to metal with increasing temperatures for T>380K and this change becomes more pronounced with increasing Co content. The magnetic and resistive behaviors are correlated by considering the model by Calderon et al [M. J. Calderon and S. D. Sarma, Annals of Physics 2007 (Accepted doi: 10.1016/j.aop.2007.01.010] where the ferromagnetism changes from being mediated by polarons in the low temperature insulating region to being mediated by the carriers released from the weakly bound states in the higher temperature metallic region.

machine_text: In this study, we present BVRI surface photometry of ten isolated spiral galaxies and their environment. We aim to explore the physical properties and structural features of these galaxies and to investigate their relationship with the surrounding environment.Our methodology involves analysis of multi-band images obtained from the 2.5-m Isaac Newton Telescope on the Canary Islands. We perform surface brightness profile and color profile analysis to derive characteristic parameters such as scale-length, central surface brightness, color gradient, and inclination angle. Furthermore, we investigate the asymmetry and clumpiness of the galaxies by examining their residual images.We aim to solve the problem of understanding the role of the environment on isolated spiral galaxies and to determine whether their physical properties and structural features are affected by the environment. Our motivation for this research is rooted in the fundamental question of how galaxies evolve and interact with their surroundings. By focusing on isolated spirals, which are not influenced by major mergers or interactions, we can gain valuable insights into the internal processes and environment-driven mechanisms that shape galaxy formation and evolution. Our findings suggest that the outer disks of isolated spirals show different structures depending on the local environment, implying that galaxy evolution is influenced by factors beyond the galaxy itself.

human_text: A release of multicolor broad band (BVRI) photometry for a subsample of 44 isolated spirals drawn from the Catalogue of Isolated Galaxies (CIG) is presented. Total magnitudes and colors at various circular apertures, as well as some global structural/morphological parameters are estimated. Morphology is reevaluated through optical and sharp/filtered R band images, (B-I) color index maps, and archive near-IR JHK images from the Two-Micron Survey. The CAS structural parameters (Concentration, Asymmetry, and Clumpiness) were calculated from the images in each one of the bands. The fraction of galaxies with well identified optical/near-IR bars (SB) is 63

machine_text: In this work, we investigate the signatures of galactic winds around high redshift galaxies. We obtained data from the Keck and Subaru telescopes, including deep imaging and spectroscopy, to identify galaxies at redshifts between 2.2 and 3.5. We then analyzed their spectra to look for evidence of gas outflows, which are thought to play a crucial role in regulating star formation and galaxy evolution.Our results reveal that galactic winds are present in a significant fraction of high-redshift galaxies, with outflow velocities of up to several hundred kilometers per second. We also find that these outflows are more common in galaxies with higher star formation rates and more massive black holes.The problem that this work attempts to solve is understanding the role that galactic winds play in shaping the properties of high-redshift galaxies. These winds are thought to be a key mechanism for regulating star formation, but their properties and prevalence are not yet well understood.Our methodology involves a combination of deep imaging and spectroscopy of high-redshift galaxies, coupled with detailed modeling of their properties and the outflows that they host. We use our observations to constrain the properties of the outflows, including their kinematics, mass, and energy. By examining the relationships between outflow properties and galaxy properties, we aim to shed new light on the physical processes driving galaxy evolution in the early universe.

human_text: We carry out cosmological chemodynamical simulations with different strengths of supernova (SN) feedback and study how galactic winds from star-forming galaxies affect the features of hydrogen (HI) and metal (CIV and OVI) absorption systems in the intergalactic medium at high redshift. We find that the outflows tend to escape to low density regions, and hardly affect the dense filaments visible in HI absorption. As a result, the strength of HI absorption near galaxies is not reduced by galactic winds, but even slightly increases. We also find that a lack of HI absorption for lines of sight (LOS) close to galaxies, as found by Adelberger et al., can be created by hot gas around the galaxies induced by accretion shock heating. In contrast to HI, metal absorption systems are sensitive to the presence of winds. The models without feedback can produce the strong CIV and OVI absorption lines in LOS within 50 kpc from galaxies, while strong SN feedback is capable of creating strong CIV and OVI lines out to about twice that distance. We also analyze the mean transmissivity of HI, CIV, and OVI within 1 h^-1 Mpc from star-forming galaxies. The probability distribution of the transmissivity of HI is independent of the strength of SN feedback, but strong feedback produces LOS with lower transmissivity of metal lines. Additionally, strong feedback can produce strong OVI lines even in cases where HI absorption is weak. We conclude that OVI is probably the best tracer for galactic winds at high redshift.

machine_text: In this work, we investigate the gauge symmetry present in Kitaev-type spin models and index theorems on odd manifolds. Gauge symmetry is a fundamental principle in theoretical physics that plays a crucial role in understanding the behavior of elementary particles and their interactions. The Kitaev model is a well-known quantum spin system that exhibits topological phases of matter and is widely studied in condensed matter physics. Recently, it has been shown that the model possesses nontrivial gauge symmetries that are intimately related to its topological properties.Our research aims to develop a systematic framework to understand the gauge symmetry inside Kitaev-type models. First, we introduce a set of local operators that generate the gauge symmetry and study their algebraic properties. Then, we show that the gauge symmetry is related to the underlying topology of the quantum system and establish a connection with the index theorems on odd manifolds. Lastly, we use our results to construct explicit gauge-invariant operators that can be used to probe the topological properties of the Kitaev model.Our work has important implications for the field of quantum many-body physics and provides a deeper understanding of the interplay between gauge symmetry and topology in condensed matter systems. Moreover, our results pave the way for future applications of Kitaev-type models in topological quantum computing and quantum information processing.

attack_machine_text: We investigated the gauge symmetry present in Kitaev-type spin models and index theorems on odd manifolds; however, researchers had already shown that this model possesses nontrivial gauge symmetries intimately related to its topological properties, which were found to be crucial in understanding elementary particles' behavior. human_text: We construct an exactly soluble spin-1/2 model on a honeycomb lattice, which is a generalization of Kitaev model. The topological phases of the system are analyzed by study of the ground state sector of this model, the vortex-free states. Basically, there are two phases, A phase and B phase. The behaviors of both A and B phases may be studied by mapping the ground state sector into a general p-wave paired states of spinless fermions with tunable pairing parameters on a square lattice. In this p-wave paired state theory, the A phase is shown to be the strong paired phase, an insulating phase. The B phase may be either gapped or gapless determined by the generalized inversion symmetry is broken or not. The gapped B is the weak pairing phase described by either the Moore-Read Pfaffian state of the spinless fermions or anti-Pfaffian state of holes depending on the sign of the next nearest neighbor hopping amplitude. A phase transition between Pfaffian and anti-Pfaffian states are found in the gapped B phase. Furthermore, we show that there is a hidden SU(2) gauge symmetry in our model. In the gapped B phase, the ground state has a non-trivial topological number, the spectral first Chern number or the chiral central charge, which reflects the chiral anomaly of the edge state. We proved that the topological number is identified to the reduced eta-invariant and this anomaly may be cancelled by a bulk Wess-Zumino term of SO(3) group through an index theorem in 2+1 dimensions.

machine_text: In this study, we aim to unveil the morphologies of luminous compact galaxies (LCGs) by analyzing data from the Hubble Space Telescope/Advanced Camera for Surveys (HST/ACS) GOODS survey. The main motivation for this research stems from the lack of understanding of the physical processes that lead to the formation and evolution of these galaxies.Our analysis reveals that LCGs exhibit a wide range of morphological features, including compactness, asymmetry, and clumpy structures, making them distinct from typical disk or elliptical galaxies. Moreover, we found that the majority of LCGs have undergone recent merger events, which could explain the observed features.The study also highlights the importance of high-resolution imaging in understanding the nature of LCGs, as traditional imaging techniques fail to resolve their intricate morphologies. Our findings provide crucial insights into the evolution of LCGs and open up new avenues for further investigation.Overall, this research attempts to solve the problem of uncovering the mechanisms behind the formation and evolution of LCGs. Our results provide a foundation for future studies that aim to explore the physical processes and environmental factors that shape these unique galaxies.

machine_text: In this research, we present an Augmented Sparse Reconstruction (ASR) algorithm for protein signaling network reconstruction. The reconstruction of protein signaling networks is a challenging task due to the complex and dynamic nature of cellular signaling. Existing methods have limited scalability and accuracy in large- scale signaling datasets. ASR aims to address this problem by integrating prior knowledge of signaling pathways and data-driven information from experimental observations.We evaluate ASR on simulated and real-world datasets and compare its performance against state-of-the-art methods. The results demonstrate that ASR yields higher accuracy and network sparsity while achieving faster runtime than existing methods. We also apply ASR to reconstruct human protein signaling networks, and we identify multiple novel pathway interactions and crosstalk between pathways.The motivation for this research stems from the need for an accurate and efficient method for protein signaling network reconstruction, which is crucial for understanding cellular signaling mechanisms and developing effective therapeutic strategies. The proposed ASR algorithm provides a promising approach that can contribute to the advancement of fundamental biological research and clinical applications.

attack_machine_text: We presented an Augmented Sparse Reconstruction (ASR) algorithm for protein signaling network reconstruction, which aimed to address the complex and dynamic nature of cellular signaling that existing methods had limited scalability and accuracy in large-scale signaling datasets. The proposed ASR algorithm integrated prior knowledge of signaling pathways and data-driven information from experimental observations, however, it demonstrated higher accuracy and network sparsity while achieving faster runtime than existing methods on simulated and real-world datasets. Furthermore, we applied ASR to reconstruct human protein signaling networks, and we identified multiple novel pathway interactions and crosstalk between pathways; however, the proposed method was crucial for understanding cellular signaling mechanisms and developing effective therapeutic strategies that were presented by us previously. human_text: The problem of reconstructing and identifying intracellular protein signaling and biochemical networks is of critical importance in biology today. We sought to develop a mathematical approach to this problem using, as a test case, one of the most well-studied and clinically important signaling networks in biology today, the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) driven signaling cascade. More specifically, we suggest a method, augmented sparse reconstruction, for the identification of links among nodes of ordinary differential equation (ODE) networks from a small set of trajectories with different initial conditions. Our method builds a system of representation by using a collection of integrals of all given trajectories and by attenuating block of terms in the representation itself. The system of representation is then augmented with random vectors, and minimization of the 1-norm is used to find sparse representations for the dynamical interactions of each node. Augmentation by random vectors is crucial, since sparsity alone is not able to handle the large error-in-variables in the representation. Augmented sparse reconstruction allows to consider potentially very large spaces of models and it is able to detect with high accuracy the few relevant links among nodes, even when moderate noise is added to the measured trajectories. After showing the performance of our method on a model of the EGFR protein network, we sketch briefly the potential future therapeutic applications of this approach.

machine_text: In this paper, we investigate the spherically symmetric problem on the brane in the context of galactic rotation curves. The problem this work attempts to solve is the discrepancy between Newtonian theory and the observed rotation curves of galaxies. Our goal is to understand if a modified gravity theory is necessary to explain this phenomenon or if it can be explained by the presence of extra dimensions. We analyze the gravitational field equations in the Randall-Sundrum model to derive the modified gravitational potential for a point mass situated on the brane. We then use this potential to calculate the rotation curves for galaxies and compare them to observations. Our results show that the modified gravitational potential is indeed able to explain the observed rotation curves without the need for a modified gravity theory. This finding suggests that the observed discrepancy could be explained by the presence of extra dimensions and the gravity they exert on objects on the brane. Our key ideas and methodology stem from the use of mathematical models and equations to analyze the behavior of galaxies and the gravitational field on the brane.

human_text: We investigate the braneworld model with induced gravity to clarify the role of the cross-over length scale ℓin the possible explanation of the dark-matter phenomenon in astrophysics and in cosmology. Observations of the 21 cm line from neutral hydrogen clouds in spiral galaxies reveal that the rotational velocities remain nearly constant at a value v_c10^-3–10^-4 in the units of the speed of light in the region of the galactic halo. Using the smallness of v_c, we develop a perturbative scheme for reconstructing the metric in a galactic halo. In the leading order of expansion in v_c, at the distances r ≳v_c ℓ, our result reproduces that obtained in the Randall-Sundrum braneworld model. This inequality is satisfied in a real spiral galaxy such as our Milky Way for distances r3 kpc, at which the rotational velocity curve becomes flat, v_c7 ×10^-4, if ℓ≲2 Mpc. The gravitational situation in this case can be approximately described by the Einstein equations with the so-called Weyl fluid playing the role of dark matter. In the region near the gravitating body, we derive a closed system of equations for static spherically symmetric situation under the approximation of zero anisotropic stress of the Weyl fluid. We find the Schwarzschild metric to be an approximate vacuum solution of these equations at distances r ≲(r_g ℓ^2)^1/3. The value ℓ≲2 Mpc complies well with the solar-system tests. At the same time, in cosmology, a low-density braneworld with ℓof this order of magnitude can mimic the expansion properties of the high-density LCDM (lambda + cold dark matter) universe at late times. Combined observations of galactic rotation curves and gravitational lensing can possibly discriminate between the higher-dimensional effects and dark matter.

machine_text: In this paper, we present a comprehensive analysis of the effectiveness of redesigning computer-based learning environments. Our work focuses on the evaluation process as a means of communication within such environments and its impact on learning outcomes. We begin by discussing the need for redesigning computer-based learning environments to increase engagement and motivation of learners. Our methodology involved a systematic review of literature on evaluation of computer-based learning environments, which was followed by empirical studies carried out in a variety of settings. We used a mixed-methods approach, including surveys, qualitative and quantitative analyses, and observations, to collect data and analyze results. Our findings indicate that effective communication through evaluation can significantly enhance instructional design, improve student engagement and increase motivation. Additionally, our work demonstrates that the integration of evaluation as an ongoing process is crucial for ensuring the sustainability and effectiveness of computer-based learning environments. This paper is a call to educators, researchers, and policymakers to consider evaluation as a vital aspect of communication and to embrace it as a strategy for enhancing learning outcomes.

human_text: In the field of evaluation research, computer scientists live constantly upon dilemmas and conflicting theories. As evaluation is differently perceived and modeled among educational areas, it is not difficult to become trapped in dilemmas, which reflects an epistemological weakness. Additionally, designing and developing a computer-based learning scenario is not an easy task. Advancing further, with end-users probing the system in realistic settings, is even harder. Computer science research in evaluation faces an immense challenge, having to cope with contributions from several conflicting and controversial research fields. We believe that deep changes must be made in our field if we are to advance beyond the CBT (computer-based training) learning model and to build an adequate epistemology for this challenge. The first task is to relocate our field by building upon recent results from philosophy, psychology, social sciences, and engineering. In this article we locate evaluation in respect to communication studies. Evaluation presupposes a definition of goals to be reached, and we suggest that it is, by many means, a silent communication between teacher and student, peers, and institutional entities. If we accept that evaluation can be viewed as set of invisible rules known by nobody, but somehow understood by everybody, we should add anthropological inquiries to our research toolkit. The paper is organized around some elements of the social communication and how they convey new insights to evaluation research for computer and related scientists. We found some technical limitations and offer discussions on how we relate to technology at same time we establish expectancies and perceive others work.

machine_text: In this work, we apply wavelet transforms to analyze the Barkhausen noise signal in a critical interface model. Barkhausen noise refers to the stochastic fluctuations of magnetic domains in ferromagnetic materials. The goal of our research is to better understand the properties of the Barkhausen noise signal in order to develop improved techniques for non-destructive evaluation of materials.The critical interface model is a theoretical framework for describing the dynamics of a material's magnetic domains during the magnetic field-induced Barkhausen effect. We use numerical simulations to generate synthetic Barkhausen noise signals within this framework. The wavelet transform is then applied to these signals to extract useful features, such as the decay rate of the signal's power spectrum.Our methodology involves comparing the results of wavelet transforms applied to simulated Barkhausen noise signals in the critical interface model with those from experimental data. We find that the wavelet approach significantly improves the resolution of the Barkhausen noise signal, allowing us to extract additional information.This work is motivated by the desire to improve the efficiency and accuracy of non-destructive testing methods. The ability to extract more information from the Barkhausen noise signal could lead to improvements in the detection and characterization of defects in materials. Additionally, our approach provides a new perspective on the interpretation of Barkhausen noise signals in terms of criticality and scaling.

human_text: We discuss the application of wavelet transforms to a critical interface model, which is known to provide a good description of Barkhausen noise in soft ferromagnets. The two-dimensional version of the model (one-dimensional interface) is considered, mainly in the adiabatic limit of very slow driving. On length scales shorter than a crossover length (which grows with the strength of surface tension), the effective interface roughness exponent ζ is ≃ 1.20, close to the expected value for the universality class of the quenched Edwards-Wilkinson model. We find that the waiting times between avalanches are fully uncorrelated, as the wavelet transform of their autocorrelations scales as white noise. Similarly, detrended size-size correlations give a white-noise wavelet transform. Consideration of finite driving rates, still deep within the intermittent regime, shows the wavelet transform of correlations scaling as 1/f^1.5 for intermediate frequencies. This behavior is ascribed to intra-avalanche correlations.

machine_text: In this work, we present an analysis of Spitzer mid-infrared (MIR) spectroscopy data for a sample of 45 infrared luminous galaxies with redshifts around z 2. The aim of our study is to investigate the properties of ionized gas, dust, and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH) features as diagnostic tools for star formation and active galactic nuclei (AGN) in high-redshift galaxies. Our sample includes both star-forming and AGN-dominated galaxies, which we classified through the analysis of their optical spectra and X-ray data.We found that the ratio of the [NeIII]15.56μm to [NeII]12.81μm lines, the EW of the 6.2μm PAH feature, and the strength of the 9.7μm silicate absorption can be used as good diagnostics for AGN activity in these galaxies. We also found that the [NeIII]/[NeII] ratio is correlated with the AGN luminosity and the hardness of the X-ray spectrum. Furthermore, the EW of the 6.2μm PAH feature is correlated with the star formation rate and the metallicity of the galaxies. Our results suggest that MIR spectroscopy can be a powerful tool for diagnosing the nature of high-redshift galaxies and distinguishing between AGN and star formation activity.

machine_text: In this study, we investigate the presence of submilliJansky (submJy) transients in archival radio observations. The importance of identifying such low-flux sources lies in the potential to gain insights into the early universe, as submJy sources are likely to be at high redshift. It is challenging to detect these transients due to the faintness of the sources and high levels of noise in the data. Hence, we develop a sensitive image processing method to better detect submJy transients in archival data from the Janskys Very Large Array (VLA). Our work attempts to solve the problem of low signal-to-noise ratios in archival data, which could potentially cause the exclusion of these crucial sources in previous surveys.The results show that our method improves the detection and characterization of submJy transients in archival VLA data. We find multiple new submJy transients that were previously undetected in the images. By comparing the newly detected sources with those from optical and X-ray catalogs, we find evidence of associations between some submJy transients and active galactic nuclei, whereas others are likely to be star-forming galaxies. Our study demonstrates the successful application of a novel and sensitive image processing method to archival radio data, providing a new window to explore the early universe.

human_text: [ABRIDGED] We report the results of a 944-epoch survey for transient sources with archival data from the Very Large Array spanning 22 years with a typical epoch separation of 7 days. Observations were obtained at 5 or 8.4 GHz for a single field of view with a full-width at half-maximum of 8.6' and 5.1', respectively, and achieved a typical point-source detection threshold at the beam center of300 microJy per epoch. Ten transient sources were detected with a significance threshold such that only one false positive would be expected. Of these transients, eight were detected in only a single epoch. Two transients were too faint to be detected in individual epochs but were detected in two-month averages. None of the ten transients was detected in longer-term averages or associated with persistent emission in the deep image produced from the combination of all epochs. The cumulative rate for the short timescale radio transients above 370 microJy at 5 and 8.4 GHz is 0.07 < R < 40 deg^-2 yr^-1, where the uncertainty is due to the unknown duration of the transients, 20 min < t_char < 7 days. A two-epoch survey for transients will detect 1.5 +/- 0.4 transient per square degrees above a flux density of 370 microJy. Two transients are associated with galaxies at z=0.040 and z=0.249. These may be similar to the peculiar Type Ib/c radio supernova SN 1998bw associated with GRB 980428. Six transients have no counterparts in the optical or infrared (R=27, Ks=18). The hosts and progenitors of these transients are unknown.

human_text: The properties of certain networks are determined by hidden variables that are not explicitly measured. The conditional probability (propagator) that a vertex with a given value of the hidden variable is connected to k of other vertices determines all measurable properties. We study hidden variable models and find an averaging approximation that enables us to obtain a general analytical result for the propagator. Analytic results showing the validity of the approximation are obtained. We apply hidden variable models to protein-protein interaction networks (PINs) in which the hidden variable is the association free-energy, determined by distributions that depend on biochemistry and evolution. We compute degree distributions as well as clustering coefficients of several PINs of different species; good agreement with measured data is obtained. For the human interactome two different parameter sets give the same degree distributions, but the computed clustering coefficients differ by a factor of about two. This shows that degree distributions are not sufficient to determine the properties of PINs.

machine_text: Our work, the Gemini Deep Planet Survey (GDPS), is a multi-year effort designed to acquire high-resolution images of young, nearby stars in search of young planets. The motivation for this research is the quest to understand the origins of planetary systems and the underlying physical processes that drive their formation, evolution, and diversity. In particular, we seek to address fundamental questions regarding the frequency of planet formation, the diversity of planetary architectures, and the roles of various factors such as stellar mass, metallicity, and companionship in shaping planetary systems.Key ideas and methodologies in GDPS include advanced adaptive optics techniques, high-contrast imaging, and careful data processing and analysis. Using the Gemini North telescope and accompanying advanced instrumentation, we obtain deep, high-resolution images of young stars and their surrounding environments, allowing us to accurately detect and characterize faint planetary signals.Ultimately, GDPS aims to provide new insights into the complex and diverse nature of planetary systems, furthering our understanding of the origins and evolution of planets and their role in shaping the habitability of our universe. By characterizing the planetary populations of young stars, we hope to inform future studies of exoplanet atmospheres, habitability, and potential for life.

human_text: We present the results of the Gemini Deep Planet Survey, a near-infrared adaptive optics search for giant planets and brown dwarfs around nearby young stars. The observations were obtained with the Altair adaptive optics system at the Gemini North telescope and angular differential imaging was used to suppress the speckle noise of the central star. Detection limits for the 85 stars observed are presented, along with a list of all faint point sources detected around them. Typically, the observations are sensitive to angular separations beyond 0.5' with 5-sigma contrast sensitivities in magnitude difference at 1.6 micron of 9.5 at 0.5', 12.9 at 1', 15.0 at 2', and 16.5 at 5'. For the typical target of the survey, a 100 Myr old K0 star located 22 pc from the Sun, the observations are sensitive enough to detect planets more massive than 2 Mjup with a projected separation in the range 40-200 AU. Second epoch observations of 48 stars with candidates (out of 54) have confirmed that all candidates are unrelated background stars. A detailed statistical analysis of the survey results, yielding upper limits on the fractions of stars with giant planet or low mass brown dwarf companions, is presented. machine_text: In this work, we investigate the magnetorotational collapse of Population III stars, focusing on the effects of rotation, magnetic fields, and gravitational instability. The collapse of massive stars represents a key process in the formation of black holes and the evolution of galaxies. However, the exact mechanisms involved in the collapse of the first generation of stars, known as Population III stars, remain poorly understood. We aim to address this knowledge gap by carrying out a series of numerical simulations, considering a range of initial conditions and physical parameters. Our work builds on previous research in this area, which has highlighted the importance of rotation and magnetic fields in shaping the dynamics of the collapse. We use the numerical hydrodynamics code FLASH, which incorporates both magnetohydrodynamics and radiation transport with adaptive mesh refinement. Through this approach, we are able to track the evolution of the collapsing star in three dimensions, capturing the complex interplay between rotation, magnetic fields, and turbulence. Our results shed new light on the key physical processes involved in Population III star formation and underline the importance of magnetorotational effects in shaping the structure and evolution of the first stars.

human_text: We perform a series of two-dimensional magnetorotational core-collapse simulations of Pop III stars. Changing the initial distributions of rotation and magnetic fields prior to collapse in a parametric manner, we compute 19 models. By so doing, we systematically investigate how rotation and magnetic fields affect the collapse dynamics and explore how the properties of the black-hole formations and neutrino emissions could be affected. As for the microphysics, we employ a realistic equation of state and approximate the neutrino transfer by a multiflavour leakage scheme. With these computations, we find that the jet-like explosions are obtained by the magnetodriven shock waves if the initial magnetic field is as large as 10^12 G. We point out that the black-hole masses at the formation decrease with the initial field strength, on the other hand, increase with the initial rotation rates. As for the neutrino properties, we point out that the degree of the differential rotation plays an important role to determine which species of the neutrino luminosity is more dominant than the others. Furthermore, we find that the stronger magnetic fields make the peak neutrino luminosities smaller, because the magnetic pressure acts to halt the collapse in the central regions, leading to the suppression of the releasable gravitational binding energies.

machine_text: In our research, we deal with the complexity of model checking higher-order fixpoint logic. The main motivation for this study is the need to develop more effective algorithmic tools for checking complex systems. Model checking is a process that allows verifying if a system satisfies a given specification. It is widely used in computer science and engineering for the verification of hardware and software systems. However, the model checking process becomes challenging when the system specifications are formulated in a higher-order fixpoint logic, which deals with recursive definitions of predicates and functions.In this research, we aim to develop efficient algorithms for model checking higher-order fixpoint logic by investigating the structural properties of the logic. One of our key contributions is the development of a reduction technique that allows reducing the model checking problem to a simpler subset of the logic. This technique is based on a novel notion of well-quasi-ordering, which captures the structural properties of the logic.To demonstrate the usefulness and effectiveness of our techniques, we apply them to verify several benchmark systems. Our results show a significant improvement in the performance of the model checking process compared to existing techniques. This research has important implications for the development of more effective algorithmic tools for verifying complex systems, which are essential for ensuring the correctness and reliability of modern computer-based applications.

human_text: Higher-Order Fixpoint Logic (HFL) is a hybrid of the simply typed λ-calculus and the modal λ-calculus. This makes it a highly expressive temporal logic that is capable of expressing various interesting correctness properties of programs that are not expressible in the modal λ-calculus.This paper provides complexity results for its model checking problem. In particular we consider those fragments of HFL built by using only types of bounded order k and arity m. We establish k-fold exponential time completeness for model checking each such fragment. For the upper bound we use fixpoint elimination to obtain reachability games that are singly-exponential in the size of the formula and k-fold exponential in the size of the underlying transition system. These games can be solved in deterministic linear time. As a simple consequence, we obtain an exponential time upper bound on the expression complexity of each such fragment.The lower bound is established by a reduction from the word problem for alternating (k-1)-fold exponential space bounded Turing Machines. Since there are fixed machines of that type whose word problems are already hard with respect to k-fold exponential time, we obtain, as a corollary, k-fold exponential time completeness for the data complexity of our fragments of HFL, provided m exceeds 3. This also yields a hierarchy result in expressive power.

machine_text: In this paper, we explore the signatures of Supersymmetric (SUSY) Dark Matter particles in the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) and Cosmic Ray spectra. The motivation for this research lies in the fact that the existence of Dark Matter in the universe is well-established through various astrophysical observations. However, the nature of Dark Matter is still unknown, and its constituents are yet to be identified. SUSY is one of the most attractive theories that could explain the existence of Dark Matter.We aim to investigate the possibility of detecting SUSY Dark Matter particles within the LHC. To achieve this, we employ the Monte Carlo simulations to simulate the events that are expected to result from SUSY Dark Matter. The simulations reveal characteristic signals of these particles, which can be detected by the LHC experiments.Additionally, we explore the signatures left by cosmic ray particles that could be associated with the presence of SUSY Dark Matter. We analyze the spectra of cosmic rays to detect any significant excess that correlates with the expected signal from SUSY Dark Matter.Our study aims to contribute to the ongoing search for SUSY Dark Matter particles by establishing the experimental signatures that could verify the existence of these particles. Our methodology involves a combination of both theoretical and experimental approaches, making use of the cutting-edge technology in collider physics and cosmic ray research.

human_text: This thesis discusses the search for supersymmetry at the future Large Hadron Collider (LHC) and the ongoing construction of one of the four large LHC experiments, the Compact Muon Solenoid (CMS), and focuses on the detection of signals from the annihilation of supersymmetric dark matter in the spectra of cosmic rays.Measurements of cosmic ray antiparticles, such as positrons, can impose strong constraints on the nature of new physics beyond the Standard Model. However, cosmic ray positron measurements are experimentally very challenging due to the vast proton background. A novel approach of positron identification with the space-borne AMS-01 experiment, namely through the detection of bremsstrahlung conversion in a silicon microstrip detector, is introduced. Bremsstrahlung from protons is suppressed by a factor of more than 3*10^6 with respect to positrons. The results of the positron measurement show that the bremsstrahlung approach extends the sensitivity range of AMS-01 to positron momenta up to 50 GeV/c, which is far beyond the original scope of the experiment. At momenta above 8 GeV/c there is indication for a positron overabundance with respect to model predictions for purely secondary positron production. Therefore, the AMS-01 data lend further weight to the hints of a positron overabundance seen in the data from earlier experiments.The positron fraction measurements from the most recent experiments are combined with the results of this analysis, giving the most precise positron fraction data yet available.

machine_text: In this work, we investigate the dynamics of mean-field spin glasses using the replica-exchange Monte Carlo (REM) algorithm. The main idea behind this work is to explore the universality of the REM algorithm across different mean-field spin glass models. The REM algorithm, which is a variant of the standard Monte Carlo algorithm, allows for the efficient sampling of the energy landscape of a given system by using multiple replicas of the system at different temperatures.We focus specifically on the Edwards-Anderson model, the Sherrington-Kirkpatrick model, and the three-dimensional Ising spin glass model. The main problem that this work attempts to solve is understanding how the universality of the REM algorithm affects the dynamics of these different models, and whether the results obtained are consistent with previous studies.Our motivation for this research stems from the fact that a better understanding of the dynamics of mean-field spin glasses is crucial for a wide range of applications in materials science and statistical physics. The REM algorithm has been shown to be an effective tool in studying the dynamics of spin glasses, and our work aims to further explore its universality across different models. Our results indicate that the REM algorithm is indeed universal in its behavior, and that it can be used to accurately study the dynamics of mean-field spin glasses.
