human_text: We consider a version of a Glauber dynamics for a p-spin Sherrington–Kirkpatrick model of a spin glass that can be seen as a time change of simple random walk on the N-dimensional hypercube. We show that, for any p>2 and any inverse temperature β>0, there exist constants g>0, such that for all exponential time scales, exp(γ N), with γ< g, the properly rescaled clock process (time-change process), converges to an α-stable subordinator where α=γ/β^2<1. Moreover, the dynamics exhibits aging at these time scales with time-time correlation function converging to the arcsine law of this α-stable subordinator. In other words, up to rescaling, on these time scales (that are shorter than the equilibration time of the system), the dynamics of p-spin models ages in the same way as the REM, and by extension Bouchaud's REM-like trap model, confirming the latter as a universal aging mechanism for a wide range of systems. The SK model (the case p=2) seems to belong to a different universality class.

machine_text: In this work, we present the summary of XMM-Newton observations of the first unidentified TeV gamma-ray source, TeV J2032+4130. The source of very high-energy gamma-rays was discovered by the H.E.S.S. experiment and located in the Cygnus region of our galaxy. A deep archival search in X-ray archives revealed a faint point source at the position of the TeV emission, hence, we carried out subsequent X-ray observations with the XMM-Newton observatory to explore the nature of the source.Our research motivation was to identify the nature of this enigmatic source and determine if it is an active galactic nucleus or a pulsar wind nebula. We analyzed the XMM-Newton data, including spectral and timing analysis, to provide insight into the nature of the X-ray emitting source. Our results from the data analysis revealed a hard X-ray spectrum with an unabsorbed flux of6.3×10^-14 erg cm^-2 s^-1 over the energy range of 2-10 keV. We also found a significant pulsation signal with a period of 143.6 ms, suggesting a strongly magnetic, rotating neutron star. Overall, our results suggest that TeV J2032+4130 is likely a pulsar wind nebula associated with a young, fast-rotating and strongly magnetized neutron star.

human_text: (abridged) The first unidentified very high energy gamma ray source (TeV J2032+4130) in the Cygnus region has been the subject of intensive search for a counterpart source at other wavelengths. A deep (≈ 50 ksec) exposure of TeV J2032+4130 with XMM-Newton has been obtained. The contribution of point sources to the observed X-ray emission from TeV J2032+4130 is subtracted from the data. The point-source subtracted X-ray data are analyzed using blank sky exposures and regions adjacent to the position of TeV J2032+4130 in the field of view covered by the XMM-Newton telescopes to search for diffuse X-ray emission. An extended X-ray emission region with a full width half maximum (FWHM) size of ≈ 12 arc min is found. The centroid of the emission is co-located with the position of TeV J2032+4130.The energy spectrum of the emission coinciding with the position and extension of TeV J2032+4130 can be modeled by a power-law model with a photon index Γ=1.5±0.2_stat±0.3_sys and an energy flux integrated between 2 and 10 keV of f_2-10 keV≈ 7· 10^-13 ergs/(cm^2 s) which is lower than the very high energy gamma-ray flux observed from TeV J2032+4130. We conclude that the faint extended X-ray emission discovered in this observation is the X-ray counterpart of TeV J2032+4130. Formally, it can not be excluded that the extended emission is due to an unrelated population of faint, hot (k_BT≈ 10 keV) unresolved point-sources which by chance coincides with the position and extension of TeV J2032+4130. We discuss our findings in the frame of both hadronic and leptonic gamma-ray production scenarios.

machine_text_attack_prompt:
Our research aimed to enhance the lifetime of wireless sensor networks (WSNs) with the collaborative beamforming and cooperative transmission (CBCT) approach. WSNs have a limited lifespan due to their battery constraints, and in many cases, replacing them is not practical. Therefore, extending the lifetime of WSN is of great importance.   We proposed a novel CBCT approach that combines two techniques, collaboration among sensor nodes and beamforming. The proposed approach optimizes the energy efficiency of the network by reducing the energy consumption of each node. The CBCT approach also makes the transmission more reliable and resilient against interferences and obstacles.   Our experimental simulations showed that the proposed CBCT method could improve the network's lifetime by nearly 20% compared to traditional techniques. Additionally, our results showed that our approach outperformed existing solutions in terms of reliability, energy consumption, and network lifetime. human_text: Extending network lifetime of battery-operated devices is a key design issue that allows uninterrupted information exchange among distributive nodes in wireless sensor networks. Collaborative beamforming (CB) and cooperative transmission (CT) have recently emerged as new communication techniques that enable and leverage effective resource sharing among collaborative/cooperative nodes. In this paper, we seek to maximize the lifetime of sensor networks by using the new idea that closely located nodes can use CB/CT to reduce the load or even avoid packet forwarding requests to nodes that have critical battery life. First, we study the effectiveness of CB/CT to improve the signal strength at a faraway destination using energy in nearby nodes. Then, a 2D disk case is analyzed to assess the resulting performance improvement. For general networks, if information-generation rates are fixed, the new routing problem is formulated as a linear programming problem; otherwise, the cost for routing is dynamically adjusted according to the amount of energy remaining and the effectiveness of CB/CT. From the analysis and simulation results, it is seen that the proposed schemes can improve the lifetime by about 90

machine_text: In this study, we present the Evolutionary Neural Gas (ENG) model, which aims to provide a novel way of generating self-organizing neural networks from input categorization. The motivation for this research stems from the need to develop efficient and adaptable unsupervised learning techniques in artificial intelligence, particularly those that can handle the complexity of high-dimensional data.The proposed model is an extension of the Neural Gas algorithm, where the structure and topology of the network are continually evolving based on genetic operators, such as crossover and mutation. We evaluated our model on several benchmark datasets and compared it with other state-of-the-art self-organizing neural network models. The results indicate that the ENG model can provide superior performance in terms of clustering accuracy and classification accuracy, particularly with highly complex datasets.The main problem that this work attempts to solve is the issue of scalability and adaptivity in self-organizing neural networks, particularly in high-dimensional and dynamic data environments. With ENG, we provide a novel and efficient approach to create robust and flexible models that can handle complex data distributions, while also being adaptable to changes in the input patterns.In conclusion, the proposed ENG model presents a promising solution for unsupervised learning problems in artificial intelligence, particularly for tasks that require efficient and adaptable clustering and classification of high-dimensional data.

human_text: Despite their claimed biological plausibility, most self organizing networks have strict topological constraints and consequently they cannot take into account a wide range of external stimuli. Furthermore their evolution is conditioned by deterministic laws which often are not correlated with the structural parameters and the global status of the network, as it should happen in a real biological system. In nature the environmental inputs are noise affected and fuzzy. Which thing sets the problem to investigate the possibility of emergent behaviour in a not strictly constrained net and subjected to different inputs. It is here presented a new model of Evolutionary Neural Gas (ENG) with any topological constraints, trained by probabilistic laws depending on the local distortion errors and the network dimension. The network is considered as a population of nodes that coexist in an ecosystem sharing local and global resources. Those particular features allow the network to quickly adapt to the environment, according to its dimensions. The ENG model analysis shows that the net evolves as a scale-free graph, and justifies in a deeply physical sense- the term gas here used.

machine_text: In this work, we present our analysis of the B->D πdecays with a focus on CP violation, using the Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) approach. The primary goal of our work is to identify the sources of CP violation in these decays and to determine whether they agree with the Standard Model predictions.To achieve this, we use the QCD factorization method, which allows us to factorize the decay amplitude into two parts: a hard-scattering kernel and a set of soft hadronic matrix elements. We calculate these matrix elements using non-perturbative techniques, such as lattice QCD simulations and light-cone sum rules.We then perform a phenomenological analysis of the B->D πdecays using these QCD factorization calculations. Our results indicate that the CP violating observables are sensitive to the strong phases of the hadronic matrix elements, which can lead to new physics contributions. We find that the Standard Model predictions for CP asymmetries in these decays are consistent with our calculations, within the current experimental uncertainties.Overall, our work offers a comprehensive QCD-based analysis of the B->D πdecays and provides a valuable tool to understand CP violation in these processes. We hope that our findings will stimulate further experimental studies of these decays, to provide a more accurate determination of CP violation parameters and to search for new physics beyond the Standard Model.

human_text: The branching ratios and CP violations of the B→ Dπ decays, including both the color-allowed and the color-suppressed modes, are investigated in detail within QCD framework by considering all diagrams which lead to three effective currents of two quarks. An intrinsic mass scale as a dynamical gluon mass is introduced to treat the infrared divergence caused by the soft collinear approximation in the endpoint regions, and the Cutkosky rule is adopted to deal with a physical-region singularity of the on mass-shell quark propagators. When the dynamical gluon mass μ_g is regarded as a universal scale, it is extracted to be around μ_g = 440 MeV from one of the well-measured B→ Dπ decay modes. The resulting predictions for all branching ratios are in agreement with the current experimental measurements. As these decays have no penguin contributions, there are no direct CP asymmetries. Due to interference between the Cabibbo-suppressed and the Cabibbo-favored amplitudes, mixing-induced CP violations are predicted in the B→ D^±π^∓ decays to be consistent with the experimental data at 1-σ level. More precise measurements will be helpful to extract weak angle 2β+γ.

machine_text: In this study, we propose an adaptive strategy for the classification of G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs), which represent a vital class of transmembrane proteins that play an essential role in diverse physiological processes. Upon activation by an extracellular ligand, GPCRs activate intracellular signaling pathways mediated by G-proteins, which in turn, regulate various cellular functions. Due to their significant role in cellular signaling, GPCRs present potential targets for drug development. However, the vast number of GPCRs, coupled with their high structural diversity, pose a significant challenge in predicting their biological functions and designing drugs.Our work attempts to solve the problem of accurately classifying GPCRs based on their primary amino acid sequences. We used a combination of feature extraction techniques and machine learning algorithms to create an adaptive classifier capable of accommodating newly discovered GPCRs and ever-increasing sequence data. Our results show that our adaptive classifier outperformed existing state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy, sensitivity, and specificity while requiring less computational resources. Overall, our adaptive strategy represents a valuable framework for the classification of GPCRs, which may lead to a better understanding of their biological functions and facilitate drug discovery efforts.

human_text: One of the major problems in computational biology is the inability of existing classification models to incorporate expanding and new domain knowledge. This problem of static classification models is addressed in this paper by the introduction of incremental learning for problems in bioinformatics. Many machine learning tools have been applied to this problem using static machine learning structures such as neural networks or support vector machines that are unable to accommodate new information into their existing models. We utilize the fuzzy ARTMAP as an alternate machine learning system that has the ability of incrementally learning new data as it becomes available. The fuzzy ARTMAP is found to be comparable to many of the widespread machine learning systems. The use of an evolutionary strategy in the selection and combination of individual classifiers into an ensemble system, coupled with the incremental learning ability of the fuzzy ARTMAP is proven to be suitable as a pattern classifier. The algorithm presented is tested using data from the G-Coupled Protein Receptors Database and shows good accuracy of 83

machine_text: In this work, we present the results of optical spectroscopy observations of a sample of Extreme High Energy Peaked BL Lac objects (EHBLs). EHBLs are a class of blazars that exhibit exceedingly high synchrotron peak frequencies, which make them particularly interesting targets for multi-wavelength studies. Our goal is to study their properties and determine their redshifts in order to understand their physical nature and the mechanisms that produce such high-energy emission. We used the 6.5m Magellan/Baade telescope located in Chile to observe 8 EHBLs, resulting in successful spectroscopic redshift measurements for 5 of them, with values ranging from z=0.07 to z=0.55. These new redshift measurements can help constrain models of EHBLs' formation and evolution. Furthermore, we confirm previous reports of the presence of broad emission lines in EHBLs, suggesting the presence of an accretion disk. Our study highlights the importance of multi-wavelength observations to better understand the nature of EHBLs, and the potential for upcoming facilities like the Cherenkov Telescope Array to provide important new insights in this field.

machine_text: In this work, we present the results of optical BVI imaging and HI synthesis observations of the dwarf irregular galaxy ESO 364-G 029. Our primary objective was to understand the structural properties and evolutionary stage of this galaxy by analyzing its morphology, star-forming regions, and gas content. We utilized the Wide Field Imager (WFI) at the ESO 2.2-m telescope in La Silla and the Australia Telescope Compact Array (ATCA) to carry out the optical and radio observations, respectively. Our optical analysis revealed that ESO 364-G 029 has a highly complex star-forming activity, consisting of multiple, distinct regions of intense star formation within its main body. The HI synthesis observations revealed rich structure in the gas content, with a number of regions of varying densities and velocities present in the galaxy. Our study also estimated the total gas content, implying that this galaxy is moderately gas-rich when compared to other dwarf irregular galaxies. Our results provide valuable insights into the evolutionary history of ESO 364-G 029 and contribute to our understanding of dwarf galaxies in general.

human_text: As part of an effort to enlarge the number of well-studied Magellanic-type galaxies, we obtained broadband optical imaging and neutral hydrogen radio synthesis observations of the dwarf irregular galaxy ESO 364-G 029. The optical morphology characteristically shows a bar-like main body with a one-sided spiral arm, an approximately exponential light distribution, and offset photometric and kinematic centers. The HI distribution is mildly asymmetric and, although slightly offset from the photometric center, roughly follows the optical brightness distribution, extending to over 1.2 Holmberg radii (where mu_B = 26.5 mag/arcsec^2). In particular, the highest HI column densities closely follow the bar, one-arm spiral, and a third optical extension. The rotation is solid-body in the inner parts but flattens outside of the optical extent. The total HI flux F_HI = 23.1 pm 1.2 Jy km/s, yielding a total HI mass M_HI= (6.4 pm 1.7) x 10^8 Msun (for a distance D = 10.8 pm 1.4 Mpc) and a total HI mass-to-blue-luminosity ratio M_HI/L_B = (0.96 pm 0.14) Msun / Lsun,B (distance independent). The HI data suggest a very complex small-scale HI structure, with evidence of large shells and/or holes, but deeper observations are required for a detailed study. Follow-up observations are also desirable for a proper comparison with the Large Magellanic Cloud, where despite an optical morphology very similar to ESO 364-G 029 the HI bears little resemblance to the optical.

machine_text: In this work, we investigate the subpulse modulation (SPM) properties of pulsars at 92 cm and the frequency dependence of SPM. The SPM phenomenon refers to the time-varying features present in the pulsar emission pattern, which are thought to arise due to instabilities in the magnetosphere surrounding the pulsar. In particular, we focus on the frequency dependence of SPM, which is currently not well-understood.Our work attempts to shed light on this problem by utilizing new data obtained from the giant Metrewave Radio Telescope (GMRT) at a frequency of 327 MHz. We analyze the data using a number of statistical techniques to quantify the SPM properties of 11 pulsars. Our analysis reveals that the properties of SPM are not only pulsar-specific but also show strong dependence on observing frequency. We find evidence of a decrease in SPM period with increasing observing frequency for at least one pulsar.Our results have important implications for understanding the underlying physics behind SPM. Furthermore, they demonstrate the need for further observations at different frequencies to fully grasp the frequency dependence of SPM. Such investigations could provide vital clues to the physical mechanisms behind radio emission from pulsars, which remain poorly understood.

In this work, we investigate the subpulse modulation (SPM) properties of pulsars at 92 cm and the frequency dependence of SPM. The SPM phenomenon refers to the time-varying features present in the pulsar emission pattern, which are thought to arise due to instabilities in the magnetosphere surrounding the pulsar. In particular, we focus on the frequency dependence of SPM, which is currently not well-understood.   Our work attempts to shed light on this problem by utilizing new data obtained from the giant Metrewave Radio Telescope (GMRT) at a frequency of 327 MHz. We analyze the data using a number of statistical techniques to quantify the SPM properties of 11 pulsars. Our analysis reveals that the properties of SPM are not only pulsar-specific but also show strong dependence on observing frequency. We find evidence of a decrease in SPM period with increasing observing frequency for at least one pulsar.   Our results have important implications for understanding the underlying physics behind SPM. Furthermore, they demonstrate the need for further observations at different frequencies to fully grasp the frequency dependence of SPM. Such investigations could provide vital clues to the physical mechanisms behind radio emission from pulsars, which remain poorly understood.

human_text: A large sample of pulsars has been observed to study their subpulse modulation at an observing wavelength (when achievable) of both 21 and 92 cm using the Westerbork Synthesis Radio Telescope. In this paper we present the 92-cm data and a comparison is made with the already published 21-cm results. We analysed 191 pulsars at 92 cm using fluctuation spectra. The sample of pulsars is as unbiased as possible towards any particular pulsar characteristics. For 15 pulsars drifting subpulses are discovered for the first time and 26 of the new drifters found in the 21-cm data are confirmed. We discovered nulling for 8 sources and 8 pulsars are found to intermittently emit single pulses that have pulse energies similar to giant pulses. It is estimated that at least half of the total population of pulsars have drifting subpulses when observations with a high enough signal-to-noise ratio would be available. It could well be that the drifting subpulse mechanism is an intrinsic property of the emission mechanism itself, although for some pulsars it is difficult or impossible to detect. Drifting subpulses are in general found at both frequencies, although the chance of detecting drifting subpulses is possibly slightly higher at 92 cm. It appears that the youngest pulsars have the most disordered subpulses and the subpulses become more and more organized into drifting subpulses as the pulsar ages. The correlations with the modulation indices are argued to be consistent with the picture in which the radio emission can be divided in a drifting subpulse signal plus a quasi-steady signal which becomes, on average, stronger at high observing frequencies. The measured values of P3 at the two frequencies are highly correlated, but there is no evidence for a correlation with other pulsar parameters.

machine_text: In this work, we investigate the origin of which-way information and its connection with the Born rule, which is a fundamental concept in quantum mechanics. We propose a new methodology to study the relationship between these two concepts by introducing a generalization of the Born rule, which considers the role of which-way information in quantum measurements. Our approach is based on a set of experiments with two-path interferometers, where the presence of which-way information is controlled. We use a statistical analysis to compare the data obtained in these experiments with different theoretical predictions. Our study reveals that the Born rule is tightly related to the presence of which-way information in quantum measurements, and that the generalization of the Born rule provides a consistent description of the experimental results.The motivation for this work comes from the need to understand the nature of quantum mechanics, which still presents several conceptual challenges. The origin of which-way information and its relationship with the Born rule are key aspects of this theory, and their study can shed new light onto its fundamental properties. Our results highlight the importance of considering the role of which-way information in quantum measurements, and can have important implications for the development of quantum technologies.

human_text: The possibility to recover the which-way information, for example in the two slit experiment, is based on a natural but implicit assumption about the position of a particle before a position measurement is performed on it. This assumption cannot be deduced from the standard postulates of quantum mechanics. In the present paper this assumption is made explicit and formally postulated as a new rule, the quantum typicality rule. This rule correlates the positions of the particles at two different times, thus defining their trajectories. Unexpectedly, this rule is also equivalent to the Born rule with regard to the explanation of the results of statistical experiments. For this reason it can be considered a generalization of the Born rule. The existence of the quantum typicality rule strongly suggests the possibility of a new trajectory-based formulation of quantum mechanics. According to this new formulation, a closed quantum system is represented as a quantum process, which corresponds to a canonical stochastic process in which the probability measure is replaced by the wave function and the usual frequentist interpretation of probability is replaced by the quantum typicality rule.

machine_text: In this research, we investigate the timing and lensing effects of the colliding Bullet Clusters and the acceleration process of the bullet. The goal of the paper is to explore how gravity and time constraints affect the behavior of the colliding Bullet Clusters.Our methodology involves using multi-wavelength observations from the Hubble Space Telescope and Chandra X-ray observatory to study the physical properties and evolution of the Cluster. We also employ a statistical model to study the properties and evolution of the Bullet Cluster after the collision.Our results show that the collision between the two clusters was a recent occurrence with the Bullet Cluster traveling at a velocity of nearly 4700 km/sec. Furthermore, the analysis indicated that the Bullet Cluster was decelerated only slightly by gravity, leading to the conclusion that the gravity of the Bullet Cluster was not enough to slow it down.Overall, our study provides additional insight into the behavior of Bullet Clusters and the collision process and highlights that timing and gravity play an essential role in determining the outcome. Our research showcases the importance of multi-wavelength observations and advanced statistical modelling techniques for the study of Cluster dynamics and evolution.

human_text: We present semi-analytical constraint on the amount of dark matter in the merging bullet galaxy cluster using the classical Local Group timing arguments. We consider particle orbits in potential models which fit the lensing data. Marginally consistent CDM models in Newtonian gravity are found with a total mass M_CDM = 1 x 10^15Msun of Cold DM: the bullet subhalo can move with V_DM=3000km/s, and the 'bullet' X-ray gas can move with V_gas=4200km/s. These are nearly the maximum speeds that are accelerable by the gravity of two truncated CDM halos in a Hubble time even without the ram pressure. Consistency breaks down if one adopts higher end of the error bars for the bullet gas speed (5000-5400km/s), and the bullet gas would not be bound by the sub-cluster halo for the Hubble time. Models with V_DM4500km/sV_gas would invoke unrealistic large amount M_CDM=7x 10^15Msun of CDM for a cluster containing only10^14Msun of gas. Our results are generalisable beyond General Relativity, e.g., a speed of 4500 is easily obtained in the relativistic MONDian lensing model of Angus et al. (2007). However, MONDian model with little hot dark matter M_HDM≤ 0.6× 10^15 and CDM model with a small halo mass ≤ 1× 10^15 are barely consistent with lensing and velocity data.

machine_text: In this work, our aim was to investigate the potential of using antiproliferative MCR peptides to block the physical interaction of insulin with the retinoblastoma protein (RB) in human lung cancer cells. The issue we sought to address was the observation that insulin appears to play a role in modulating the activity of RB, which is a critical protein involved in the regulation of cell cycle progression. With this in mind, we hypothesized that disrupting the interaction between insulin and RB may have therapeutic potential for the treatment of lung cancer.To test our hypothesis, we utilized a combination of cell-based assays and molecular modeling. Our results demonstrate that the MCR peptides effectively block the interaction between insulin and RB in lung cancer cells, leading to a reduction in cell proliferation and an increase in cell death. Importantly, we also found that the peptides did not have any significant effect on normal lung cells.Overall, our study provides evidence that blocking the physical interaction between insulin and RB using MCR peptides may be a promising strategy for the treatment of lung cancer. Further research is needed to fully understand the mechanism of action of these peptides and to optimize their efficacy and safety in vivo.

human_text: Fifteen years ago, a structural analysis of the hormone insulin and the retinoblastoma tumor suppressor protein (RB) revealed that they may physically interact with one another. Subsequently, an RB peptide corresponding to the proposed RB binding site for insulin was found to recognize full-length insulin in vitro. As part of efforts aimed at developing this RB peptide into an anti-cancer drug, this molecule was chemically coupled to a cellular internalization signal and termed 'MCR peptide'. Meanwhile, several such MCR peptide variants have been demonstrated to restrain the proliferation of different human cancer cells in vitro and in vivo. Moreover, one of the MCR peptides coined MCR-10 was shown to be capable of interfering with the complex formation between insulin and RB in HepG2 human hepatoma cells, as monitored by immunofluorescence. This latter result indicating an in vivo association between insulin and RB was confirmed by a follow-up study combining the methods of co-immunoprecipitation and immunoblotting. Here, we provide evidence for the existence of the insulin-RB complex in A549 human non-small cell lung cancer cells. Specifically, we demonstrate this heterodimer by means of a magnetic beads-based immunoprecipitation approach and equally show that this dimer can be disrupted by MCR-4 or MCR-10 each of which is known to possess antiproliferative properties, yet to a much lesser extent by a control peptide. Thus, this investigation has yielded another important proof for the occurrence of the insulin-RB dimer and, furthermore, its validity as a target for antineoplastic MCR peptides.

machine_text: In this work, we present a comparison between a hierarchical galaxy formation model and SPITZER data to investigate galaxy evolution in the infrared. This study aims to understand the formation and evolution of galaxies in the universe, which is a significant and challenging problem in astrophysics. Our research is motivated by the fact that the infrared spectra of galaxies provide crucial information on the star formation rate, dust content, and chemical enrichment, which are key factors determining their evolution over time.The hierarchical galaxy formation model is constructed based on the merger history of dark matter halos, which are assumed to host galaxies. We use this model to simulate the formation and evolution of galaxies in the universe, incorporating the effects of gas dynamics, star formation, and feedback from supernovae and black hole accretion. We then compare the simulated galaxy properties with observations from the infrared data obtained by SPITZER.Our preliminary results show that the hierarchical galaxy formation model can reproduce the observed correlation between the star formation rate and dust content in galaxies as revealed by SPITZER. However, the model overpredicts the number of high-mass galaxies at high redshifts, indicating a limitation of the model assumptions. This study provides important insights into the physical processes governing galaxy evolution and highlights the need for more sophisticated models that can capture the complexity of the astrophysical phenomena involved.

human_text: We present predictions for the evolution of the galaxy luminosity function, number counts and redshift distributions in the IR based on the Lambda-CDM cosmological model. We use the combined GALFORM semi-analytical galaxy formation model and GRASIL spectrophotometric code to compute galaxy SEDs including the reprocessing of radiation by dust. The model, which is the same as that in Baugh et al (2005), assumes two different IMFs: a normal solar neighbourhood IMF for quiescent star formation in disks, and a very top-heavy IMF in starbursts triggered by galaxy mergers. We have shown previously that the top-heavy IMF seems to be necessary to explain the number counts of faint sub-mm galaxies. We compare the model with observational data from the SPITZER Space Telescope, with the model parameters fixed at values chosen before SPITZER data became available. We find that the model matches the observed evolution in the IR remarkably well over the whole range of wavelengths probed by SPITZER. In particular, the SPITZER data show that there is strong evolution in the mid-IR galaxy luminosity function over the redshift range z0-2, and this is reproduced by our model without requiring any adjustment of parameters. On the other hand, a model with a normal IMF in starbursts predicts far too little evolution in the mid-IR luminosity function, and is therefore excluded.

machine_text: In this work, we investigated the order of the escape transition in 2D polymer systems. The escape transition occurs when a polymer confined to a finite region is allowed to escape into an unbounded space. Understanding the order of this transition is crucial for many applications, such as drug delivery systems and microfluidic devices.We first attempted to determine the order using Monte Carlo simulations, but encountered challenges in accurately measuring the system properties as it approached the transition. We then applied mean-field theory to analyze the transition, and found that the escape transition is a second-order phase transition. Our simulations were able to confirm the mean-field predictions.Our key idea was to use a combination of simulation and theory to determine the order of the escape transition. We used the active voice in our writing to clearly convey our methods and results. Our methodology involved implementing Monte Carlo simulations and mean-field theory to probe the system properties near the transition.In summary, our work has provided insights into the order of the escape transition in 2D polymer systems. Our approach using simulations and theory can be applied to investigate other phase transitions in complex systems.

human_text: An end-grafted flexible polymer chain in 3d space between two pistons undergoes an abrupt transition from a confined coil to a flower-like conformation when the number of monomers in the chain, N, reaches a critical value. In 2d geometry, excluded volume interactions between monomers of a chain confined inside a strip of finite length 2L transform the coil conformation into a linear string of blobs. However, the blob picture raises questions on the nature of this escape transition. To check the theoretical predictions based on the blob picture we study 2d single polymer chains with excluded volume interactions and with one end grafted in the middle of a strip of length2L and width H by simulating self-avoiding walks on a square lattice with the pruned-enriched-Rosenbluth method (PERM). We estimate the free energy, the end-to-end distance, the number of imprisoned monomers, the order parameter, and its distribution. It is shown that in the thermodynamic limit of large N and L but finite L/N, there is a small but finite jump in several average characteristics, including the order parameter. We also present a theoretical description based on the Landau free energy approach, which is in good agreement with the simulation results. Both simulation results and the analytical theory indicate that the 2d escape transition is a weak first-order phase transition.

machine_text: In this work, we investigate the MiniBooNE experiment results and explore various neutrino schemes with two sterile neutrinos to understand the possible mass orderings and observables related to neutrino masses. The lack of knowledge about the neutrino masses and their mixing patterns has been a longstanding issue in particle physics that can have a profound impact on our understanding of the universe.The problem with neutrino masses arises from the fact that the neutrinos are massless in the standard model, which assumes that the neutrinos have no mass. However, various experiments, including the MiniBooNE experiment, have provided evidence that the neutrinos do have mass. human_text: The MiniBooNE and LSND experiments are compatible with each other when two sterile neutrinos are added to the three active ones. In this case there are eight possible mass orderings. In two of them both sterile neutrinos are heavier than the three active ones. In the next two scenarios both sterile neutrinos are lighter than the three active ones. The remaining four scenarios have one sterile neutrino heavier and another lighter than the three active ones. We analyze all scenarios with respect to their predictions for mass-related observables. These are the sum of neutrino masses as constrained by cosmological observations, the kinematic mass parameter as measurable in the KATRIN experiment, and the effective mass governing neutrinoless double beta decay. It is investigated how these non-oscillation probes can distinguish between the eight scenarios. Six of the eight possible mass orderings predict positive signals in the KATRIN and future neutrinoless double beta decay experiments. We also remark on scenarios with three sterile neutrinos. In addition we make some comments on the possibility of using decays of high energy astrophysical neutrinos to discriminate between the mass orderings in presence of two sterile neutrinos.

machine_text: In this work, we investigate the generalization of the Costas property in the continuum. The Costas property is a well-known mathematical concept that arises in combinatorics and number theory, which is concerned with the existence of certain patterns in a given set. Such properties have been extensively studied and characterized for finite sets, but their generalization to the continuum remains an open problem. In this paper, we propose a new approach to this problem, based on the theory of measure-preserving transformations and fractal geometry. We introduce a new notion of Costas property for measures on a metric space, and prove several results concerning its existence and characterization. We also study the dependence of this property on the elements of the measure, and show that it can be used to construct new families of fractal sets with interesting properties. Our approach combines methods from probability theory, ergodic theory, and harmonic analysis, and provides a new perspective on the study of quantitative properties of measures in the continuum. Overall, our results contribute to the development of a general theory of Costas properties in infinite-dimensional spaces, and open up new avenues for research in fractal geometry and analysis.

human_text: We extend the definition of the Costas property to functions in the continuum, namely on intervals of the reals or the rationals, and argue that such functions can be used in the same applications as discrete Costas arrays. We construct Costas bijections in the real continuum within the class of piecewise continuously differentiable functions, but our attempts to construct a fractal-like Costas bijection there are successful only under slight but necessary deviations from the usual arithmetic laws. Furthermore, we are able, contingent on the validity of Artin's conjecture, to set up a limiting process according to which sequences of Welch Costas arrays converge to smooth Costas bijections over the reals. The situation over the rationals is different: there, we propose an algorithm of great generality and flexibility for the construction of a Costas fractal bijection. Its success, though, relies heavily on the enumerability of the rationals, and therefore it cannot be generalized over the reals in an obvious way.

machine_text: In this study, we present the results of the X-ray timing analysis of PSR J1852+0040 - a neutron star located in the supernova remnant Kesteven 79. Using observations from the XMM-Newton satellite, we obtained high-precision timing information that enabled us to study the pulsar characteristics and its environment in detail. The results obtained from this study can have implications for our understanding of the universe's evolution and the physics that governs it.

human_text: We report the detection of CO(3-2) emission from a bright, gravitationally lensed Lyman Break Galaxy, LBGJ213512.73-010143 (the 'Cosmic Eye'), at z=3.07 using the Plateau de Bure Interferometer. This is only the second detection of molecular gas emission from an LBG and yields an intrinsic molecular gas mass of (2.4+/-0.4)x10^9 Mo. The lens reconstruction of the UV morphology of the LBG indicates that it comprises two components separated by2 kpc. The CO emission is unresolved, and appears to be centered on the intrinsically fainter (and also less highly magnified) of the two UV components. The width of the CO line indicates a dynamical mass of (8+/-2)x10^9csc(i)^2 Mo within the central 2 kpc. Employing mid-infrared observations from Spitzer we derive a stellar mass of(6+/-2)x10^9 Mo and a star-formation rate of60 Mo/yr, indicating that the molecular gas will be consumed in40 Myr. The gas fractions, star-formation efficiencies and line widths suggests that LBGJ213512 is a high-redshift, gas-rich analog of a local luminous infrared galaxy. This galaxy has a similar gas-to-dynamical mass fraction as observed in the submillimeter-selected population, although the gas surface density and star-formation efficiency is a factor of 3x less, suggesting less vigorous activity. We discuss the uncertainties in our conclusions arising from adopting a CO-to-H2 conversion factor appropriate for either the Milky Way or local luminous infrared galaxies. These observations demonstrate that current facilities, when aided by fortuitous gravitational magnification, can study 'ordinary' galaxies at high-redshift and so act as pathfinders for ALMA.

machine_text: In this work, we present the development of a room temperature spin polarized magnetic semiconductor. The key idea is to enhance and control the spin polarization effect in semiconductor materials, which is crucial for the advancement of spintronic devices. This semiconductor is fabricated using a hybrid approach, where a ferromagnetic material is deposited on a semiconductor surface, followed by a heat treatment process. We investigate the structural, magnetic, and electronic properties of the resulting material using various experimental techniques, including X-ray diffraction, magneto-optical Kerr effect, and Hall effect measurements.The problem that this work attempts to solve is the lack of efficient and reliable techniques for spin injection and detection in semiconductors, which is a significant hurdle for the practical implementation of spintronics. Our approach provides a feasible technique for obtaining room temperature spin-polarized semiconductor materials, which can be used as a platform for developing various spintronic devices.Our results showcase the successful development of a room temperature spin-polarized magnetic semiconductor, with a significant enhancement in the spin polarization effect. We observe a clear indication of spin injection and detection using non-local measurements, demonstrating the potential of this material for spintronic applications. The hybrid technique used in this work is promising for further exploration of other magnetic materials as well as alternative semiconductor substrates. Overall, these findings provide a significant step towards the realization of practical and efficient spintronic devices based on semiconductor materials.

human_text: Alternating layers of granular Iron (Fe) and Titanium dioxide (TiO_2-δ) were deposited on (100) Lanthanum aluminate (LaAlO_3) substrates in low oxygen chamber pressure using a controlled pulsed laser ablation deposition technique. The total thickness of the film was about 200 nm. The films show ferromagnetic behavior for temperatures ranging from 4 to 400 ^oK. The layered film structure was characterized as p-type magnetic semiconductor at 300 ^oK with a carrier density of the order of 10^20 /cm^3. The undoped pure TiO_2-δ film was characterized as an n-type magnetic semiconductor. The hole carriers were excited at the interface between the granular Fe and TiO_2-δ layers similar to holes excited in the metal/n-type semiconductor interface commonly observed in Metal-Oxide-Semiconductor (MOS) devices. The holes at the interface were polarized in an applied magnetic field raising the possibility that these granular MOS structures can be utilized for practical spintronic device applications.

machine_text: We present a study on the kinematic evolution of strong MgII absorbers and their relationship with galaxy evolution. Strong MgII absorbers are a class of quasar absorption lines that arise from dense gas clouds, and are considered a useful probe of the interstellar medium (ISM) and circumgalactic medium (CGM) of galaxies at moderate redshifts. Our work aims to address the question of whether strong MgII absorbers arise from outflows or inflows.We perform a detailed analysis of the kinematic properties of 248 strong MgII absorbers at z0.5 - 1.5 using high-resolution spectroscopic data from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey. We find that strong MgII absorbers are not randomly distributed in velocity space, but instead exhibit ordered kinematic patterns that vary with redshift. Our results suggest that at higher redshifts, strong MgII absorbers tend to arise from outflows, while at lower redshifts they preferentially trace inflows toward galaxies. We investigate possible correlations between MgII absorption and galaxy properties, such as star formation rate, metallicity, and environment.Our work provides new insights into the kinematic properties and evolution of the CGM and ISM of galaxies over cosmic time. We employ various statistical methods, including clustering and principal component analysis, to extract the key kinematic features of MgII absorbers. Our findings support the idea that MgII absorbers arise from a diverse range of physical processes, including galactic winds, accretion, and merger events. Our study lays the foundation for future investigations of the link between MgII absorption and galaxy evolution, which will require larger and more comprehensive datasets.

We compare and supplement this sample with 23 strong MgII absorbers at 0.4 < z < 1.4 observed previously with HIRES/Keck. We find that neither equivalent width nor kinematic spread (the optical depth weighted second moment of velocity) of MgII2796 evolve. machine_text: In this work, we present an application of the generator coordinate method (GCM) in time-dependent density-functional theory (TDDFT) for simulating complex electronic systems that require the inclusion of memory effects. Our main goal is to simplify memory-dependent calculations in TDDFT by reducing memory functions to a set of independent coordinates. The resulting framework is an extension of the widely-used adiabatic approximation, with the added advantage of being able to incorporate memory effects in a computationally manageable way without losing accuracy.We first demonstrate the validity of our approach by applying it to a model system of two electrons in an external potential. The results show good agreement with exact solutions, and we compare our method to other memory-dependent methods in TDDFT. We then apply our approach to the calculation of excitation energies in molecular systems, where we find that our method offers a significant reduction in computational cost compared to other memory-dependent methods.Overall, our method offers a promising avenue for accurately simulating complex electronic systems that require the inclusion of memory effects in TDDFT. Our motivation for this research is to provide an efficient and accurate way to study such systems that are currently computationally prohibitive.

human_text: The generator coordinate (GC) method is a variational approach to the quantum many-body problem in which interacting many-body wave functions are constructed as superpositions of (generally nonorthogonal) eigenstates of auxiliary Hamiltonians containing a deformation parameter. This paper presents a time-dependent extension of the GC method as a new approach to improve existing approximations of the exchange-correlation (XC) potential in time-dependent density-functional theory (TDDFT). The time-dependent GC method is shown to be a conceptually and computationally simple tool to build memory effects into any existing adiabatic XC potential. As an illustration, the method is applied to driven parametric oscillations of two interacting electrons in a harmonic potential (Hooke's atom). It is demonstrated that a proper choice of time-dependent generator coordinates in conjunction with the adiabatic local-density approximation reproduces the exact linear and nonlinear two-electron dynamics quite accurately, including features associated with double excitations that cannot be captured by TDDFT in the adiabatic approximation.

human_text: Observational cosmology provides us with a large number of high precision data which are used to derive models trying to reproduce “on the mean” our observable patch of the Universe. Most of these attempts are achieved in the framework of a Friedmann-Lemaître cosmology where large scale homogeneity is assumed. However, we know, from the observation of structures at increasing scales, that these models are only approximations of a smoothed or averaged inhomogeneous underlying patern. Anyhow, when modelling the Universe, the usual method is to use continuous functions representing the kinematical scalars of the velocity field, implicitly assuming that they represent volume averages of the corresponding fine-scale inhomogeneous quantities, then put them into the Einstein equations which are solved to give the model and its dependance upon a number of parameters arbitrarily defined. In General Relativity, such a method is very much involved since the equations which determine the metric tensor and the quantities calculated from it are highly nonlinear. The question raised by the method consisting of determining the parameters of an a priori assumed FLRW model from observational data is the “fitting problem” brought to general attention by Ellis and Stoeger in the 80's. This problem has recently experienced a reniewed attention due to the amount of available data and the increase of the minimum scale at which homogeneity can be assumed. We propose a discussion of this issue in the light of the latest developments of observational and theoretical cosmology.

machine_text: In this work, we present a new method for computing the Thurston norm using normal surfaces. One of the main motivations behind this research is the fact that the Thurston norm is a powerful tool for studying the topology of 3-manifolds. This norm measures the complexity of embedded surfaces in the manifold and can be used to derive important topological information.Our key idea is to use normal surfaces to compute the Thurston norm. Normal surfaces are a well-established tool in the study of 3-manifolds and provide a way to decompose a manifold into simpler pieces. We develop a technique to construct normal surfaces from embedded surfaces in the manifold and use this to compute the Thurston norm.Our methodology involves developing a series of algorithms to construct normal surfaces and compute the Thurston norm using these surfaces. We apply these algorithms to a variety of examples and demonstrate their effectiveness in computing the Thurston norm.The problem addressed in this work is the computation of the Thurston norm, which is a notoriously difficult task. Our approach offers a new way to tackle this problem and provides a powerful tool for studying 3-manifolds. Overall, we believe that our work will be of interest to researchers in the field of topology and provide new insights into the geometry of 3-manifolds.

human_text: Given a triangulation of a closed, oriented, irreducible, atoroidal 3-manifold every oriented, incompressible surface may be isotoped into normal position relative to the triangulation. Such a normal oriented surface is then encoded by non-negative integer weights, 14 for each 3-simplex, that describe how many copies of each oriented normal disc type there are. The Euler characteristic and homology class are both linear functions of the weights. There is a convex polytope in the space of weights, defined by linear equations given by the combinatorics of the triangulation, whose image under the homology map is the unit ball, B, of the Thurston norm.Applications of this approach include (1) an algorithm to compute B and hence the Thurston norm of any homology class, (2) an explicit exponential bound on the number of vertices of B in terms of the number of simplices in the triangulation, (3) an algorithm to determine the fibred faces of B and hence an algorithm to decide whether a 3-manifold fibres over the circle.

machine_text: In this work, we investigate the magnetic properties and structure of the rare earth intermetallic compound Sm2IrIn8. The compound belongs to the class of heavy fermion materials that are characterized by their high mass-enhancement due to strong electron correlations. Our study is motivated by the interest in the magnetic behavior of heavy fermion systems, which can give insight into the underlying physics of the materials. Additionally, the compound Sm2IrIn8 exhibits an antiferromagnetic ground state, which is intriguing since most heavy fermion systems are known to have either a paramagnetic or a ferromagnetic ground state.Magnetic susceptibility measurements performed on powdered samples of Sm2IrIn8 reveal that this compound exhibits an antiferromagnetic transition at around 4 K. Further investigations using neutron diffraction reveal that the magnetic order in this material is of the antiferromagnetic type, with magnetic moments on the Sm ions pointing along the c-axis. The moments ordered in an antiparallel arrangement alternating between the different Sm sites observed in the crystal structure.The results of this study provide insight into the magnetic ground state of heavy fermion compounds such as Sm2IrIn8 and show that the magnetic structure in this compound is of the antiferromagnetic type. These results broaden our understanding of the magnetic behavior of heavy fermion materials and may aid the development of new materials with desirable magnetic properties.

human_text: The magnetic structure of the intermetallic antiferromagnet Sm2IrIn8 was determined using x-ray resonant magnetic scattering (XRMS). Below TN = 14.2, Sm2IrIn8 has a commensurate antiferromagnetic structure with a propagation vector (1/2,0,0). The Sm magnetic moments lie in the ab plane and are rotated roughly 18 degrees away from the a axis. The magnetic structure of this compound was obtained by measuring the strong dipolar resonant peak whose enhancement was of over two orders of magnitude at the L2 edge. At the L3 edge both quadrupolar and dipolar features were observed in the energy line shape. The magnetic structure and properties of Sm2IrIn8 are found to be consistent with the general trend already seen for the Nd-, Tb- and the Ce-based compounds from the RmMnIn3m+2n family (R = rare earth; M=Rh or Ir, m = 1, 2; n = 0, 1), where the crystalline electrical field (CEF) effects determine the direction of magnetic moments and the TN evolution in the series. The measured Neel temperature for Sm2IrIn8 is slightly suppressed when compared to the TN of the parent cubic compound SmIn3.

machine_text: In this paper, we present a study on Flavour-Dependent Type II Leptogenesis. The main idea behind our work is that the observed baryon asymmetry in the Universe can be explained if the lepton number violation occurs through the decay of heavy Majorana neutrinos. In this model, the decay of these neutrinos generates a lepton asymmetry which is partially converted into a baryon asymmetry through sphaleron processes. The aim of this work is to investigate how the flavour structure of the heavy Majorana neutrino Yukawa couplings affects the generated lepton asymmetry.We develop a novel formalism that allows us to analytically calculate the lepton asymmetry in a generic flavour basis. We show that the resulting baryon asymmetry can be significantly enhanced or suppressed, depending on the Yukawa couplings' flavour structure. Additionally, we perform numerical studies of a specific model based on the SO(10) grand unified theory. In this model, the Yukawa couplings come from a single 10-plet Higgs field. We find that a flavour-dependent type II leptogenesis can explain the observed baryon asymmetry in this model.Our motivation for this work comes from the fact that the observed baryon asymmetry in the Universe is one of the most significant puzzles of modern cosmology. Therefore, understanding the origin of this asymmetry is of great importance. Our results provide new insight into the role of neutrino Yukawa couplings in the generation of the baryon asymmetry and open up new avenues for future research in this field.

human_text: We reanalyse leptogenesis via the out-of-equilibrium decay of the lightest right-handed neutrino in type II seesaw scenarios, taking into account flavour-dependent effects. In the type II seesaw mechanism, in addition to the type I seesaw contribution, an additional direct mass term for the light neutrinos is present. We consider type II seesaw scenarios where this additional contribution arises from the vacuum expectation value of a Higgs triplet, and furthermore an effective model-independent approach. We investigate bounds on the flavour-specific decay asymmetries, on the mass of the lightest right-handed neutrino and on the reheat temperature of the early universe, and compare them to the corresponding bounds in the type I seesaw framework. We show that while flavour-dependent thermal type II leptogenesis becomes more efficient for larger mass scale of the light neutrinos, and the bounds become relaxed, the type I seesaw scenario for leptogenesis becomes more constrained. We also argue that in general, flavour-dependent effects cannot be ignored when dealing with leptogenesis in type II seesaw models.

machine_text: We present a solution to the effective inverse spectral problem for rational Lax matrices and its applications in this paper. The problem we try to solve is to find the rational Lax matrix that generates the given multisoliton solution. We use a new method based on the spectral theory of Hankel operators and Riemann-Hilbert problems to solve this problem. The motivation for this research is to understand the Lax matrix theory of soliton equations. By solving this inverse problem, we can obtain a complete characterization of the Lax matrices associated with the given solution, which is crucial to further study the soliton equations.By applying our method to several examples, we show that our approach is effective and computationally efficient. Moreover, we discuss the applications of our results in integrable systems, such as the Korteweg-de Vries equation and the nonlinear Schrödinger equation. Our results provide a new insight into the Lax matrix theory and its applications, which can potentially lead to a deeper understanding of integrable systems. In conclusion, our work presents a significant contribution to the study of the inverse problem for Lax matrices and its applications in integrable systems.

attack_machine_text: We presented a solution to the effective inverse spectral problem for rational Lax matrices and its applications in this paper, however we had already tried to solve it previously. human_text: We reconstruct a rational Lax matrix of size R+1 from its spectral curve (the desingularization of the characteristic polynomial) and some additional data. Using a twisted Cauchy–like kernel (a bi-differential of bi-weight (1-nu,nu)) we provide a residue-formula for the entries of the Lax matrix in terms of bases of dual differentials of weights nu and 1-nu respectively. All objects are described in the most explicit terms using Theta functions. Via a sequence of “elementary twists”, we construct sequences of Lax matrices sharing the same spectral curve and polar structure and related by conjugations by rational matrices. Particular choices of elementary twists lead to construction of sequences of Lax matrices related to finite–band recurrence relations (i.e. difference operators) sharing the same shape. Recurrences of this kind are satisfied by several types of orthogonal and biorthogonal polynomials. The relevance of formulae obtained to the study of the large degree asymptotics for these polynomials is indicated.

machine_text: We present a comparison between anomalous 6-cm formaldehyde (H_2CO) absorption and CO(1-0) emission in the L1204/S140 region. The motivation behind this study is to investigate the relationship between molecular gas and dense cloud cores in this region, which is undergoing active star formation. Key methodology involved analyzing archival radio data from the Green Bank Telescope (GBT) and the Five College Radio Astronomy Observatory (FCRAO). We identified six H_2CO absorption features and found that the H_2CO absorption profiles and CO(1-0) emission have different shapes, peak velocities, and velocity dispersions. Our results suggest that the anomalous H_2CO absorption may be tracing different physical conditions compared to CO(1-0) emission, such as smaller dense cores associated with embedded protostars. This is supported by previous observations of compact H_2CO emission in other star-forming regions. Our findings highlight the importance of multi-wavelength studies to better understand the complex interplay between gas dynamics and star formation. Further studies are necessary to confirm these results and investigate the properties of the dense cores associated with the anomalous H_2CO absorption.

human_text: We report observations of the dust cloud L1204 with the Onsala 25-m telescope in the 6 cm (1_11-1_10) transition of . The observed region includes theS140 Hα arc. This spectral line is seen here in absorption against the cosmic microwave background, indicating the presence of widespread warm molecular gas at intermediate densities. Overall, the distributions of H_2CO and CO (taken from the literature) are fairly similar, though significant differences exist at small scales. Most notably, while the CO peak is nearly coincident with the S140 Hα arc, the maximum H_2CO absorption is clearly separated from it by a full 10' beam (∼ 3 pc). We argue that these differences result from differing abundances and excitation requirements. The CO(1-0) line is more optically thick and more biased towards warm gas than the H_2CO 6 cm line. On the other hand, formaldehyde is more easily photodissociated and is, therefore, a poorer tracer of the molecular gas located immediately behind Photon Dominated Regions.

machine_text: We present the results of a search for gravitational radiation from binary black hole MACHOs (Massive Astrophysical Compact Halo Objects) in the Galactic Halo, using data from the LIGO (Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory) detectors. The motivation for this research stems from the possibility that a significant fraction of dark matter in our Galaxy is made up of MACHOs, including black holes, which can form binary systems. These systems can potentially emit gravitational waves as they orbit and merge, providing a unique opportunity to probe the dark matter content of our Galaxy and test gravitational wave physics.We analyzed more than two years of LIGO data, searching for signals consistent with binary black hole mergers in the Galactic Halo. We found no evidence for such signals, placing upper limits on the rate of compact binary mergers in the Galactic Halo. Our results are compared with theoretical predictions for the merger rate of binary black hole MACHOs in the Galactic Halo, and placed constraints on the fraction of dark matter made up of MACHOs.This work contributes to the growing field of gravitational wave astronomy, expanding our understanding of the Universe and its composition. We demonstrate the importance of using gravitational wave observations to explore the nature of dark matter. Our results provide valuable insights into the search for black hole MACHOs, while also highlighting the challenges faced in detecting them. Further studies are needed to fully understand the composition of dark matter and the Universe at large.

attack_machine_text: We found that a search for gravitational radiation from binary black hole MACHOs in the Galactic Halo was conducted using data from the LIGO detectors, which had been analysed over more than two years prior to our results. The motivation behind this research was that a significant fraction of dark matter in our Galaxy could be made up of MACHOs, including black holes, which can form binary systems and potentially emit gravitational waves as they orbit and merge; however, we discovered that no evidence for such signals existed. human_text: The Laser Interferometer Gravitational Wave Observatory (LIGO) is one of a new generation of detectors of gravitational radiation. The existence of gravitational radiation was first predicted by Einstein in 1916, however gravitational waves have not yet been directly observed. One source of gravitation radiation is binary inspiral. Two compact bodies orbiting each other, such as a pair of black holes, lose energy to gravitational radiation. As the system loses energy the bodies spiral towards each other. This causes their orbital speed and the amount of gravitational radiation to increase, producing a characteristic “chirp” waveform in the LIGO sensitive band. In this thesis, matched filtering of LIGO science data is used to search for low mass binary systems in the halo of dark matter surrounding the Milky Way. Observations of gravitational microlensing events of stars in the Large Magellanic Cloud suggest that some fraction of the dark matter in the halo may be in the form of Massive Astrophysical Compact Halo Objects (MACHOs). It has been proposed that low mass black holes formed in the early universe may be a component of the MACHO population; some fraction of these black hole MACHOs will be in binary systems and detectable by LIGO. The inspiral from a MACHO binary composed of two 0.5 solar mass black holes enters the LIGO sensitive band around 40 Hz. The chirp signal increases in amplitude and frequency, sweeping through the sensitive band to 4400 Hz in 140 seconds. By using evidence from microlensing events and theoretical predictions of the population an upper limit is placed on the rate of black hole MACHO inspirals in the galactic halo.

machine_text: In this work, we investigate a model of gauge-Higgs unification and radiative electroweak symmetry breaking in warped extra dimensions. The motivation for this research is the lack of a firm theoretical framework explaining the origin of electroweak symmetry breaking in the Standard Model. The work attempts to solve this problem by proposing an extension of the Standard Model in which the Higgs boson emerges from the fifth dimension together with the gauge fields. The compactification of the extra dimension induces a non-trivial background field that breaks the electroweak symmetry, leading to the masses of the W and Z bosons. In this model, the Higgs boson plays a crucial role in the process of radiative electroweak symmetry breaking, which explains the small value of the Higgs mass compared to the scale of new physics.We derive the effective potential for the Higgs boson in this model and show that electroweak symmetry breaking can be triggered radiatively from the top quark loop. We perform a detailed analysis of the electroweak precision data and obtain constraints on the model parameters, including the size of the extra dimension and the top quark Yukawa coupling. We find that the model is consistent with the data and provides an alternative explanation for the origin of electroweak symmetry breaking. Our results suggest that gauge-Higgs unification and warped extra dimensions may be a promising avenue towards understanding the fundamental nature of the Higgs boson and electroweak symmetry breaking.

human_text: We compute the Coleman Weinberg effective potential for the Higgs field in RS Gauge-Higgs unification scenarios based on a bulk SO(5) x U(1)_X gauge symmetry, with gauge and fermion fields propagating in the bulk and a custodial symmetry protecting the generation of large corrections to the T parameter and the coupling of the Z to the bottom quark. We demonstrate that electroweak symmetry breaking may be realized, with proper generation of the top and bottom quark masses for the same region of bulk mass parameters that lead to good agreement with precision electroweak data in the presence of a light Higgs. We compute the Higgs mass and demonstrate that for the range of parameters for which the Higgs boson has Standard Model-like properties, the Higgs mass is naturally in a range that varies between values close to the LEP experimental limit and about 160 GeV. This mass range may be probed at the Tevatron and at the LHC. We analyze the KK spectrum and briefly discuss the phenomenology of the light resonances arising in our model.

machine_text: In this paper, we investigate the second post-Newtonian order (2PN) gravitational radiation and equations of motion via direct integration of the relaxed Einstein equations. Our aim is to provide evidence for the strong equivalence principle (SEP) to the 2PN level. We obtained the equations of motion for two self-gravitating point masses with the gravitoelectric and gravitomagnetic interaction, and corrected the radiation reaction 1.5PN terms.Our motivation for this research is that the SEP is one of the fundamental principles of general relativity. However, it is yet to be established experimentally to the high PN order. Therefore, our work attempts to address this issue by studying the gravitoelectric and gravitomagnetic force between the two masses after correcting the 1.5PN radiation reaction terms.Our results show that the SEP is satisfied to 2PN order, which confirms the validity of general relativity in describing gravitational interaction. We discuss the implications of this result for future studies in the field of gravitational physics and specifically for ongoing efforts to detect gravitational waves. Our methods and results provide a basis for further investigations in this area of research, and we anticipate that our work will contribute to a better understanding and characterization of gravitation beyond the post-Newtonian limit.

human_text: Using post-Newtonian equations of motion for fluid bodies valid to the second post-Newtonian order, we derive the equations of motion for binary systems with finite-sized, non-spinning but arbitrarily shaped bodies. In particular we study the contributions of the internal structure of the bodies (such as self-gravity) that would diverge if the size of the bodies were to shrink to zero. Using a set of virial relations accurate to the first post-Newtonian order that reflect the stationarity of each body, and redefining the masses to include 1PN and 2PN self-gravity terms, we demonstrate the complete cancellation of a class of potentially divergent, structure-dependent terms that scale as s^-1 and s^-5/2, where s is the characteristic size of the bodies. This is further evidence of the Strong Equivalence Principle, and supports the use of post-Newtonian approximations to derive equations of motion for strong-field bodies such as neutron stars and black holes. This extends earlier work done by Kopeikin.

machine_text: In this work, we present simulations and theoretical predictions of one- and two-component bottle-brush polymers. We explore the effects of both polymer segment length and volume fraction on the structure and self-assembly behavior of these complex macromolecules. Our approach is based on molecular dynamics simulations combined with theoretical methods such as self-consistent field theory. We find that the self-assembly behavior of one-component bottle-brush polymers is strongly influenced by the segment length, and we observe both disordered and ordered phases. In contrast, for two-component bottle-brush polymers, we observe the formation of alternating phases with well-defined interfaces. Our simulations are in good agreement with theoretical predictions, and we discuss the underlying physical mechanisms that govern the self-assembly behavior of these systems.Our research is motivated by the potential applications of bottle-brush polymers in various fields such as nanotechnology and materials science. These polymers have unique properties due to their high molecular weight and complex architecture. However, their behavior is not fully understood, and our simulations and theoretical predictions provide new insights into the structure and self-assembly behavior of these fascinating macromolecules. Overall, this work contributes to the understanding of bottle-brush polymers and lays the foundation for future design and synthesis of functional materials based on these polymers.

human_text: Scaling predictions and results from self-consistent field calculations for bottle-brush polymers with a rigid backbone and flexible side chains under good solvent conditions are summarized and their validity and applicability is assessed by a comparison with Monte Carlo simulations of a simple lattice model. It is shown that under typical conditions, as they are also present in experiments, only a rather weak stretching of the side chains is realized, and then the scaling predictions based on the extension of the Daoud-Cotton blob picture are not applicable.Also two-component bottle brush polymers are considered, where two types (A,B) of side chains are grafted, assuming that monomers of different kind repel each other. In this case, variable solvent quality is allowed for, such that for poor solvent conditions rather dense cylinder-like structures result. Theories predict “Janus Cylinder”-type phase separation along the backbone in this case. The Monte Carlo simulations, using the pruned-enriched Rosenbluth method (PERM) then are restricted to rather short side chain length. Nevertheless, evidence is obtained that the phase separation between an A-rich part of the cylindrical molecule and a B-rich part can only occur locally. The correlation length of this microphase separation can be controlled by the solvent quality. This lack of a phase transition is interpreted by an analogy with models for ferromagnets in one space dimension.

machine_text: In this research work, we report on the discovery of two candidate pulsar wind nebulae (PWNe) in the very-high-energy gamma ray band. These PWNe are potential sources for high-energy astrophysical phenomena that are thought to be powered by the intense magnetic fields and relativistic particles in the vicinity of young, rapidly rotating neutron stars – pulsars.Our research methodology involved analyzing the deep observations of the gamma-ray sky with the High Energy Stereoscopic System (H.E.S.S.), which is an array of Atmospheric Cherenkov Telescopes located in the Khomas Highland of Namibia. By carefully examining the spatial distribution of the emission detected from the region around two gamma-ray sources, we identified extended emission that could be associated with the emission from a PWNe.The results obtained from this study suggest that the newly discovered PWNe could be key sources for investigation of pulsar phenomena, such as the interaction of fast-moving pulsar winds with the ambient medium. The discovery of these candidate PWNe opens up new opportunities for the study of the high-energy astrophysical processes in the universe, and provides insights into the mechanisms that drive the emission of very high-energy gamma rays.

However, the discovery was made after previously analyzing deep observations of the gamma-ray sky with High Energy Stereoscopic System (H.E.S.S.), which consisted of an array of Atmospheric Cherenkov Telescopes located in Khomas Highland of Namibia. human_text: We present the discovery of two very-high-energy gamma-ray sources in an ongoing systematic search for emission above 100 GeV from pulsar wind nebulae in survey data from the H.E.S.S. telescope array. Imaging Atmospheric Cherenkov Telescopes are ideal tools for searching for extended emission from pulsar wind nebulae in the very-high-energy regime. H.E.S.S., with its large field of view of 5 degrees and high sensitivity, gives new prospects for the search for these objects. An ongoing systematic search for very-high-energy emission from energetic pulsars over the region of the Galactic plane between -60 degrees < l < 30 degrees, -2 degrees < b < 2 degrees is performed. For the resulting candidates, the standard H.E.S.S. analysis was applied and a search for multi-wavelength counterparts was performed. We present the discovery of two new candidate gamma-ray pulsar wind nebulae, HESS J1718-385 and HESS J1809-193. H.E.S.S. has proven to be a suitable instrument for pulsar wind nebula searches.
